description:
First thing that caught my attention is the GREAT music! If you're born in the 80's you're going to love the throwback rnb! They were playing all the jams!!! I just wanted to sit there and listen to the music all night.

Food is excellent  super flavorful broth; noodles are cooked perfectly. Rolls are 4 pieces, however, they're hella good and only 7 bucks. Wakame salad was super good as well.

Server is really attentive and quick on his feet. The only thing he forgot was our tea (which isn't a big deal), I'm still sticking with my 5 star rating.

I'll definitely be a regular as I live down the street!
author: Lena J.

description:
Cozy and small restaurant. I loved the modern simplistic look. 

Their menus are very straightforward and their ramens are well made. I got the chicken shoyu ramen with grated garlic. it was flavorful and refreshing. I highly recommend this place if you want a solid bowl of ramen! 

UPDATE:

I really loved this place! I would come all the way from Excelsior to eat their ramen, but tonight might be my last time. 

We got seated at around 7:50pm or so and we ordered right away. It took 30-40 minutes for our food to come and all we got were 2 ramens and a roll. People who were seated after us got their bento boxes within 10-15 minutes. What gives! I knew that this place typically had slow service but tonight was extra slow for some reason. The restaurant was only half full, too... I was absolutely hangry! 

Only saving grace was our server. He was thoroughly apologetic and even gave us a bowl of miso soup on the house! Bless you, kind server.
author: Chia W.

description:
Been here twice. First time was good but second time I regretted.

On second visit I ordered the pork base shoyu ramen with extra assorted veggies and soup was so bland it was shocking. It didn't taste like much of anything but pork soup. Not sure if they forgot to add the shoyu but it was definitely bad. And the assorted veggies? Save yourself the $3. Not worth it either.

The only saving grace was the salmon sashimi and takoyaki but I wouldn't return just for that and overall don't recommend it.
author: Hello E.

description:
We found this place after a great hike in lands end. It's only a mile away from Land's End and it's located in a cute neighborhood across the road from the theater. 

We were lucky that we got there when there were a couple tables available as it got quite busy very quickly and we could see the wait line outside the store the entire time we were there. 

Ramen was great and sushi was good too. What I didn't like was how close the tables are and how easy it was to hear all the other tables. People were also quite load which is annoying when you're trying to relax and enjoy your dinner. So not very ideal for a date, at least on weekends.
author: Afshin D.

description:
This restaurant is small, cozy, and dimly lit. I came here on a Thursday night ~7 pm and there was a 25 min wait. Kinda not bad, kinda not great either but I guess since it's small inside w limited tables a line can form pretty fast. My friend and I decided to go to the bar next door while we waited so it worked out :) 

I got the spicy miso tonkotsu ramen + corn and also the hot sake and Sapporo. The ramen was flavorful, rich, and delicious! I wish it had more meat... but besides that, it was pretty tasty! 

This place is great for small groups or couples/individuals, and vice versa, if you have a party of 4+ you'll be taking up half the restaurant haha. This is a gr8 hole in the wall
author: Joy K.

description:
It's a small place - we got lucky and walked in right as a table was clearing - but I think often there is a wait.

We got tempura for an appetizer. It was quite nice. Well fried, etc.

We got Ramen with the garlic soy broth and enjoyed it. Rich broth. Rich Noodles. Egg was appropriately medium. Good meat. They do charge you extra for a lot of things you want to put in it - just saying. Not overwhelming large portions, but we were full with our appetizer.  

Service was a bit slow and they only had one server on, which for the business of the restaurant seemed a bit little, but two might have been to much - maybe just a buser?
author: Sarah C.

description:
Food: 
+ I ordered the chicken oyakudon which came with the miso soup and salad. It was a good value for a meal, but the egg and chicken was not warm when served. My miso soup was served first, but since I was waiting for my friend's and my main entree to come to consume it, it became lukewarm by the time I ate it with the entree. 

Service:
+ slow, especially since we were seated in the back corner. The server was attentive when he flagged him though. 
+ our main entree also took a while to be served. 

Even though it didn't meet my expectations, the menu displayed lots of meals that was of good value, and I'm willing to give it a try next time!
author: Linda K.

description:
Don't let the cute appearance of this restaurant fool you- If I could give this restaurant 0 stars, I would.

First, the tables are tiny and squeezed together so closely that my gf and I felt like we were sitting in a shared, loud common table.

Second, our food took foreverrrrr to come out and the place was only half full. My gf was starving but we decided to be patient.

Third, when the food came out it was subpar compared to ALL of the other Japanese restaurants in the Richmond district. The sushi was bland and the garlic miso ramen was not nearly as good as Ajisen in Westfield mall.

Now...IF the service was good, I would have overlooked all of this and just carried on after this uneventful dining experience.

But no...we had Joey as our server.

Sigh...Joey Joey Joey. What did the world do to you for you to turn out this way?

To kill the time while we waiting for our food, we decided to order a large hot sake. But after we both finished our little sake cups, we both decided that we hated it.

So after calling Joey over, we asked to take back the hot sake so that we can order a bottle of cold sake. 

But he told us that he couldn't give us a refund.

So I get a little confused and told him that we didn't like the hot sake at all but we'd be willing to pay for a more expensive cold sake.

Joey insisted that he couldn't take back the hot sake because he said "I can't resell it"

Now, to be clear, this is a bottle of hot sake that comes from one of those big jugs that they just microwave. Even a restaurant that opens a bottle of wine will let you take back a bottle of you dislike if. This was merely a cheap bottle of hot sake that they microwaved.

I even asked Joey if he could check with the manager of the restaurant and he promptly replied "no, they'll say the same thing as me".

That's it. That's what ruined our date night.

This is why we'll never come back to this place and we'll make sure our friends don't come here either
author: Jon C.

description:
Have you ever been excited about a restaurant because it had an item on the menu you couldn't find elsewhere, only to find that it DIDN'T HAVE WHAT YOU WANTED...but you enjoyed your experience anyway because the food was good?! Excuse me for my run-on sentence, but that was my experience with San Francisco's Miki Restaurant! Recently, I stopped by Miki  with my girlfriend after noticing (through Yelp) that this place had Zaru Soba Noodles (a.k.a cold soba noodles with a hot broth on the side). But NOPE, they didn't serve it (or any type of soba noodles at that)! However, we still ended up satisfied because the ramen here was not all that bad for the price and the service was great .

Miki Restaurant is located on Balboa Street in the Outer Richmond neighborhood. The really nice perks about this spot are that 1. Outer Richmond is all residential and so traffic will be  GOOD and street parking is going to be EASY if you choose to drive; and 2. Public transportation should be a cinch since a number of rails go that way (e.g. the 31 runs right through Balboa Street). If you decide to come, I HIGHLY recommend coming early and with a small party because this place is TINY. To put it into perspective, the restaurant's size is around the same as a dorm room; in fact, I was surprised there's a bathroom for customers inside the kitchen. Intimate, but maybe too close? Luckily though, we were seated immediately when we came around 7pm on a Saturday. 

Contrary to what I thought, Miki Restaurant serves primarily two types of food: sushi (both rolls and sashimi) as well as ramen. For their sushi, they have a few specialty rolls (like 4-5) and a some generic rolls such as spicy tuna and salmon (like around 8-9) different types. In addition, they have around 13 or so nigiri options (two pieces each). In regards to pricing, it's like $7 for their specialty rolls, $3.5 for 3 pieces of their basic rolls ($7 for double portion), and like $5-$6 for nigiri. If you want to mix it up, they also have combination plates too.

If you are interested in ramen, Miki has a separate one-page menu. Basically, they have tonkatsu, chicken, and vegetarian broths. For the meat broths, you can choose whether you want a miso, shio (salt), or shoyu (soy sauce) base. Unfortunately vegetarian broth = miso. Pricing isn't too bad, as it's around $11-$13 depending on what base you want + what extra ingredients you want to add. We ended up getting one garlic shoyu ramen, one shio ramen, as well as three-piece orders for salmon and tuna avocado rolls. Here's what we thought:

-Garlic Shoyu Ramen (7/10): If you are a big garlic enthusiast like me, this ramen broth is FIRE. Like, have you ever had a ramen bowl with WHOLE GARLIC CLOVES? Miki doesn't hold back! I thought the soy sauce broth was really tasty and the noodles were cooked great. I didn't really care for the pork, as it tasted dry and didn't have that fatty/juicy consistency I've come to expect. $12.5 wasn't that "bad" of a price, but unfortunately the portion size could have been a bit better. For example, every bowl only comes with two SMALL pieces of pork. AND, you get HALF an egg?! But, if you are looking for a ramen fix, this bowl isn't a bad option as a whole.

-Shio Ramen (7/10): My girlfriend echoed the same sentiments I had about her Shio Ramen. Overall, she thought the broth was cooked well; though this is a salt base ramen, the broth wasn't overwhelmingly salty, as can be the case with many ramen shops. The noodles were done well, although she too did not care for the pork. And that half egg though! Did they like cut one in half and serve both pieces to each of us?  For $11, this isn't bad but again the portion size is a bit on the smaller end. 

-Salmon/Tuna Avocado Rolls (5/10): If you think that a ramen bowl isn't enough to sustain your hunger and you are considering getting sushi here, THINK AGAIN! Though the sushi rolls are pretty cheap, they taste very mediocre. There's really nothing special about the sushi that they serve, although in their defense we ordered the basic rolls. Both the salmon and tuna avocado rolls were very plain and a bit too dry; this may just be me, but I actually felt a bit sick after eating them...I recommend not getting sushi here and just stick with their ramen. 

-Service (8/10): The service at Miki restaurant is really good, but not extraordinary. I'm glad that the employees here are SUPER RESPONSIVE. Like, I remember spilling water and they brought out napkins fairly quickly. 

All in all, I thought Miki Restaurant was a solid choice for dinner, but it didn't blow me away. The portion size for ramen was average, but at least the broth was good + pricing was fine. The service was also decent too. Though I was disappointed Miki didn't have soba noodles, the ramen made up for it. For that, I give this place a "nice-su, you can take your parents here and they'll be happy" rating. Just make sure you steer away from the sushi.

Eat well and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description:
My family and I just left this place because the young Asian girl working there provided horrible service. There were 3 tables of two and we asked if we can take one of the table and borrow a chair from another table so we can put our newborn whose in her car seat on it and she said no, we will have to wait for a bigger table. We understood so we waited inside the restaurant because it was cold outside and I didn't want to risk my newborn getting sick. 

A customer walks in and she offered him a seat near the cashier but he asked to sit by the window and she said okay. Then a couple walks in and asked for a table of two so she asked us to wait outside because we had our baby on the chair. 

We decided to leave because she could've offered the table by the register to the couple but instead she asked us to wait outside in the cold. She had no empathy. We never met anyone who would ask a family with a newborn to wait outside in the cold or make any effort to accommodate a seating arrangement. 

I hope one day she gets the same treatment she treated us.
author: Helen S.

description: Need to hire BETTER servers with BETTER service. Asian server dude with the nike hat sucked. Came in 10/20 on a Friday night. Terrible service. Had to get up and ask for our drinks 20 minutes after when other tables who just got seated got their shit right away. Couldn't even get our orders right. Server had no motivation nor any personality. He sounded dumb and dull. Won't come back ONLY for that reason. Fire his ass if you want better business.
author: Marc J.

description: Just say yes to ramen! Miki's was soooo good. Our friends who are 1. Japanese & 2. Have visited Japan several times hyped this place and said it was "best ramen they've had outside of Japan". They were not wrong. We both ordered tonkatsu ramen with spicy miso broth and it was out of this world delicious! We crushed some lunchtime ramen and I took some home for breakfast the next day. This morning's breakfast of leftover ramen was even tastier next day! Get their early as it is a small, intimate spot and they filled up very quickly when we were the first ones there for lunch on a Saturday. We look forward to returning and trying some sushi as well!
author: Jenice M.

description:
My boyfriend and I were visiting SF for a day and were craving some Ramen. We have been to some popular spots in the area but wanted to try something new, so we came to Miki. 

We got there at around 5:15 PM (on purpose to avoid the dinner crowd), and we got seated right away. It was a Friday night and most of the seats were still open, so we picked one by the window. The ambient was okay. I thought that it would feel more cozy given the size but it didnt. Once I sat down and got a menu, it smelled like pee so i thought it was maybe coming from the outside? But turned out it was coming from the menus. Off to a not so pleasant start. 

I order the tonkotsu broth with extra spicy miso and my boyfriend got the chicken broth with garlic miso. The other reviews said that the service is slow but it was fine for us. 

For the food! The Tonkotsu broth didn't taste super rich but it was good nonetheless... The noodles were not so impressive. The texture is pretty hard/rough and it didn't really mash well with the broth. The extra spicy was a good value add. I also added pork belly which was AMAZING!!!! Though overall the food just wasn't the greatest. I usually finish my food and stuff my face when the food is good, but I had plenty of leftover which i just gave to my bf to finish. 

For the price we paid I'd rather have eaten back in Sac for a way better deal and food. I don't think I would come back.
author: Jen K.

description:
After watching the episode of Chef's Table on Netflix featuring Ivan and his ramen we just HAD to go find a good ramen place for ourselves (thanks Netflix).
I was reading the reviews about how this place gets packed real fast so we got there right at opening time!

Atmosphere/staff: cozy little place but clean and the staff was very nice. The place is indeed really small, maybe 8 tables, half of them only seating for 2 people. There was 3 of us so we took one of the two 4 people tables there.

Appetizers: we got the tako and chicken karaage. Both were delicious but my favorite was the octopus. Deep fried tiny tako served with a garlic mayo. Two thumbs up.

Ramen: I chose to try the chicken broth instead of the tonkotsu that I usually go for. I had it with garlic miso and added pork belly and extra green onions. Each ramen comes with chasu pork, half a soft boiled egg and green onions. The broth was so so good, I was pleasantly surprised! It was perfectly umami and salty but without an overwhelming fatty taste. Just so yum. I tried my friends' spicy tonkotsu and shoyu tonkotsu and I honestly liked my broth better (they were good but not as tasty as the chicken broth). The egg was a tad bit too cooked for a soft boiled egg but otherwise was good. The chasu pork and the pork belly both paired well with the ramen. The ramen noodles were also good, the right amount of chewy and not overcooked.

We left there with happy tummies. The place was packed by the time we left and it was a random week day too. Just plan accordingly and come try this ramen joint!
author: Stephanie O.

description: Miki is located all the way out in the outer Richmond, on balboa st. However it is conveniently located right across the street from the movie theatre. The ramen here is great, among some of the best in the city. If you are looking for dinner on Balboa st, or are waiting for a movie, this should be among the top of the list for potential places to dine. I like that you get to create your own ramen, ask staff for help if you need to.
author: Ross S.

description:
I had dinner with a friend around 6pm and thankfully she was able to get us a table near the window. We both hadn't been here before and were excited to try it out. 

My friend had ramen and I decided on a bento box. I ended up getting chicken teriyaki and veggie tempura. Not the best I've had, but decent. My friend liked her ramen. 

Overall, the food was ok. I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here. The place is very small. You will definitely feel cramped. Service was alright. There was only one person taking orders and bringing out food. 

Total for 2 before tip:
$33.42
author: Fallon P.

description:
Very small place, pretty good ramen. Great and interesting broth options - some of the best chicken broth I've had with Ramen. The pork broth was super creamy and heavy for my liking. 

Love the $1.50 for an extra serving of noodles!
author: Salim Z.

description: I've been coming here for years. However, I've not been coming here much due to laziness. It has improved the menu with some great sushi items. Of course, the ramen is still the best.
author: William L.

description:
Came back in for lunch yesterday after a year hiatus.  The food is good, but if you're in a hurry this may not be the place for you.  

I used to work in the neighborhood and would come to Miki once a week at least for lunch.  I would order their ramen, which are good for the area.  I've also had their bentos, udon and donburi.  The food is good quality with good flavor.  However, because it's a smaller business, it takes some time for food to come out of the kitchen.  We try to be one of the first parties to order because our lunch breaks are only an hour long (I know hour lunches seem like a long time).  The service is good; the server started to recognize us after some time.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
This place is a hole in the wall, so it's a bit hard to find. I'm not usually a huge fan of ramen, it tends upset my stomach every time and the broth is usually very salty for my taste. However, I was very surprised with Miki because it fit my taste buds. My boyfriend and I both ordered the garlic shoyu with some rolls on the side. Each roll was about $6 for 4 pieces and it was ok. Maybe it's because we walked in about an hour before they were closing, but the fish didn't taste too fresh. Like I mentioned above, I'm picky when it comes to ramen but garlic shoyu's ramen broth was good. It wasn't salty nor bland, just perfect. I do wish that their chashu were more fatty though. Each bowl comes with two thin slices of meat and we felt that it wasn't enough.

So far, this is the most decent ramen place I've tried so I'd probably come back again if my bf and I are craving ramen when in Richmond area.
author: Elaine C.

description: Ramen was delicious and the portion was huge! Sushi was fresh and just as yummy as the ramen.
author: crissy c.

description:
The restaurant is small and the kitchen is tiny. I am surprise that they do ramen, sushi and grilled food in such a small kitchen. Tonkatsu broth was good. The toro, Tako, ikura and the tempura were excellent. Food was pricey but still affordable. Expect to spend between $50 to $100 for two or three people.

Yes, I plan to return.
author: H C.

description:
My husband and I got MSG poisoning from our dinner last night. It was such an intense and scary experience. We understand that some cuisines do use MSG and we're normally pretty forgiving - we remind ourselves to drink lots of water and accept that it's hard to avoid when eating out. However our recent experience will definitely keep us from coming back to this spot. 

If you have any food sensitivities, please be careful about eating here.
author: Nayomi H.

description: Wow, this used to be our secret special ramen place in the Outer Richmond where most people can't be bothered to go. I hadn't been in a while and noticed that the interior had been redone, more modern hipsterish. The menu was a little different, too, with some 'yoshoku' (Western inspired) dishes such as natto omelette (natto, the stinky soy beans that most people outside of Japan cannot stand, but some Japanese love!) and mentaiko (spicy cod roe) omelette)--psyche! saiko!! Anyway, I had a feeling that staff and ownership may have changed when I heard both customer and waitstaff discuss the 'tonkatsu ramen'. It is not 'tonkatsu', but 'tonkotsu'. The former is a breaded pork cutlet. The latter is a rich pork broth. We ordered a shio (salt) ramen with a tonkotsu base. Something was off with the broth from the start. It was a bit salty and lacked a certain depth. We also tried the salmon teriyaki teishoku which came with 2 pieces of California maki and white rice (!!). The California maki used real crab meat, which is a plus, but we are not big fans of 'American rolls'.  The salmon teriyaki came with 'teriyaki sauce', which is more 'American style teriyaki', than Japanese. Chicken karaage (Japanese style chicken nuggets) came with the order, but was a bit too oily and soggy. Also accompanying the teishoku meal was miso shiru, but it was too salty and inedible. I left feeling rather disappointed, but the restaurant was packed an a line waiting outside, so perhaps this place is to the taste of others, just not me. That said, the service was fine. The server was friendly and efficient. Nice interior, albeit on the small side (but that is not a negative).
author: 和子

description:
Hands down the best Ramen is SF and I have tried nearly all of them ;) the one thing I will miss after living in San Francisco for 3 years will be this place! 
Just order the ramen: tonkatsu, shio, with pork belly and spinach. You will not be disappointed.
author: Damian S.

description:
Came for lunch a little before closing time. Small little restaurant and doesn't seat too many people. Very cozy. I ordered the spicy miso tonkotsu ramen with added corn. The food took what seemed like forever to come. I would say a little over twenty five minutes. My ramen was good but I ruined it because I added the corn. There was so much corn that it overwhelmed me. A lot of noodles though! The chasu was thick, which I liked! 

Needless to say, the long wait time made my experience here a less pleasant one.
author: Annie H.

description:
We stopped by here for a quick dinner before heading over to the Pier, The wait time was quick for a weekday at about 6pm.

Two bowls of Ramen, White Tuna Sashimi, and Takoyaki balls, the bill was quite reasonable for the amount of food we had. 

Though I've never had Takoyaki anywhere else before, the sauce and flavor is on the strong side. But I believe this is a very popular dish in Japan, so it was definitely worth trying for once. 

The Sashimi didn't taste extremely "fresh", but it was still good. Though from my understanding you usually serve sashimi from fish that has been frozen (kills the bacteria). Other places i've been have this firm but also easy to bite texture. 

The Ramen was ok, I haven't had any bad ramen yet. Our server was also friendly and attended to us quickly whenever we tried to get his attention. I would definitely consider coming back here again.
author: Tony T.

description: Preface: Based on my recent experience only. Miki has been our local ramen go to spot for years. The service is friendly, they know our order and it's decent ramen. Recently we noticed some changes and the waiter let us know there was a change in owners. Tonight, I ordered my normal vegetarian ramen. About half way through, my husband noticed mine looked liked his in color. The waiter notified me it was the chicken ramen. As a vegetarian for 10+ years, this is not only upsetting but physically sickening. Super disappointing. Also, I did not feel like it was handled well. Should have tried to make it right. Now I won't feel safe eating here again.
author: Dani B.

description:
Miki is one of the many hidden treasures of the City that I am reluctant to share with the masses . . . so please consider yourself one very fortunate yelper. 

Now although there has been a recent rash of ramen joints popping up all over the City, Miki still is still without question my go-to spot for ramen.

Their spicy miso tonkotsu ramen is a super rich and oily and has never failed to satisfy my ramen needs.  I usually dress it up with extra chasu and garlic, but on the rare occasions I don't, you'll still find me busily slurping noodles nonstop for the next ten minutes or so once it arrives.

My wife, on the other hand, usually orders the torigara or vegetarian based ramens.  I never knew veggie ramen could ever taste this good.  Although, I do cheat a little and add chasu to it to the dish . . . because man (meaning me) cannot (probably could but why?) live on veggies alone.

Our little one is a fan of their karaage and for very good reason: they're wonderfully crisp and tasty morsels of moist and juicy chicken.  Yum, yum, yum, yum, yum.  You know what?  Change that.  I really should say, my little one and I are huge fans of their karaage. 

Anyways, there's something really special about this out of the way, non trendy, small feel (dare I say boutique-ie?) eatery that makes me think their food is prepared with more love and care than all these recent popups.
author: Dan B.

description:
3-1/2 stars.

We came here exactly at 12pm on a dreary Saturday for a bowl of pipin' hot Ramen.  We were the first table there.  I ordered the Pork Bone Miso Ramen, my daughter a tempura Udon and my husband a bento box combo comprised of Chicken Karaage and tempura.  

The ramen was fantastic! The pork broth was full of flavor. The noodles were just the right texture.  The bamboo shoots were fresh and soft.  Chasiu (only 2 pieces though) was tasty and tender.  I drank 1/2 of the soup and 2 hours later, I'm not thirsty, which probably means they didn't use loads of MSG.  Everything about the ramen was done perfectly - my only complaint is that the portion was very small for the hefty price tag of $11.00.  This is probably one of the most expensive bowl of ramen I had, given the size of it.  I finished the whole thing and felt I still could have eaten more.  I just wish they would give you a bit more especially that they are charging $11 for it.   I had a taste of the Udon and Bento Box combo and think those are just average.  Nothing extraordinary about them.  $9.50 each.  

Wait service is ok - it's a small restaurant so only 1 waiter.  He seemed to be attentive and got things done quickly.  The one thing you need to note is that there is a long wait for your food.  Expect at least 15 mins.  So if you're super hungry, you will be hangry by the time the food comes.

Overall, I think if you have a massive craving for a good bowl of ramen, willing to wait and fork out 11-12 bucks, this is the place to go.  I would just eat the ramen here though.  The other stuff just seems to just average.
author: Jannie Q.

description: Great little place for ramen. Often quite busy, but very easy to get take-out, hop over to the Hockey Haven for a quick drink, and 20 minutes later your dinner is ready to go. Favourite is the veggie ramen + egg. All broths are rich and so yummy.
author: Madeline M.

description:
Cute little ramen joint on Balboa St added with a slight hint of claustrophobia due to the ratio of people to seats available. It can get packed really fast so we were lucky to grab a seat before it got crazy around 6 PM on a Sunday night. Prices are pretty decent around $11-ish for the ramen and sushi from $4-12 bucks.

RAMEN HERE IS SO TASTY! We got an order of Tonkatsu Garlic Shoyu and Torigara (chicken ramen). The tonkatsu is not too heavy but a complimentary savory with the noodles (btw great ratio too on this), meat, and egg. I wasn't too fond of the egg because the yolk was a bit overcooked for me. If you're interested in trying out chicken broth instead of the pork, the Torigara is a solid choice. It's pretty much the same as the Tonkatsu (noodle, egg, meat etc) with the broth being a bit lighter but also creamy! It's a different experience for the taste buds so yes on this! The chashu itself was really tasty without the broth and that's really saying something about how they're preparing the meats here too.

I don't know what it was but the water and cup here smelled kinda funky like old Chinese hobby gift shops. Skip for me! Service was kind of slow with little check up from the servers but difficult to walk around in general. 

PASS on the sushi here! We ordered the Rainbow roll which is considered a specialty roll here for $7. We were so disappointed with it since it didn't taste too fresh and it came out to only 4 rolls only too. I guess it's more ramen than it is anything else. Anywhoo, still a solid ramen shop if you're looking for comfort food around here!
author: Jia Qi F.

description:
With the likes of Katana-ya and Tanpopo nowhere near as good as they used to be (those five stars I gave now look SUPER generous), I've been on the hunt again for the best ramen in the city.  Mensho is a hit among my friends, and the buzziest name at the moment, but I'll pass on waits upwards of two hours (despite my love for ramen, I have my limits).  Yet, ironically enough, I may have found exactly what I was looking for in the exact opposite type of place!

Stationed out in the far and quiet reaches of the Outer Richmond, Miki is an under the radar gem and the epitome of a neighborhood joint - a tiny, mom-and-pop shop without the frills, but with all of the good food.  While ramen is clearly the name of game here (evidenced by the full menu page devoted to your customization options), there are a number of non-ramen entrees available (lunch boxes/plates, donbouris, curries, and udon/soba), along with a bunch of small dishes on their specialties board.

-- CHICKEN KARAAGE
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/miki-restaurant-san-francisco?select=c4EoEqsQRpwICGQjB6VLNw)
A fairly plain rendition, but in a good way!  The batter was the perfect thickness and it was really crispy.  Plus, the chicken was both well seasoned and juicy.  Unfortunately, I didn't catch the price on the menu board (and my buddy paid), but there's no question that this was one of the better karaages I've had.

-- GARLIC MISO TONKOTSU RAMEN with Chashu, Nitamago (Seasoned Boiled Egg), Menma, and Green Onions...$9.95
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/miki-restaurant-san-francisco?select=pei1uGKcg5FxpDwpwYbPwg)
Simply put, this was pretty awesome.  The noodles had just the right bite to them and the included condiments were solid as well (no dry chashu here!).  It also didn't hurt that the Pork Belly I added (+$3.00) was fantastic as well (not too fatty, very tender).  However, to me, the broth was the star - deep and rich with a nice garlicky flavor).

Also, I think it's worth noting that we didn't run into the slow service that a lot of the older reviews have mentioned.  Rather, things moved at a steady pace and our server was quite friendly.  Admittedly though, we had also arrived towards the latter portion of their lunch service, so we might have missed the crowds.  In any case, if you're willing to stand outside for hours in the TL for ramen, waiting inside at your table with a drink in hand shouldn't be that big of a deal.

FOUR AND A HALF STARS ROUNDED UP.
author: Mike L.

description:
This is a new low. I have never eaten at a restaurant where my ENTIRE party felt sick/nauseous immediately after the meal. You can actually see how filthy the kitchen is along the way to the restroom. 

This restaurant's health score has improved with the most recent health inspection (from 68 to 83) but they must have reverted to old habits. 

Nausea aside, the servers were polite and the food was decent. 

Keep reading if you don't care about food safety. 

I ordered the chicken broth ramen with garlic miso, and my friends all ordered the tonkotsu ramen. The tonkotsu broth was overly salty, but it was definitely not the saltiest ramen I've ever had. The chicken broth lacked depth of flavor that I've tasted at shops that specialize in chicken ramen. The pork belly topping was dry and the seasoned egg was under-seasoned/bland. They used different noodles for the two broths, both were thick chewy alkaline noodles (which I like).
author: Jason C.

description:
A really small ramen shop. I came here Saturday night around 6pm and had to wait about 45mins before getting seated. The service was decent and didn't take as long as some reviews have said but the food does take a while to make it to the table.

I got the garlic shoyu and I loved it, the soup was ON POINT. The pork wasn't super impressive, it wasn't fatty enough for me but man, if you love garlic, this is your ramen shop. That garlic taste has such a nice, almost spicy kick to it. It's perfect for a winter night. 

Just a warning though, if you do get the garlic soup, the garlic taste will stay with you for days!
author: Kelly Y.

description:
When Mr. Joy suggested we try Miki Ramen, I was all for it. A ramen shop in the Outer Richmond probably won't have a crazy line - was my initial thought. When we arrived, there was a waiting list, but not a very long one. The restaurant is rather small with a handful of tables and just a couple of cooks behind the counter of a very small kitchen. 

We ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen with Pork Belly and Torigara Ramen (chicken flavor). Once our food arrived, we enjoyed some very surprisingly tasty ramen. I wasn't expecting to receive subpar ramen or anything, but I was more surprised that Miki managed to stay under the radar. Hopefully it stays that way. Both had translucent, but visibly fatty broth, which means more flavor. The pork broth had slightly more body to it. The noodles were thick and chewy. The ramen included chashu, half a boiled egg, bamboo shoots, and green onions. The yolk in the egg was cooked solid, but still very gooey. 

We also ordered takoyaki, which were delightfully milky and creamy on the inside, and crunchy on the outside, with a sprinkling of bonito flakes flailing to and fro. 

The rest of the menu includes all the usual Japanese dishes, including sushi, okonomiyaki, and so forth. I may give the other selections a try, but it seemed a bit overwhelming to look through. 
Now, the health inspection score is rather low, but I think they do rather well in their limited facilities. After a couple of times here, I've left full and satisfied. I've seen dirty, dingy places with 90+ scores. Such ratings reveal very little about how the restaurant falls short of restaurant standards and don't hold much weight in my eyes. I'd definitely revisit Miki for affordable ramen as opposed to making a far-flung journey for a bowl of noodles.
author: Joy W.

description: I had a garlic miso ramen and it contains the worst MSG ever. My body felt ache and my tummy hurts. The noodle soup was cold. My friend had a chicken broth miso and she felt the same. No thank you. We will not come again.
author: Bro M.

description:
Had one really good experience and one really bad experience..had the ramen tonkotsu both times. Also had the California rolls and tried another appetizer. Everything but the ramen was great; for the ramen, first time it was great, second time it was terrible. All the noodles were clumped together like they didn't stir them while they were cooking. I could understand that, but when I told the waiter, he brought back a tiny portion of noodles in one of those small side bowls. When I asked him to bring back more noodles he took my bowl, I guess he poured everything but the noodles into a bowl of noodles, and brought it back lukewarm. Come on, at that point just bring a new bowl out.

As noted in other reviews, it's a pretty small place, so there's almost always a wait during dinner. Totally worth it the time the ramen was good, awful when the ramen was bad.
author: Nelson D.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night, wait time was about 45 minutes for two with 5 parties ahead of us. 

Decided to go with the garlic miso tonkotsu ramen. The broth was the best part of this dish if you like garlic - it was very garlicky with the minced garlic and garlic cloves.

The noodles were very disappointing, it was touch and not chewy. Not a lot of ingredients are included in the ramen, most are available for extra charge. The ramen came with two small slices of chashu, a piece of seaweed, bamboo shoots and half of a soft-boiled egg. 

Overall, I really liked the broth but I'm not sure if I would come here again.
author: Amy T.

description:
As we searched for a new ramen joint on a chilly night, this once crossed my Yelp path. Looked promising with 4-stars and greater than 300 reviews. It seemed pretty easy to get to, and there is ample parking in the area. Plus, if it sucked, we could always go across the street for some Purple Kow that could make up for it!

This is a small place with a few tables. That to me is always a good thing, especially for authentic comfort foods, such as ramen. We got there relatively early in the evening, so seating was ample...  

The ramen did not disappoint. We got the Tonkotsu Garlic Miso Ramen and the Tonkotsu Spicy Miso ramen (regular). We also got Chicken Karage and a rainbow roll.

Tonkotsu ramen (garlic miso) - Great depth of flavor. The broth is deep, not watery, and fulfilling. The garlic permeates throughout the rich broth, and every once in awhile, you get a surprise of roasted garlic clove. Noodles are more al-dente then most ramen joints, so that's much appreciated. Don't get soggy seating in the broth. I added some pork-belly to the mix, and that was such a smart move. Appropriate mix of fat/meat. Delectable.

Spicy Miso - Similar to above (but no garlic). Spicy-level on point. Seemed a little bit thinner than the garlic version. I enjoyed the garlic one much more. But as we were leaving, the server brought out a spicy garlic miso!!! Next time, Imma try that.

Chicken Karage - Five pieces. Non-fatty. Not greasy. Expertly battered and fried. Loved it.

Rainbow roll - My advice is to skip it. And also likely skip all the sushi option. I should have known given you can't see a sushi bar, or the chef. Mediocre at best. 

I'll come here again for sure. But for the ramen. No fishy, for me.
author: Edward L.

description:
Had to wait 40 minutes for 2 tables for our party of 7. Be patient. Server was considerate of the grandparents in the party and let them sit at a table once he had one so they could get out of the cold outside. Added folding chair to table for 4 for 10 year old in the party.

I had the vegetarian garlic miso ramen with pork belly; husband, garlic tonkatsu. Garlic was potent, but good. Even more than you would find in Italian cooking with cloves of garlic and minced garlic. Pork belly was marinated well and very flavorful and tender. Grandma enjoyed her Oyako Don saying that the chicken was very tender. Grandpa had udon with tempura and chicken. Teens had pork tonkatsu shoyu ramen and chicken shio ramen.

The server did not rush you out once you were seated. Lunch was very filling.
author: Belinda L.

description:
What a little gem of a Ramen shop! 

TLDR; Authentic ramen tucked away in a nice neighborhood, cozy and small with lots of other authentic appetizers available but at the pricier end. The only reason I am docking it a star, ended up with a $50+ bill with two ramen bowls (plus extra egg, noodles, etc.) and kara-age.

Came here when it was pouring rain (quite simply the only proper time to eat ramen is in cold weather, imho) and the seating was quite packed inside. It can only sit less than 25 people so it's nice and cosy and steamy. 

They do have non-pork based soup base, which I got the chicken and my fellow diner got a vegetarian base. It was incredibly good, the soup was full of depth, you can tell they really spend their time developing the flavor and it came from a long steep. The noodles are also of great quality, nice and soft yet firm. Really tasty and their egg was done perfectly. 

We had the kara-age and it was also done excellently- well fried, with ours having some skin. The sauce, some mayo-based tart sauce was perfect for pairing with the fried chicken.

Overall a great dining experience here! Would definitely come back.
author: David T.

description:
Looking for some satisfying tonkotsu-style ramen? Well Miki is that place! Miki had a pretty extensive menu for ramenya, and I really respect that. Most ramenyas only have ramen and gyoza on their menu, but Miki has other items from takoyaki, to udon, to rolls. Not bad for such a teeny tiny restaurant! 

My dining partner and I weren't extremely hungry, so we split an order of takoyaki and a bowl of miso garlic tonkotsu ramen with extra noodles. It was so delicious! That egg was unforgettable! Perfectly flavored and cooked. The charsiu was also very tender and oh so melt in your mouth. They were also very generous on the grated garlic and the menma.

We left with an empty bowl, and two full stomachs. Was it the best bowl of ramen I've ever had? Probably not. But, I would 100% recommend this place to anyone craving a hearty bowl of ramen on a cool San Francisco evening. The only thing to watch out for is the wait. For me, there was no wait because it was just the two of us, but it definitely will be harder if you're in a group over 2. A large group is impossible.
author: Kaitlyn F.

description:
Miki has the no-frills, local-business charm that is all but washed away--along with quality broth--in many of the newer, ultra sleek ramen places.

Because it's a small place and they don't have the capacity to operate with the in-n-out efficiency of larger Japantown ramen restaurants, your food may take awhile (there is even a notice at each time politely apologizing for the wait time). After enjoying Miki's freshly cooked, steamy bowls of ramen, I now detest too-fast-to-be-true lukewarm broths even more.

Ramen is $9.50 for regular pork or chicken broth base, shoyu/shio/miso ($9.75 for garlic or spicy miso), and basic toppings of 1/2 egg, 1 piece of chashu, green onions, and menma. Almost too basic with only one piece of chashu and no kikurage, but it's same complimentary toppings as Izakaya Sokai in the Inner Sunset. Also, default noodle portions are decent enough to keep you from going hungry. Noodles are the curly yellow ones used at many ramen places, standard and warranting neither tirade nor eulogy about noodle QQ/al dente-ness.

The broth definitely stands out the most--nice and balanced, strong tonkotsu flavors, not too creamy or salty, and it seemed to have a stronger sesame taste than most places. The boo got the GARLIC MISO which was deliicously garlicky; I got the SPICY MISO and because it was an extra $0.25, I opted for the extra spicy level. While most spicy miso I've tried is mild at best, Miki's had quite a kick and, at long last, satisfied my hunt for actually-spicy miso. The catch is that the broth was hotter than expected and I dismissed it as spiciness, ending up with minor mouth burns... first world problems :X

Other notes:
- They also had an interesting vegetarian kelp broth, but it costs more at ~$11.50, plus I was in a carnivorous mood. 
- After we ordered, I heard another table saying the pork belly (extra $3) is a must-get. Because of the small chashu serving, I would recommend saving your Purple Kow change for the pork belly addition, especially if you are in a carnivorous mood. 
- TL;DR: good quality broth but could use more toppings and is pricey-ish. Don't come when you're in a carnivorous mood.
author: Edna C.

description:
I came in a little before closing time, and we only had to wait about 5 minutes to get seated.  There is no inside waiting area, and the restaurant itself is really small (only about 9 tables), so I could see this being an issue if it's busy or raining.  

Once we got seated, however, we had to wait about 30 minutes for our food.  I actually had to leave to refill our parking meter, because our food took forever to get to our table.  Again, this is a really small restaurant, and the broth is already made, so I really don't understand what took so long to get our ramen.  

The ramen itself was alright.  I ordered the Garlic Miso Tonkotsu ramen and added spinach, because it doesn't come with any vegetables otherwise.  It definitely lived up to the name and was very garlicky.  It actually became overbearing for me.  They give you a good amount of noodles, but the cha shu was my favorite part.  It's a thicker cut (not like the red ones you might typically imagine) and it was really tender.  Only thing is that they don't give you much cha shu at all.  If I ever come back, I'd probably get the spicy miso next time.
author: Eric L.

description:
This place is quite small, so if you are coming with a big party, make sure to call in advance to  check if  you'll be able to find a table available.

This is a Japanese restaurant with ramen as its main selling point, so that's what I ordered. You have 3 options of ramen: Pork (Tonkotsu), Chicken, or Vegetarian. You then have to choose the sauce/broth, and you can add extra ingredients (corn, butter, vegetables, pork belly...). It already comes with meat (pork or chicken) or veggies, half of a boiled egg, bamboo sprouts, and seaweed.

I had the Tonkotsu with garlic shoyu sauce and added assorted vegetables. It was quite yummy, although I wasn't in awe with the dish.  

I am definitely happy to have a ramen place close by. But it's not the sort of place I would tell you to go to have the best ramen of your life.
author: Andréia S.

description:
It's pouring rain outside, and I was craving xlb, but since I wasn't smart enough to check yelp - my favorite xlb spots were closed today. Spotting Miki Restaurant and remembering that I'd been here many years ago and had a pleasant experience, I decided to give them another shot. I checked yelp and saw that it had some decent reviews, including some pictures of the ramen menu.. Please see my updated ramen menu pic, as the prices have been raised by a couple dollars per bowl! 

Like that stupid ex-boyfriend that you can't stop thinking about.... this is how I feel about my experience at Miki. I just cannot get over how bad this $16 bowl of ramen was! 

I ordered a spicy miso ramen bowl, then added garlic and corn. The ramen came out in about 8-10 minutes, not a big deal. It looked a little oily, but I figured maybe that was from the chili oil. I tried to taste a bit of the broth, as I usually do, but the top centimeter at least was all oil. I thought, oh maybe if I mix the noodles up then it'll balance the bowl out.. Nope, that didn't work either. 

While the noodles were not inedible, they didn't not have the proper chewiness to them. And when I was finally able to taste the broth without scooping up a spoonful of oil, there was not even a hint of miso. I think they just use the same pork broth, dump chili oil and fresh garlic in....

The pork, bamboo, and corn were all ok. Not good or bad. 

Overall, very disappointed. If I ever come back, it will not be for the ramen.
author: Lisa N.

description:
The ramen! This place is so good. The ramen is amazing (especially if you like spicy). I enjoy the level of customization with the ramen. There are so many vegetarian options-- so exciting! My boyfriend tried the sushi and was underwhelmed, but who gets sushi at a ramen place?! 

There's been a wait each time I've gone, but that's to be expected with a small restaurant like this. 

It's a great little date night spot if you want to catch a movie across the street at balboa theater or grab some drinks a few doors down at hockey haven.
author: Sarah S.

description:
The good news:  Pork belly on noodles was delicious.  We all liked our ramen, my husband loved his spicy noodles.  My daughter liked her bento box with teriyaki chicken.

The not so good news:  The ramen did have a slightly metallic taste, like when I was a kid and people boiled their noodles in aluminum pots.  Or when tomato sauce came from a can without plastic bpa lining.  The sushi ginger tasted moldy and something was off with the tempura or dipping sauce.

I'd give the food 2.5 stars.

The bad news:  The age old question of do you remain blissfully ignorant, or look behind the curtain?  Nature answered that question for me and since you have to go through the kitchen to get to the bathroom, I was forced to look.  I tried not to look too closely (I had just finished my meal), but everything I saw in front of me and out of my peripheral vision shouted health code violations.  It was disgusting.  And we were probably the third table served for the evening, so the kitchen must not have been clean when they started service.  Truly made me think twice about eating at restaurants with a hidden kitchen (which is most).  Not sure if my upset stomach this morning is from the food or just thinking about the kitchen but my son feels bad too!
author: Amy K.

description: Great ramen/Japanese restaurant - one of the things I liked best was that they have vegetarian options for the ramen.  Everything was really good - sushi, sashimi, tempura & both the meat & veggie ramens.  The restaurant is small, but good for kids.  I don't believe the review where someone alleged "msg poisoning."
author: Alexandra B.

description: It's such great food but we won't be going back. Both my husband and I had the worst MSG reaction
author: Alexis K.

description:
Small, hole in the wall, mom and pop Japanese restaurant. They serve ramen, small plates, bento boxes, sushi, etc. 

We got the tonkotsu garlic miso ramen and it was really good. The soft boiled egg is really nice. The broth isn't too salty. The pork belly is very tasty. The noodles were cooked to perfection. 

Price is decent, service is good, and easy parking.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
The roommate isn't a huge fan of going out to eat when he's in SF. So Thursdays and Sundays are delivery or take out days. (Basically they are his lazy days since he's not working.) On Thursday, April 30th around 6pm, we decided to grab take out from Miki since I was craving ramen.

*Miki ramen: includes chashu (seasoned pork slice), nitamago (seasoned boiled egg, half), menma (bamboo shoots), green onion
-Tonkotsu: original pork based broth, Spicy miso ($9.75)
-Additional toppings: Pork belly (3 pcs) $3, Corn ($1.25), Spinach ($1.50)

I'd been here years ago and remembering liking their ramen. I believe my memory served me well. The noodles had a nice chew. The broth good flavor. I thought the pork belly was great. Nice and tender. My only complaint was there wasn't much soup for all the noodles and toppings. I typically like more broth.

The roommate ordered the Chicken karaage (5 pcs): deep fried marinated chicken ($7) and Katsu don: deep fried pork cutlet over rice ($10). He enjoyed it and finished every morsel. Our only complaint was they didn't give us a sauce for the karaage. We just made our own sriracha aioli at home.

Great having a ramen joint and close to home!
author: Elena N.

description:
Delicious! mmmm nom nom.

Make sure to go before or after peak dinner hours.. I don't mind waiting for awesome food (Hockey Haven is right next door!) but they have extremely limited space inside, so either bundle up and stand in the cold or be ok with an early/late dinner. 

They also don't care about table size. If the next party is a party of 2, they'll seat you at a table big enough for 4, even if there's a party of 4 right behind you.. Definitely adds to the wait. Now that I'm thinking about it, they should replace those 4tops with 2tops and just group them together when needed.

I love their succinct ramen menu. SUPER reasonably priced and their extras weren't outrageous either (4 sheets of nori for $1ish). Highly recommend the Garlic Shoyu as it's well balanced in savory richness without being overly salty.. or anti-vampire breath-y. 
Definitely add more chashu as these are thinly sliced (but tasty!). I personally love extra nori and bamboo shoots in mine, they always pleasantly add texture and dimension to the bowl rather than distract.
I almost always leave broth behind, but because it was so yummy (read: I'm a fatty), I ordered extra noodles (perfectly cooked) to take with my residual broth. No drop of broth left behind!

Side order board looked on point too.. their takoyaki did NOT disappoint. Didn't try anything else during this time, will have to visit again for sure.

PS - killer service, SUPER nice waitstaff (I was given extra bamboo shoots when I questioned how much "extra" they gave me to begin with), didn't rush anyone out (I was eyeing this woman who was done but sat there for forever while my mom and I froze outside...) which is always nice.
author: Rica R.

description: FYI potential diners- they are CLOSED right now, sign in window says 11/25-12/11, and their prices have gone up significantly, though I'm not sure since when. A bowl of ramen that used to cost 9.75 now costs 12.50 before add ons. Last time I checked, still the best ramen in the city.
author: Sophie H.

description: Great spot in the Outer Richmond for Japanese. Tiny place, only around 6 or 7 tables. Me and my friend both had ramen, which was very good. The menu is set up in a "create your own adventure" for the ramen, which is fun and different. And they offer lots of add-ons! The menu also had a small selection of sushi, sushi bowls, and other various Japanese inspired dishes. I only saw one server for all the tables, so serve was pretty slow. They also are closed for random weeks, which is not updated in their google maps page or yelp (went there once and it was closed for two weeks). Overall if you live in the neighborhood and want some tasty ramen, it's a great option!!
author: Taylor B.

description: This fried head shrimps are so crispy and we can eat all of it, but be careful it is so hot when they serve it on the table. Wait for a few minutes before you put it into your mouth.
author: Rijanti H.

description:
My favorite Tacoyaki place closed down and I was so sad because I couldn't find a placae that could live up to it...Until NOW! Shh..I think they deep fry them that's the secret right? It's crispy on the outside YUMM!!! 

I had the Pork Katsu Curry yum yum and sushi was ok. 

Can't wait to try more.
author: Karen T.

description: We came here on Saturday noon time and got seated right away. Their ramen is thicker than what I had in other Ramen restaurants and tastes great! I like their tea a lot! It tastes stronger and fresher.
author: Suhui C.

description:
Ok I've been here for the tail end of the lunch period and service was pretty good.  Last night, I dropped in for an early dinner before a meeting.  At the time, we were the only people in the restaurant.  Both of us ordered bento boxes.  Mine was chicken Karaage and my friend had the chicken katsu.  

While we were waiting for our food, the restaurant started filling up.  We then notice that people were getting their food (mostly ramen) before us.  My friend asked about the status of our food and they said it will be coming soon.  After about a 1//2 hour wait, our food finally arrived.

At this point, we inhaled the food because we had to run off to a meeting.  We even made arrangements for the bill to come at the same time as the food because we can no longer afford to wait for the bill.  We wanted to pay and leave!

Food was great.  Don't get me wrong.  I loved the chicken karaage.  It was fried just right.  Service is s-l-o-w.  If you're in a rush, this isn't the place for you.
author: Wendy H.

description: So you find yourself in the Outer Richmond area with a craving for ramen on a rainy day. Well then, it's time to make your way to Miki. Miki has a good mix of ramen and sushi dishes. There are different ramen "flavors" you choose from with the vegetarian options (a kelp based broth) being miso, garlic miso, and spicy miso. Being the spice devil I am, I ordered the spicy miso. It seemed like the best option for a rainy day too! I was definitely not let down. The veggie broth was developed enough to hold my interest and satisfy my palate. Time to add this place to my SF veggie ramen recommendations for sure.There aren't many veggie things on the sushi menu outside of veggie tempura and the cucumber/avocado rolls, but I gravitate towards noodle soups so not too big of a problem for me. ^^
author: Lakshmi M.

description:
I love yukke. All of them are delicious! They come with quail egg, chives, and cut up fish. Hotate and salmon are my go to flavors. I also love their yellow and white roll with panko (+$0.50). It's quite worth it. If you don't get full off of the sushi get ramen, too. 

This place is small and a mom and pop type shop. You have to be patient and try to come early to get a seat. Around 5pm is a good time. They don't serve yukke for lunch, only dinner. I used to be a regular here, but the prices have gone up since I've first started coming a few years ago. I still love it, but I miss the old prices. Oh well. San Francisco is becoming expensive in general...
author: Lyra C.

description: I really like this spot. Great spot to get a meal before or after a movie at the Balboa Theater, across the street. Keep an eye on the specials and follow your server's suggestions on what's especially good. If it's crowded, grab a beer at the bar next door (Hockey Haven) while you wait.
author: chris e.

description:
Absolute garbage.  I ordered the tonkatsu broth,  with the extra garlic shoyu option. I also got an extra egg and green onions. 

The Ramen had the flattest, palest,  most one-dimensional broth I've ever had. It literally almost tasted like water- totally devoid of any depth. My heart actually sank with the first taste of broth.

They put one miniscule piece of charsiu pork in the bowl- so small I was incredulous.  I'll include a picture. 

Overall the meal was indescribably disappointing and you couldn't pay me to go back.
author: Grizzle J.

description:
Now I'm sitting in the restaurant, I order spicy miso ramen, extra spicy with extra chashu pork and pork belly.

The ramen was just okay, with a bit green chashu and cold half boiled egg, I eat almost half and then I found the bug in my bowl.

The glass of water have some white dust inside also.

The service is so-so but I worry about the cleanness and the quality of there food.
author: Thancha N.

description:
I like the tempura! There was so yummy and crispy!
My girl friend said" this is the best Japanese food I have ever had!"
author: Weichao X.

description:
Laughing at whoever called this place a hole in the wall. Pretty sure that because it's tiny, doesn't mean it's a hole in the wall. 

We've been more than once - typically right as they open for lunch because yes, they get busy. For good reason- the ramen is good! If you like garlic broth, this is a good place for it. 

But I'm really writing this review because they have katsu on the menu and I've only been able to get it twice - othertimes they haven't had it. And it's SO GOOD. So if you own Miki and reading this, please bring it back consistently!
author: Kat G.

description: I really really wanted to like this place because the food looked good and the prices seem decently price. but it was a totally fail because of the service.
author: Angela T.

description:
Came here based on recommendation from a friend and ordered the tempura udon. Broth was too salty but the tempura was good. I wouldn't order it again.

The shop is pretty small and it wasn't too crowded. I came on a Tuesday night with a friend and we were able to get seated immediately. I might come back to try the ramen since I think that's what they are more known for. 

Prices are pretty good, then again most food in this area is below average $. Service was also okay. Overall a meh experience, but I wouldn't be opposed to trying again since it wasn't terrible.
author: Sophia H.

description:
Really mediocre Ramen--flavorless, cold meat and vegetables, over cooked strangely pale egg. Soggy kareage, greasy tempura. And it took 45 minutes to get our food. Considering that it cost as much as higher quality places in the city, there were fewer than 15 customers, there is no excuse.
And the kitchen was filthy.
author: Monica B.

description: Came here on a Thursday night. There was a wait, about 30 minutes? It's a really small place, very cozy and perfect for date night. I ordered their shio tonkotsu ramen with pork belly. Flavor was not strong, a little bland to me. The pork belly was really fatty (which I like, but so bad health wise lol). The person I came with ordered soba noodles I think? He thought it was just okay. I would come back (if I were in the area) to try their other ramens or maybe just their sushi stuff.
author: Lina C.

description:
I just noticed in the past couple weeks, I've been on a ramen Yelp review kick.  Well here's another one for you!  Bf & I were in Outer Sunset a few weeks ago & I was craving ramen again for lunch.  To my knowledge, there's only noteworthy ramen in Inner Sunset, not wanting to deal with parking there, I Yelped around and found Miki's 4 stars.  

Next door is packed Shanghai House.  We came at the right time to this tiny restaurant as there were only three tables occupied, but quickly filled up after.  There was only one waiter & I believe only one person working the kitchen, so it's probably not best to come here if you're in a rush during prime time hours like we were.  I like the menu had lots of different ramen options including a chicken broth which I went with.  The build your own bowl of udon also caught my eye, but I saw the good reviews on the garlic ramen broths, so I decided to go with the chicken broth based garlic ramen and he went with the tonkatsu ramen.  

Be forewarned you will have stank breath after eating this!  It was very garlicky (good thing).  I also liked how the egg had oozy yolk, but it was really cold.  I felt like the price of the ramen ($9.75) was steep for what you got - half a soft boiled egg, green onions, bamboo shoots, and two small pieces of pork.  Though the egg was still yolky, noodles were cooked fine, and the broth was good, it's not one of our top choices.  It is a decent choice for ramen, especially in Outer Richmond.
author: Cat C.

description:
I'm here at least once a week. 

Staples include, but are not limited to:
- Chriashi bowl
- Tempura
- Salmon handroll
- Vegetarian ramen
- Oyako Don

Pro tip: When it's busy (which is a lot) I make my order to go and pop into Hockey Haven for a drink while I wait. ;-)
author: Licette M.

description:
Although this place is small and almost invisible to people walking by, they have one of the most delicious ramen I've ever had. I was searching for a new ramen place and was excited to discover a restaurant in my neighborhood. I ordered the spicy miso tonkotsu which is ramen with a pork based soup. What I love is that you get to order what soup base you want. If you want chicken instead, they offer that. If you prefer vegetable broth, they also have that.

My spicy miso tonkotsu included half a soft boiled egg, slices of pork, bamboo shoots, minced garlic, chopped green onions, and a piece of seaweed on the side. The soup was very flavorful and delicious. I finished my bowl and wanted more. The soup was a little oily, but it wasn't overwhelming.

My friend ordered the garlic miso tonkotsu. I had a sip of her soup and it was definitely garlicky. If you're a fan of garlic, that is the ramen you should try.

Overall, I really enjoyed the ramen at this restaurant. I thought it was a little pricy for the amount of ramen that we got, but it was still good. 

I think my biggest concern for this place is the service. While we were there, a few tables were occupied. The restaurant wasn't full, but the service was still slow. We waited over half an hour for our food. Maybe it wouldn't have been too bad of a wait, but we were hungry when we arrived so the wait made us a little bit grouchy. From what I saw, I think the chef in the kitchen makes the ramen bowls individually. Which means it takes awhile for us to get our food.

I recommend not going here if you're extremely hungry because it does take awhile for the food to come out. But if you're a fan of ramen, this is definitely a place to come and try. The ramen is delicious.
author: Andrea G.

description:
Pleasantly surprised with this ramen place. I've had this restaurant bookmarked for a while and was excited when I finally got to try the place. Its a really small mom and pop looking shop but its cute. There are signs posted everywhere saying to expect a longer wait time for food because of the small kitchen. I appreciate a business thats upfront about the wait time of their food. I think my friend and I waited less than 10 minutes to get our ramen which was nice. It wasnt very busy when we came though.

I ordered the spicy tonkatsu ramen and added corn. It was a little more spicy than I wanted but it was pretty good. My friend ordered the chicken base soup with garlic miso. It was sooooo good. I have to come back just to order that broth. Overall the food was great! It's a little pricy, my friend and i ordered ramen and our bill was 32 bucks? Definitely didn't help that he added a bunch of sides ... LOL next time we'll skip on the extras.
author: Kelly S.

description:
First time trying this place out! My wife heard it was delicious and since it next to "purplekow" we thought it was a perfect time to check it out.

The store front looks nice with the red banner and the inside looks warm and intimate with wood themed everywhere. Most importantly, it was clean! Restrooms and all.

We shared a chicken karage and mixed tempura. Both were good and on point. Nothing negative about it. Solid.

My wife ordered the chicken broth, garlic-miso, with added corn and I had the pork broth, spicy-miso, side garlic and corn and all I have to say it was delicious! My wife is not a "broth-noodle-fiend" like myself, but she enjoyed it and she is definitely a picky eater. As for my bowl, the broth was thick, full of flavor, and just had enough heat to complete it. I will also mention it did not taste too salty as the other ramen joints I tried. The noodles were al-dente which "ramen lovers" can understand why I was happy about that. The bamboo, soft boiled egg, and green onions were great making this a great bowl of ramen.

Grace (our waiter) suggested we try a side of pork belly to accompany our ramen and man....it was divine! Melt in your mouth goodness! If you get ramen, PLEASE order pork belly with it. You'll thank me

All in all, we throughly enjoyed the experience, food, and service here and would definitely come again! 

Talking about service, they were nice and courteous! Always checked on us and made sure we were taken care of which made the experience more great. Solid.
author: Sophana T.

description: Miki is one of the best neighborhood spots in outer Richmond. Do you want a bowl of ramen? Yakitori? Chirashi? Hamachi Kama? In addition to being in adorable restaurant space with great service? Well this is the place to go. All the food I've tried has been solid and prices are reasonable. Nothing pretentious and levels above a take out spot. Definitely my new default place for when I'm craving Japanese staples.
author: Linda L.

description:
I came here with one of my friends at around 6. There was a bit of a wait, but it wasn't a big deal. When we were seated, the waiter was very polite and gave us plenty of time to get situated and order. 

Miki's is different from other ramen spots in SF since the broth here actually tastes legit. You can taste the intense flavor compared to other watered-down, less flavorful broths at other restaurants. The prices were pretty decent and it's right across from Purple Kow if you want boba after dinner.
author: Chris V.

description:
Wow. Never would've thought I'd find my favorite ramen spot in SF right in the Outer Richmond. I'm seriously impressed by Miki's ramen even though they are not really your typical "ramen-only shop". I always thought this place was a simple neighborhood Japanese restaurant that happen to offer ramen (so how good would that be? I was skeptical). But after a reco from a friend AND the great reviews on yelp, I had to try. Surprisingly delicious and absolutely hit the spot. 

Noodles - perfectly wavy and al dente, just the way I like it
Soup - hot (I'm always afraid of lukewarm soup), I ordered the spicy miso and the type and level of spice is excellent
Pork - you can choose pork belly, but the regular pork that came with mine was not too lean and not too fatty
Egg - texture and flavor is seriously on point
Other toppings - I traded my menma with corn and wasn't charged extra, plus it came with plenty of green onions and seaweed

I'm glad I went at around 6pm before the dinner wave. I wouldn't be surprised if you have to wait for a while, this place is quite small. But totally worth it. If you are really hungry I suggest adding extra noodles. 

No doubt I'll return...like...next week! Love this place!
author: Jackie C.

description:
Not bad, not bad at all. 

Had the ramen, a katsu curry plate and some ikura nigiri. The ikura was pretty fresh and not overly salty. ramen was just okay, not as great as everybody raves. I will say that I would prefer this over Genki (gag) and the egg is delicious.  They were a little skimp on the curry though because it barely was enough to even cover our katsu and rice. Boo! 

Tiny hole in the wall and there's like, 1 server. Be a little patient.
author: Susy C.

description:
On a recommendation of a friend, we decided to check this spot out. First off, the space is small, so it's better for dates or threesomes (get yo mind outta the gutter). We had a group of 8, so I'm thankful they accommodated us w/o a fuss. 

Most of us wanted to order the chicken karaage curry, but they ran out of curry that night (Saturday around 7pm). I opted for the bento combination with chicken karaage and tempura. I really like how they fried it. It was not super oily and had a good amount of flavor. I wish I remembered to ask them for some lemon and pepper to sprinkle on the chicken. 

Pricing was reasonable for about $20 after tax and tip. I hope to try the karaage curry next time, if I'm in the area.
author: Thomas L.

description: This is my favorite Ramen place in sf so far.  The broth is flavorful. Ramen is all about the broth and this place definitely puts some love into their broth. Tonkotsu (pork broth) is probably the best.  Get it garlic based for an extra kick.  Pork belly is very tender braised with sweetened soy sauce.  Egg isn't overcooked and still slightly runny just the way it should be.  If you want slightly lighter broth, torigara  shio (salted chicken) is really good =).
author: Kathy C.

description: My friends and I came in on a Saturday around 6:15 pm and waited about 10-15 minutes to be seated. This other group came in shortly after my group but ordered a minute before we did. By the time our food came out, the group that ordered right before us already finished eating. I ordered a spicy miso tonkotsu ramen for around $12. The food was pretty good but the portion was kind of small for the price and I don't think it was worth the wait. The ramen came with some bamboo shoots, green onions, half an egg, and 2 pieces of meat. I wished they gave more meat but you can pay extra to add more things to the ramen.
author: Annie Z.

description: This was really good ramen place. You may have to wait awhile to get in because its a small place (so get there early), and its not great for big groups. I probably wouldn't bring a group bigger than 4. But it was worth the wait, in my opinion. I had the miso ramen and it was really good. I've gone back a couple times now and always love the ramen.
author: Theo L.

description:
This is a small Japanese restaurant is located in the Richmond District! you know that saying "quality over quantity" well, that is exactly what Miki's is. The sushi rolls come out in only 4 pieces but tastes great and you still have room for other food that are coming. The downside is that because there is only one chef who does mostly all the cooking, the food takes a while to come out, about 40-45 minutes. Although it takes quite some time to come out but they make up for in the quality of their great tasting food.

 My family and I absolutely love the food here. We come here at least once or twice a month to have dinner! We love their Salmon Soy sauce butter, Black Cod, Salmon sashimi, fried chicken, Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen, and their Spicy Tuna Crunch Roll. They use to have the most amazing fried oysters but sadly they stopped. 

This restaurant is a must TRY!
author: Sophia L.

description:
Definitely a hole-in-the-wall sort of place.  But it's a comfortable place.  

Chicken karaage appetizer = okay. It was missing something...perhaps ginger? 

Tonkatsu ramen garlic miso, added spinach, but they did not have spinach, which they informed me when the ramen came out.  Noodles were good and perfect consistency (not soggy). Boiled egg was epic. Broth was boring. I was truly disappointed by the broth. 

Spicy himachi avocado roll = 3 pieces, which was fresh and delicious. Definitely had a good kick to it. 

Service = one server, as warned.  Asked for refill on the water, which was expected, given the one server.  

Seating = mostly 2 and 4-tops.  Small joint.  

Prices = moderate.
author: Fannie S.

description:
One of the better bowls of ramen I've had in this city, and that's been really hard to come by! Its a pretty small place, and they take reservations so I definitely recommend you to call ahead, just in case. 

I got the spicy miso ramen (regular spicy) which wasn't too spicy at all. The basic bowl comes with half an egg, bamboo, seaweed and a slice of chasu. I ordered an extra egg, which was worth the dollar something. They soft boil it perfectly, and its cooked like a tea egg so there's extra flavor. The broth was pretty solid, but I normally do like it to be a little more dense in flavor, personal preference. But the noodles were perfectly chewy, probably bc they were a bit thicker than usual. One comment about their takoyaki, I didn't like how fried and crunchy they were on the outside. Def didn't compare to the famous takoyaki at Izakaya Sozai. But would def go back for the ramen.
author: Samantha C.

description: Came in on a Tuesday Night around 7:15pm. Waited about 45 minutes to be seated by their one and only waiter. Ordered right away and we still waited for our food for about 30-40 minutes. The food was pretty delicious, probably because we waited for so long for our food and were starving. Ordered the Garlic Miso, one in Pork Broth and the other in Chicken Broth. Before we ordered, we asked the waiter if we were able to exchange the Bamboo Shoots (which the ramen automatically comes with) for other toppings, and the kind waiter gladly let us. So instead of Bamboo shoots, we got one with extra noodles and the other with corn. Definitely ask if you can substitute if you don't like some of the toppings the ramen automatically comes with! Overall, would not wait longer than we did for some ramen, but it was a nice small restaurant.
author: Courtney D.

description:
Miki isn't a ramen shop, but they do offer a menu dedicated to ramen.  They also serve your typical bentos, donburi, curry, sashimi, rolls, and entrees.

This review is just for the ramen.  We ordered:

*Spicy Tonkotsu Miso Ramen
*Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen w/ Corn

Both ramens were ok.  The broth could have used a bit more flavor since it was bland.  For the spicy tonkotsu miso, I was able to taste the miso, but didn't taste the heat even though I ordered "spicy" ramen.  The noodles weren't al dente.  The ramen came with a piece of pork, square of seaweed, bamboo shoots, and green onions (which I asked to omit).

The service was slow. It took a while for our waiter to bring our bill even though it wasn't that busy.
author: Candice H.

description: I ordered takoyaki which is very moist inside and crunchy outside that made it special both ramen that we ordered have the right spices and broth mixture  the best part of this place whenit  come's to ramen they have choices between beef, chicken or vegetable broth happy yelping everyone
author: Allan A.

description:
Bomb Toro Hamachi, did not like the wasabi underneath but I know that's standard at many Japanese Restaurants.

I really like that they have a variety for ramen here, they even have a chicken based broth instead you can't have pork. They also have Miso, Spicy,  Shoyu, and Garlic options as well. You can pay more for a larger portion of ramen as well. I love my eggs though, so I'm sad they only give you half an egg and some bamboo. Personally, I prefer the pork more moist. I felt like it was a tad on the dry side, and rough as well. But my friend told me she preferred it because it was not as fatty as other ramen joints. The ramen was very flavorful, but it gets salty towards the end, so you definitely can't have too much of the soup which is a tad on the oily side. If you'd like to have it spicier as them for the spicy oil & powder to add it to your liking. I really enjoyed the ramen though, and I'm glad that they're open for lunch, just wish it was on the Lunch Menu at a discounted price too!

Gosh, my mouth is watering thinking about the Spicy Garlic Miso Ramen I got! XD Just beware that you will definitely get garlic breath after eating here.
author: Cindy C.

description:
Despite the restaurant name, we didn't order anything off the ramen menu.  Everything was between average and good.  They do have smaller rolls at $7 (but half the size)so you can order different ones.  Prices were about what you would expect otherwise.

I thought service was fine.  The place was small so it was easy to wave your hand and we got everything we needed.

Overall, glad this little place is there as an option in the neighborhood.
author: Franklin W.
