description: Found this place via Yelp. I was in the neighborhood & decided to try it out. I ordered the tonkatsu ramen with garlic miso & added corn. Broth was delicious and very flavorful. It was garlicky but not over powering. It was perfect! Server was great and attentive. Next time I'm back in the area, I will definitely pay them another visit.
author: Jade M.

description: Ramen is outstanding: Had the Tonkatsu shio ramen with pork belly!  Service can be slow but worth the wait!
author: Liz T.

description:
I wanted to give this place a try since a friend of mine is a regular here and always tells me how good the food is. Today, I finally found the time to go with my boyfriend and my brother, but was somewhat disappointed. 

A little after 6:00pm, I arrived around the area and saw a bunch of people outside the small place - turns out some were waiting for Miki and some where waiting for the place next door. I went in to put my name down and saw I was about 4th on the list. The wait wasn't anything too long before the couple who put their name right before me were seated. BUT there was a table for 4 open and my group wasn't seated - instead a family walked in and got seated right away at that open table. I went in to ask them how much longer the wait would be and it seems like they realized they skipped over my name and I had been watching it happen; I was offered a corner table for 2 and a chair would be pulled up for the third person in our party. We already waited for practically AN HOUR so we might as well try the food here, right? 

Since we waited for a long time, we already knew what we wanted, so we ordered 3 different ramen, 3 sushi rolls, and a large house sake. The water came to our table quickly, 2 of our rolls (yellow and orange rolls, each had 4 pieces) came after a bit of a wait, and then our ramen came one after another (few minutes between each bowl). Notice some things weren't checked off coming to our table? That's because they were forgotten - we ended up canceling them and asked for the revised bill. 

I will admit that their food has some good flavor to them, but the slow/unorganized service needs work. After tonight, I am very annoyed and would not consider giving them a second chance for a long time. The only reason why I am even considering going back is because my friend still raves about their other food options.
author: Christina L.

description: Loved the service, liked the food.  Didn't have to wait too long.  Just wish this place was bigger  =)
author: Angelica Y.

description:
Worried about the often mentioned line that forms outside Miki, i came early one evening to try their spicy tonkatsu garlic ramen. The parking gods were on my side for once and i found a spot right outside - something normally difficult to attain in this area. We ordered a couple of pints of sopporo ($3 happy hour price), an orange roll (salmon and avocado), and half orders of various fresh sashimi.

The ramen is good enough to convince me i need to come back if i'm ever craving a hot bowl of noodle soup. Thick broth and flavorful pieces of pork and egg! Definitely spicy enough but didn't have me crying (like my most recent experience at an izakaya...). 

The restaurant is super teeny tiny. I wouldn't come with a large group.
author: Samantha L.

description: First time at Miki and I loved it. Had the seafood sunomono which had a nice flavor with Ebi and big Tako tentacles. I love octopus so I also ordered the Tako Karaage which is the whole baby octopus fried they were delicious. I then had the Ramen with the chicken base broth and spicy Miso flavor. Clean plate club!!! I will be back for sure.
author: F N.

description: Out of all of the ramen places I have tried so far in the city, Miki has been my absolute favorite, and therefore, it is the restaurant to which I return the most. Their tonkotsu base is perfectly creamy and flavorful, and their noodles are the perfect texture and thickness. As with other good ramen restaurants in the bay, if you show up at prime dinner-eating times on weekend nights, you will likely have to wait a bit before getting seated, but it's worth it. My favorite is the garlic shoyu tonkotsu base ramen. Great stuff. Man, writing this is making me want Miki. Looks like I'll be heading over for dinner today.
author: Dorian K.

description: Food was good the first time I was here. But their hours / days are so weird, their early ones are 12-2? Why bother? Closed on odd days of the week and seems to change often. Apparently I'm not in sync with them. If I ever get there when they're open again I'll update this review.
author: SF R.

description: Spicy Miso Ramen with pork belly was amazing! Friendly service too! Would definitely come back to this place.
author: Daniel V.

description:
Healthy and sustainable portions of ramen are served up in this tucked away Outer Richmond spot. The pork tonkotsu with garlic miso helped me conquer an aggressive initial stage of potential fever like symptoms. The ample roasted garlic cloves and manageable spice factor were the key players in the battle for my health. 

Thanks Miki!
author: Katie P.

description: Came here w/ my family on a Saturday afternoon, it was a busy day there was a lot of people. The place is really small probably good for couples only, LOL. Party of 9 and I told him were willing to wait and can be seated in separate tables and he was like "not gona happen". Are you kidding me? Its the first time that happened to me. We got rejected! We drove all the way and ended up being rejected. So we decided to eat at the Pho place across the street which was really good!
author: Monique A.

description: Awesome place close to my house. True Japanese dishes with good lunch combos. This place is really small though and hard to find parking on balboa
author: Dylan L.

description:
This is the most authentic ramen place I have found in San Francisco.  The menu options, taste, and presentation are exactly like what I had in Japan.

I had spicy garlic miso ramen with chicken broth and pork belly.  The pork belly was sooooo good; sweet and savory.

This place rocks!!!!
author: Ryan Y.

description:
The Ramen has changed!
I do not know that it's the same owner or what.

As I wrote:
"It was overdosed by garlic.
I still have the same thought as my previous review as:
" I maybe wrong about this, but, i am just wonder, HOW CAN THEY MAKE A REAL RAMEN FROM SCRATCH? 
The place has too many things in the menu, so how can they make it?
That's why they only available Shoyu, Miso, Tonkotsu. You can buy pretty good instant Ramen package from Japanese market like this.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_..."

But the new menu is very simple. It is easy to read.
And the noodle is really good as the old Suzu like.
Do you remember that the Old Suzu at J-town?
Suzu also has changed so badly. The quality of the Ramen went down hill so as the service.
But, Miki has improved. The egg noodle is medium thick wavy noodle was al-dente, broth was very flavorful and decent price. I still don't know the Ramen is made from scratch but, I really like it this time.

I also had the Kara-age curry over rice, taste good but it was way too small. I also don't know the curry made from scratch either.
The curry gets 2 star.
But, I give 4 star for the new Ramen menu.

I don't mind to come back.
author: Nobu K.

description:
My friend and I were visiting Sutro Baths when we decided to grab some ramen for dinner. The proximity to the ocean was nice, and parking (my worst fear) wasn't too difficult to find. 

The waiter was friendly and relaxed, and seemed relatively busy, but since it was a small restaurant, one waiter was definitely enough (my water glass was never empty). He was very attentive at all times -- thank goodness! I hate having to do the half-sitting half-standing awkward wave dance to the waiter every time I need something. 

**TIP** Don't order the tea unless you are ready to pay an extra $1.50 per person. Purple Kow is right across the street if you want a post-dinner tea drink! 

The restaurant itself is tiny, with maybe about 10-15 small tables inside. We came here on a Wednesday night around 7:30pm, and were able to grab a table -- but it filled up quickly shortly after we arrived. 

As for the ramen: It was good, but nothing too special, especially for the price (~$10). The broth was flavorful, the noodles were decent, and soft-boiled egg was delicious, but the bamboo shoots were a little too squishy for my taste (around the consistency of a mushroom). If you're looking for ramen in SF, I actually enjoyed Katana-Ya (by Union Square) a lot more -- but you'll definitely get a shorter line here. 

Overall, I had a decent experience at this place. The attentive service was nice, but the food left me wanting something more. I'll probably only make it back here if I'm in the area.
author: Christine L.

description: We've gone back many times. Except for sometimes slow dinner rush service, the food and value are outstanding.
author: Andrew M.

description: I had an outstanding bowl of ramen recently at Miki.  This is a TINY restaurant which you could easily miss if you aren't looking for it.  I was looking for it, and I still almost missed it!  A good ramen is hard to find, especially so close to my home.  So I was delighted with the product I received- at a very reasonable price.  I will be back for sure to expand on the menu.
author: Andy S.

description:
Came here for the tonkotsu spicy miso and it was tasty! Obviously doesn't compare to Japan but for a ramen spot in the area, I was fairly impressed. The consistency of their noodles were on point, and the chashuu & the half-cooked egg was nicely flavored. The broth was not as rich as I preferred (considering it is tonkotsu) but I was satisfied.

Overall, I was content. Would have probably given this place 4 stars. However, the reason why I'm giving this place 3 stars is because of my post-meal experience. They put more MSG into their broth than I can handle. After walking out of the place, both my friend and I felt very nauseous and jittery for a couple hours. I don't know if it was because we have a lower tolerance for MSG..? Maybe. In the past, I've walked out of a few pho places with the same symptoms.
author: Okran O.

description:
My little hidden gem in Outer Richmond. Recently, they did a huge change on their interiors: New wall, new table sets, new lightings, and anything inside the restaurant. Looks super neat now.

The ramen is pretty good here. Probably best one in Outer Richmond neighborhood. Sometimes, you have to wait in line if the store is busy.

Food in general and appetizers are great!
author: Silin N.

description: Great food, fresh sushi, awesome ramen. Visually beautiful dishes; you can tell a lot of care is given to every dish. Beautiful, comfortable decor and super easygoing servers. I am a SF native foodie and this is my favorite sushi/ramen place by far; I come here every week. Recommend the miso ramen (chicken broth) with pork belly and bamboo, and of course the chef recommended hamachi toro nigiri.
author: Jennifer T.

description: Solid ramen with a lot of options for adds, sushi and appetizers.  Got the spicy miso, added corn and pork belly.  The pork belly is almost a must unless you're a ramen noob then fine don't get it.  I also got the spicy white tuna 3 piece roll and it was dericious.  The only thing i wished was that my broth was hotter in temperature.
author: Vince L.

description:
Miki is just plain good.  Good value, good food, good service. It's one of those really solid places you go to for a reliable meal if you live in outer richmond. 

My favs are the tuna yukkedon (think spicy tuna-esque chirashi bowl) and their garlic ramen. Beware of their garlic ramen because it is strong. I was thirsty for two days after!!
author: Anna T.

description:
I would give Miki five stars, but the wait was horrendous.  I get there and my party of four are on the list and the approx wait time was 30 minutes.  However, there are only a few options for seating with more than 2 people. So, it took like an hour to finally get seated since the wait really depends on how fast people eat and get served. 

Anyways, onto the important parts.  I ordered the chicken karaage and ramen (tonkatsu with garlic miso and extra noodles). The ramen was amazing. The broth was a little on the thick side, but that's totally fine. The chashu was thick cut and super moist. Also, the karaage was the best I've had around.  I guess you can say the wait was worth it, since I wasn't grumpy anymore after I ate!
author: Lisa X.

description: A small little place in the outer sunset but the ramen here packs great flavor. I ordered the spicy miss ramen and although the portion size was on the smaller size, the taste of the broth was excellent and delivered a good kick. The service here can be slow as there is usually only one person doing the hosting, waiting, and bussing during the lighter shifts.
author: Brandon N.

description:
Nice option for this stretch of Balboa!  I've only eaten here for lunch and each time it's been delicious. The ginger pork rice is a must-try if you're not in a ramen mood.  Otherwise, the tonkatsu ramen is a winner - get the spicy garlic tonkatsu ramen if you want to warm up or are fighting off a cold.

This is a local restaurant with a small staff.  Dishes can take a while to come out, but they're well worth the wait!
author: M G.

description: Expect a wait. This place is tiny to the point where you can see uncomfortably close dates going on every once in a while. But the ramen is dope. There's Purple Kow and La Promenade Cafe nearby while you wait.
author: Joy Y.

description:
I came here with my family for my birthday dinner because my family likes the asian tradition of eating noodles on birthdays. It is a very small place with only a few tables, so I imagine that during rush hour you'd have to wait a while. Fortunately, they do take reservations and since we made one, we hardly had to wait. 

I had one of the best bowls of ramen here, and my family enjoyed it too. I ordered the garlic miso tonkotsu (pork base) ramen with pork belly added to it (which is $3 extra but totally worth it if you want to indulge a bit more!) and it was so yummy and very filling. The soup wasn't overly salty or oily, and the noodles were firm and chewy. In addition to the noodles, the bowls come with half a soft boiled egg, tender bamboo shoots, one piece of pork (a bit less than typical ramen places) and seaweed. The soup to noodle ratio was also perfect, plenty of flavorful soup for each spoonful of noodles.  They also have a wide variety of other typical Japanese appetizers and entrees, if you're not necessarily a ramen person.
author: Kailin H.

description:
After hiking in the cold we decided on something soupy. Ramen it was! This place has very limited seating, glad we didn't have to wait. 

I ordered the Shio Tonkotsu with pork belly. Thank youuuu Yelpers! It was definitely worth adding the pork belly. The meat wasn't chewy at. all. Cooked and marinated to perfection. The broth tastes very clean (as in not fatty) and light. I dare say that without the addition of pork belly it would have been bland. The other flavor was Garlic Miso Tonkotsu. It definitely had the garlic kick. 

Only disappointment was that they ran out of spinach. I always want spinach in my ramen. *le sigh. 

It did get busy and we did have to ask for tea refill twice. We were a bit confused as to why some tables had their own tea pot while we had just our lonely cups. Especially after a hike. We want more! 

I might come back here... I spotted an intriguing dish from the table over. Must look at the menu and figure out what it was.
author: Audrey N.

description:
If you are looking for a good ramen place in the Richmond, head to Miki. Although the restaurant is smaller than the average ramen joint, the food measures up to my "ramen standards." 

Miki doesn't just serve ramen (although its their specialty), they also have udon, soba, sushi, bento boxes, and other Japanese entrees. However, if you enjoy your ramen, definitely order it. I would choose the spicy tonkotsu which includes scrumptious broth, a delicious egg, and perfectly cooked ramen noodles. I usually order an extra egg since it is just PERFECTION! 

My small complaint is that the broth is a little too salty so I end up having a lot of leftovers due to the fact that I can't finish the noodles/broth. I usually can finish entire bowl at other ramen locations, but at this one I cannot. Nonetheless, it's a giant bowl of great ramen served by genuine workers. Not too pricy for a bowl either. 

Miki is a ramen haven for all who crave a relish bowl of goodness, and if not the bento boxes are also pretty good. Come to Miki to travel in a ramen lover's paradise on the quaint Balboa location.
author: Jessica E.

description:
Don't get me wrong. The food is good, but boy that wait is ridiculous. 

They even have signs up stating that during peak hours the food will take longer to cook since everything is fresh. That's not a problem. But holy shit I didn't expect it to take that long!

I got in with my mother and grandmother (who are both diabetic btw, thank god they weren't starving) a few mins after they opened. Not that many people inside, about 2 tables. We sat down and 2 more tables sat. 5 total. Anyways holy shit it took 40 mins to get our food!! What!! There was a guy that put in a to go order and he must have came back 5 times to check if his food was ready. HOW CAN YOU ONLY HAVE 1 CHEF?!

Food was good though. Don't eat here if you are on a 1hour lunch break. Or be the first 2 customers.
author: J V.

description: Not bad at all! Small and cozy place! Go in parties of one, two or no more than four or you will be waiting for a while. If your desperate you could order to go. Their sushi is fresh and tasty. Ramen is good and age dashi tofu is really good!! One of the best tofu I tasted. This ramen broth is unique and has a special taste from your traditional broth and ramen.Very good! A must try!
author: K C.

description:
This lil hole in the wall..how did i miss you!?

Two types of broth, chicken or pork but u can still pick you salt, miso or shoyu for either =).  

I tried the garlic shoyu chicken broth and i asked them to make it spicy which they did without addl charge (yay) and also the same in tonkatsu broth..

both of them are unique and very delicious...the tonkatsu definitely have a fatter taste to it but it leave your taste bud clean unlike others with a lingering taste.  

The portion is decent size, but based on price and location, i guess its reasonable. 

The wait is the only thing that sucks since they only have one chef and one waitress but i dont mind =)
author: Laurie W.

description:
TONKATSU GARLIC SHOYU RAMEN. so delicious i had to put it in all caps.

love love this place. i love the authenticity of the food. i love how the ramen broth is garlicky and delicious. i love the cute teacups and teapots they use here. i even love the cute japanese grandpas who come and kick it here every weekend.

the base price of the ramen includes two slices of pork, a handful of bamboo pieces, half a soft-boiled egg, and a large piece of seaweed. it's an extra charge if you want to add corn, pork belly, extra meat, another egg, etc. regardless of that minor setback, this is (and will forever be) one of the best bowls of ramen i've had in the city.

it's a bit hard finding this place, because it is literally a hole in the wall. there is no sign outside, just a curtain hanging in front of the doorway. the space is pretty small, with probably about 8 tables of 4 total in the entire restaurant. i wouldn't recommend coming here with a large party.

what's also cool is that once you're all garlicky and satisfied, you can satisfy yourself by heading right across the street to cop some purple kow!

CASH ONLY! luckily there's a bank of america right down the block :)
author: Caitlin C.

description:
I was excited to see that there was a whole menu dedicated to ramen, so that is exactly what I ordered. I tried the tonkotsu miso ramen, and it was just ok. The broth was a little bland, and the portion was kind of small. I don't think I will order the ramen again. 

The waitress was friendly, though.
author: Rachel H.

description:
GLOBULAR FATTINESS. Legit no lies. Got here at 6pm on a Friday night and it wasn't too busy.  However, it quickly filled up.  Service is slow and that's because there's only one waitress so keep that in mind. Be patient :) 

The bowl of ramen was tres delicious considering it was a cold rainy day in SF. Got the Tonkotsu Garlic Miso Ramen. o-m.g So good! The broth had so many dimensions of flavor, and it was hearty. I felt a little guilty drinking the soup considering how I saw the blobs of fat, but it tastes so good going down. The noodles were the perfect consistency, chewy (japanese al dente). The egg was ok, but better than other eggs. I love the bamboo shoots (I ordered extra for $0.50).  The chasu was good, but I was definitely there for the broth and noodles. 

The boyfriend was smart and he ordered a side of chicken karage and dunked that into his broth. His fav! A repeat for me!
author: Vanessa K.

description: One of the best Ramen noodles in SF. Love to bring my friends visiting from out of state here for a yummy bowl of ramen. Very satisfying!
author: Mary T.

description: The best ramen! Hands down. Better than any place in Japantown. Come early because there is always a wait. I always get the spicy pork broth with extra garlic.
author: Patricia I.

description:
Awesome place!

For appetizers:
-Grilled squid...average, I had better.
-Grilled scallop skewers...Pretty tasty!

For entrees:
-Pork Spicy Miso Ramen with extra corn & pork belly! = MMMMM! Yummy yummy in my tummy!!
-Spicy Salmon roll w/ Avocado = Good!
-Spicy Hamachi roll w/ Avocado = Great!
-Spicy Tuna w/ Avocado = Da Best!
-Scallop Nigiri (Yekke) w/ Quail Egg = Awesome!
-Unagi Nigiri = Hella good!

Food comes out kinda slow, but that's cool with me. 
Service is pretty good & the waiter is very friendly. 

Love this place! I shall return!
author: Marc E.

description: My friend and I had lunch here today around 1pm. Place was full and we were third in line. Took about 15 min. There was only one wait staff for the front. We ordered tonkatsu miso ramen with extra chasu and corn, combo box with salmon sashimi and Saba salt. My friend said this was the best ramen broth in sf and I thought both fish was fresh and nicely grilled. The waiter was very nice. When we were waiting for our table he even ran out to chase a customer because they forgot their cc. Definitely will be back!!!!
author: priscilla m.

description: Seriously, some of the BEST ramen my husband and I have ever had. We arrived on a cold foggy day and were seating in their super tiny place pretty quickly. We started with some very fresh and tasty sushi rolls. I have to say they were just wonderful.  Then the ramen arrived and all conversation ceased. We both ordered the pork broth with medium spicy miso, plus some added vegetables.  Every spoon was so flavorful, the noodles perfect.  It was really amazing. Going back this week for a second visit.
author: Sallye M.

description:
Favorite ramen place in the whole city. Their broth is so flavorful ! I love that they have he option of pork or chicken broth.


I regularly get the miso garlic ramen with pork broth and tako karaage! Also, don't forget your Asahi. 


It is quite a small place, so expect to wait if you come during peak hours. I always reserve a table during dinner, it's super convenient. 

Unfortunately, I'm moving out of the Bay Area and will miss this place SO MUCH. Thanks, Miki, for the delicious ramen!
author: K N.

description: The broth was pretty good and noodles.  The broth was warm though when I got it.  Wasn't hot at all.  They need to work on making it hot when it  comes out.  The Chasu and pork belly tasted good but, it was not tender at all.  It was actually hard.  Maybe if they cook it longer I will give this place a 5 star.  Overall, the ramen was good but they need to work on those cons.
author: Randy P.

description:
Oh ho ho! Yummy Ramen up in this tiny restaurant. And, they have chicken based broth which is a little less rich than the typical pork broth (don't fret...they've got pork broth too). The egg was cooked perfectly and the noodles were so chewy. 

We had some toro sushi and a salmon piece, plus a roll and the sea weed salad. All was delicious except for the roll...roll was kinda bland. Bomb as hell ramen and Toro though!!

I may still be a bit of a ramen newbie. But, top three bowls of ramen I've had the pleasure to fill my fat face with!
author: Dusty B.

description:
Ignore the bad reviews, this place is fantastic. Service was wonderful and quick.

Both the pork and chicken broth options are delicious. If you like garlic, ask for the garlic miso with extra garlic. You will not be disappointed. (We didn't try the vegetarian broth as we're both meat lovers). 

Every table being served while we were there were enjoying a big serving of ramen for a reason... It's delicious!
author: Stephanie V.

description: Pretty exceptional ramen. I've had their garlic shoyu, their garlic miso and tonkotsu. Sooo goood! Service was prompt and wait time was reasonable given the space is the size of a walk-in closet. You best go there starving so that you have plenty of room to finish your bowl. You'll have nightmares if you let any go to waste! It's that good! Parking is doable in this neighborhood.
author: J A.

description:
Small restaurant with about 10 tables, one server, and one chef.  Feels homey.
Dinner chirashi sushi comes in a round plastic bowl topped with a piece of unagi, tuna, hamachi, tamago, octopus, shrimp, roe, and ginger.  Rice was nicely seasoned topped with sesame seeds and chopped up pickled mushrooms and tofu skin.  
Meal also came with miso soup and salad.
hole in the wall in the balboa area.  very quiet neighborhood.
author: Linda T.

description: I mean. Wow. Miki is OUT. OF. CONTROL. Such good Ramen, and the best sushi around.
author: Chris C.

description: Ramen isn't worth the wait. Very small place, uncomfortable inside.
author: Vasya M.

description: Wow.. if I had seen the food safety alert that it was in the bottom 5% in San francisco, i would not have went there for dinner tonight! They are so stingy. 4 pieces of sushi in a roll and only one piece of pork in the ramen. The fish in the sushi tasted so bland and the California roll was the worst I had in a long time. I had a nasty taste left in my mouth by the end of the night!
author: Eric C.

description:
My Manager from my last Firm posted on FB "found the BEST ramen in the city last night. I am going to be mysterious because it's a foodie secret!! :) OMG, so good, reminds me of Japan!!!" which led me to coming here 3 days later....  And I would completely agree.  It's DELICIOUS!  

The funny thing is when I came tonight, SHE WAS THERE!  

Anyways, onto the food.  I ordered the tonkatsu miso ramen and the boyfriend ordered the tonkatsu spicy miso ramen.  Add a side appetizer of tempura and my belly is happily filled and I find myself making continuous "MMMMMMM" sounds after every bite.  The broth is RICH in flavor, noodles are just the right amount of chewy and the portions are large!  For $8.50 we had a very full sized bowl of noodles with richness in every spoon.  The bowl comes with half an egg, piece of pork, seaweed slice and bamboo/green onions.  The egg is PERFECTLY cooked.  Still cold outside and oozing yolk center.  SO yummy.  It's difficult to find a place that makes them like this in SF.

They have options to add more and the bf added pork belly and I added corn.  The pork belly is very well marinated but it's not the typical so soft it melts in your mouth.  It's a bit tough... I suppose a tough texture to the bite which is not normally how I imagine pork belly but the flavor made it well worth trying.  I'm not sure if I would order that again.

The tempura was good, crunchy, hot out of the oil and very fresh.  The sauce was delicious as well!

Overall a wonderful experience and I can see why my Manager recommended.  I can't wait to go again and try the rest of their menu.  I was so excited about the Ramen that I didn't even remember to look at anything else!  I think I might try the donburis next time?  But I really do love me a bowl of ramen....

I would have to agree...this is definitely one of the better ramen places I've tried in San Francisco.  Quite a wonderful gem we have in Outer Richmond!
author: Sandy L.

description:
Unfortunately I was expecting more. The food is good, but not worth the drive across the park followed by a wait in the cold (while there's an open table waiting to be wiped down for 10 minutes). To be fair they were packed and the 2 nice wait (and 3-4 kitchen) staff seemed overwhelmed, but I've been to other similarly sized and staffed restaurants that managed to quickly get things out/done. 

Appetizers/rolls ordered: 
The caterpillar roll was good but fried shrimp is not hard to make tasty. Menu said 6 pieces?? we got 4. Salmon skin roll was nice and crispy, happy with that one. Gyoza filling was good. 

Ramen: 
Garlic miso and garlic shoyu were both good because of all of the grated garlic and roasted garlic. I love garlic..but also think the broth could have had more flavor. The garlic made the soup, was not impressed by the broth. Been to ramen places where the soup is rich and fantastic on its own. 

Tonkatsu was good. Added corn (canned, could do without). Egg was nice and runny. 

Overall it's a decent place for Japanese if you're in the neighborhood and don't mind waiting a long time for edible ramen. Next time I'm craving out of this world noodles though, I'll stick to my joint in the Inner Sunset.
author: Liz L.

description:
tasty ramen broth! and so fatty that when i took the take order home and finished the noodles the soup congealed at room temperature within the hour. i should post a photo for evidence. 
but back to the broth for a minute.  the soup rivals (dare i say it) Orenchi Ramen in Santa Clara. i did NOT say beats, i said "rivals"
the noodles have proper texture and taste and the accompanying slice of pork is flavorful.  but SF folk, this tiny spot on Balboa street in the Richmond is a definite hidden treasure when it comes to ramen places.
add this to your foodie bucket list!
author: Jeff W.

description:
I really liked the food here, but the service is painfully slow!

There are a lot of other food besides ramen. We shared a scallop and curry karage as an appetizer. I think we got the ramen before the karage. We definitely got food before our drinks. 

However, my ramen was good. The broth was rich and flavorful!
author: Terry C.

description:
MIki is an hole -in- the- wall old fashioned japanese restaurant. somewhere they've forgotten how to service patrons and make good food.

eats: tonkotsu sio ramen (8.5)
-ramen kind of kinky, not fully cooked yet.
-may be similar to  high end instant kind but also available wholesale
-topping (1)chashu, green onions, half boiled egg, menma
-broth very thick, tasty, had aftertaste, msg? too concentrated. forget to add water?
2,5 stars

temaki:
-no tea, water given, waitress just disappeared after leaving ramen. 
-only one other table and some pending take out.
-dinner black board had many items marketd "out".
-probably should have ordered curry kaarange chicken...
-bambo-like  tables and chairs....
author: Victor G.

description:
My hubby had already tried this place with a co-worker of his so one evening I decided we should try it together. 

It's a smaller place and gets packed if you don't go right at opening, so we were lucky to get a table. The kitchen seemed busy and so did the staff but eventually we had our order taken. Both of us decided to go with the miso ramen with roasted garlic. I added extra to mine, including extra broth. The portions were very satisfying and the flavor was full of garlic flavor and made me feel all warm and fuzzy inside. 

Prices are about right at $8.50 a bowl and they serve pretty big portions, even include an egg. The service was pretty friendly, despite, how busy they were. I highly recommend this ramen place if you live or work in the neighborhood.
author: Petra S.

description:
Came into Miki hoping for some really tasty ramen. We walked in and noticed that there was only one waiter. We put it our order as soon as we could, spicy miso ramen and garlic miso ramen. We waited.. And waited.. And waited. We noticed that 4 groups of people that had gotten put in there order before us still didn't have their food yet. 45 mins later, we got our ramen. At first glance, everything looked okay. However, our broth looked pretty oily. My friend's broth in her garlic miso ramen wasn't that flavorful so she asked for spicy oil to get a bit of kick in the broth. But what she was handed was a small bowl of sriracha and sesame oil. She mixed it into her broth and immediately noticed that her garlic miso tasted exactly the same as my spicy miso, just with sriracha and sesame oil added. In addition, both of our broths were extremely salty.

Prices were pretty high for the lack of quality in our food. The cost to add pork belly is $3 and the price of our ramen was $12.50 each. The pork belly was really tender but seemed like it was soaked in sugar and soy sauce for a little too long. The flavors were too different with the ramen that I almost lost my appetite.

However, the service from the waiter was excellent. My advice to Miki would be to hire more waiters so that one person isn't stressed out the entire time.
author: Bonnie S.

description:
Garlic Tonkatsu Miso. Extra garlic. Extra spicy. Yums. 

If you're on the same ramen boat as I am: trying to find the best ramen in SF without having to venture to San Mateo to wait an hour for Ramen Parlor or Ramen Dojo, then look no further. THIS IS IT. I mean, who's even hungry after an hour? 

Either way. My normal ramen spot is Sawaii Ramen on Irving, but they're just satisfactory. It doesn't hit that ramen G spot you need when you get that hankering. IF you know what I'm sayin'. And Katana-Ya in Union Square is just meh for me. The broth is VERY flavorful, noodles are perfectly chewy. I added pork belly to mine and it was falling off the fat. Just the way I like it. AND DAT EGG. dat egg.........that perfectly cooked, soft boiled egg added the perfect garnish. The epitome of every ramen picture you see on Instagram. 

Side note: Restaurant is TINY! Mostly 2 people tables, but they'll accommodate if they need to. Fits maybe 15 people at most? Luckily we went on a slower night during the week so it wasn't an issue to get a table. Did notice that it got busier soon after, around 8PM.
author: Jen L.

description: This place has horrible hours...and one look at the recent Health Inspection Report (I didn't notice it until afterwards) should have you running for the hills.  The owner is incredibly lazy and it shows.  While the tonkatsu soup base is OK, it comes off rather bambooy -- which I dislike.  All ramen come with only one small slice of pork - and it's extremely poor quality.  Adding pork belly didn't help as it was shockingly tough and very sweet.  They don't accept American Express and they also allow rude gaijin patrons to swear loudly and continuously have their cell phones on full volume.
author: Louis A.

description:
I'm a regular here and although the Ramen is top notch here, they can improve on their sushi. They offer sushi but considering this place reviewed for their ramen, their sushi could improve in consistency of freshness. They are hit or miss on sushi but don't let that discourage you from eating the sushi as I order sushi hear all the time because it still taste great.

Service is pretty decent as always and the server is always kind and respectful.

Will come again next week since I love this place.
author: Rick Ross A.

description: Not recommended. Ordered their bestseller Miso ramen. Took me 25 min for waiting, the meat is still half-cold and the soup is too salty. BTW, the pork belly there is not that bad which slow cooked with a hint of sweet.
author: Louie Z.

description:
Pros: Tonkatsu Garlic Miso Ramen is the one to get! Their sushi rolls aren't bad either.

Cons: Not a big restaurant so sometimes there's a wait.
author: K.C K.

description: As good as it gets for Ramen noodles.  The spicy miso in "Regular" (between Mild and Extra Spicy) was just right for this Midwest patron.  With sliced pork and corn, it was simply awesome.
author: Thane H.

description:
I've been to many ramen restaurant around the world... the lastest was ramen republic at Saporo, Japan. (Many different style of ramen restaurants locate in the same floor)  I had to say this place is one of the better one I tried in bay area.

The tonkasu soup was rich and flavorful, and since I'm here to critic the ramen.  I never order soup with spicy or garlic.  Always stick with the basic... soy, shio, shoyu, tonkasu and I ordered the tonkasu.   the ramen texture was al dante.  Now, al dante means firm but not hard, so it's not the proper description.  The texture was... crisp and firm yet tender.  Well, let's say it was done perfectly.

It's definitely way better than many of those ramen place in SF that operates by Chinese.  Once you taste the soup and take a bite of the ramen... you can tell instantly.  

Cons:  This is a very small restaurant... not a lot of tables.
author: Mark L.

description: I really love their ramen.  I ordered the same menu Chashu Ramen (this time with extra chashu).  It was so good!  My friend order Ika Sashimi and Black Cod.  I don't eat raw food so I tried his Black Cod.  Small cut for $13.50 (a little pricey).  It taste so good!
author: Annie A.

description: Really good ramen with lots of choices! Small place with just a few tables. Come early to get a table.
author: Brian H.

description: Amazing ramen and good sushi and appetizer options. Try the shio ramen for a lighter take - they also have a veggie broth that I will try next time. Worth the wait at dinner time, but if you can sneak over for lunch, you won't be disappointed (though you will probably need a nap!)
author: Jay L.

description: We came here on a Tuesday around 12:30pm. The place is very small, with about 7-8 small tables. It wasn't packed, but service was extremely slow. I had the garlic miso ramen and my daughter had the tonkatsu-don. Took 30 minutes to get our food on the table. The ramen was ok, broth was very very salty. The don was just ok, nothing special. I will stick with Ramen Dojo or Santa Ramen in San Mateo.
author: mei c.

description:
FOOD:
1.) ramen - yum not bads
2.) Simple rolls caterpillar. Not the best but pretty cheap. Wonder about the ramen. Try it some day. Sake happy hr large 3bucks.
3.) teriyaki chicken n sashimi lunch bento - kinda meager n skimpy for $8, comes w miso. but not much of a salad 

So next time I would only go here for simple rolls or ramen. 

SERVICE:
Not bad.

ATMOSPHERE:
Very small. Very casual.
author: Angela L.

description:
I came here with the fiancé after receiving a tip from a friend about this little gem so close to my house. Who would've thought. I think I'm still surprised. I may not be a ramen connoisseur, but i know what I like. So if you're looking for some technical review about the consistency of the broth and ingredients, save yourself the time and move on to another review. I am your typical consumer who enjoys noodles. 

In my opinion, I really enjoyed the ramen. The broth was well flavored. The noodles were al dente. The egg was the perfect consistency and temperature. Great customer service. Price...is average. We ordered the chicken karaage appetizer as well which was perfectly fried. My only critique is I wish instead of mayo, I wish the dipping sauce was some sort of spicy aioli.

My fiancé however begs to differ. She shares the opposite side of the spectrum, but since I do not agree with her, let's leave it at that. 

Nice and quaint.
author: Jason N.

description: The options and add ons are cool, but I wish the broth had a bit more flavor.
author: Hannah P.

description: Good food but service a little slow. That's the only reason I knocked off a star!  Husband got lunch bento box, which was a pretty good deal. I got ramen. It was good and tasty, as well as reasonably priced. Excellent selection of options for all good. Will hopefully come back!
author: Jennifer Hom C.

description:
This place is dirty! Their health score is at a 68. A 68? How that is acceptable blows my mind. I am a public health employee and to score that low means that your restaurant is beyond dirty! Go to their restroom and you'll find a guy in the back washing dishes in one communal tub with ALL the dishes literally getting thrown in infested water from previously old food and Lord knows what else. I'm pretty damn sure that does not meet the mere health standards. The kitchen is even worse! It looks like a back alley that hasn't been sanitized or wiped down in years! The water pitcher is stained with dirt and looks like it hasn't been washed at all. It looks like it been purchased in the 1990s and has not been replaced since. When we were given our tea pot, I lifted it up and there were traces of dirt on our table. There was also only one server who was handling EVERYTHING, wiping down tables, clearing dishes, delivering food, and taking care of people's bill and for the few hours we were there, I have not seen him wash his hands once. 

It was busy, there was only one chef and it took them half an hour for our appetizer to arrive. It was a good thing I wasn't starving or in a hurry anywhere or else I would've been super grumpy and been complaining the whole time. At first I thought, yum I found my usual ramen place, but this place has a lot of health code violations, starting first and foremost with water sanitation, the ultimate no no. Not coming back here!!!
author: Marie N.

description:
How can you ever have Ramen elsewhere? Well...at least for me, this is the case! Since being introduced to the fresh ramen at Miki, I have been back 1-2 times per month and have yet to veer from the ramen path! And, since discovering this wondrous ramen, havefound myself ordering ramen at other places, only to be sorely disappointed! I've yet to find a better ramen!

I religiously order the spicy Tonkatsu miso ramen,  deviating once to the roasted garlic variety which I found tasty, but not my preference to w/out.

Warning: wait time is a bit inconsistent.  My friend and I were informed on our last visit that due to a large order ahead of ours, it could be a half hour wait for our ramen. Not to worry-we had ordered sushi and wakame which was fairly quick and staved off the hunger while we waited!  This time, our "usual" had corn and an oily film on top which I took to be butter. I'm not sure if this was an order error or a "bonus" for the wait, since corn and butter are among several "add on" toppings you may choose for an additional fee. Yummy!

I continue to go back, as I can't seem to shake this newfound craving! Sadly, the other offerings are never ordered by me, though they look really good!  I just keep ordering the ramen!  The "white board" offerings look extensive, with items "sold out" by the time I get there at my usual later weeknight hour!  

Speaking of which, I have always been on a late weeknight and there are always others there! On occasion, one or two other staggered tables of guests; more frequently,  rotation of 4-8 other parties of 2-4.  It is a small space with limited seating. Tonight, four other parties were seated, making it half-full. One other couple came in while we dined. It's small, it's cozy.

Last, I will just say that they have this wonderful dessert ( and yes, I'm a 
pig as you can see, as I'm outting myself  by informing you that I ALWAYS get a bowl of ramen-and you can see I get sushi , too!). Anyway, this dessert consists if three little wonton-wrapped, mochi, nanana and sweet red bean-filled fried dumplings served with a dainty scoop of green tea ice-cream with just the slightest drizzle of chocolate 
sauce, sprinkled with powdered sugar.  Pretty divine way to end a piggy 
session! Run out on occasion, not always part of my Ramen run!

Small (not great for parties larger than perhaps 6), sometimes a bit of a wait; I would be VERY SAD if this restaurant ceased to exist! Viva la Miki!

ETA: It occurred to me that it is worth mentioning that they only accept credit cards during dinner hours. Lunch is cah only but should you forget, have no fear-a bank (B of A-?) is a half block down on the corner!
author: Leslie W.

description:
Another ramen place to try because we were too lazy to go all the way to San Mateo and wait for Ramen Dojo. lol

Anyway, for such a small place, we were surprised they even took reservations for a group of 6. It was definitely a plus, no line for us! 

I grabbed tonkatsu garlic shoyu and it wasn't bad, but it was definitely nothing special. I don't think it was even very memorable. 

I don't think I'll be screaming to return to this place. I'd much prefer to go a few blocks up to get some Shanghai Dumpling King, even if there's a line.
author: Harriet W.

description:
Miki is a small little japanese restaurant in the Outer Richmond.  It is easy to miss so be on the look out for it.  It probably seats around 20 people max. and the service can be a little slow for bigger parties, but its well worth the wait.  I came here at lunchtime during the weekday and it was fairly empty.

With my group of friends, we ordered a variety of things from the lunch menu.  The lunch specials are a great deal (only $8.50!) for two selections plus rice, miso soup, and a small salad.  I ordered the chicken katsu and the saba shioyaki.  They were excellent and very flavorful.  The portions of each were about half of a what you would normally expect but probably hence why they give you two.

While cheap and pretty good, this restaurant lacks the normal flare of your typical Japanese restaurant. The sushi selection is sub-par and the quality is average (the fish looked okay and got some mixed reviews by my friends who ordered it).  Moreover, the service (because there was only one person and one chef) was very limited, but still sufficient.

Its a decent restaurant for a quick bite and reasonable if you're looking for some cheap Japanese food.  I will probably be back to try their well-reviewed and raved about ramen.
author: Robert T.

description:
It's a very small restuarant.. blink your eye walking by and you'll pass it.  I sure did the first time I walked by it and had to check the address on yelp to make sure I was on the right block!

This place is known for its ramen, and indeed, they have good ramen noodles.  I ordered the tonkatsu garlic miso ramen - the broth is thick and well-made with enough garlic to boot.  What I was most impressed with is the texture and consistency of the ramen; it was just the way I like it!  Of course, you also get 1/2 an egg perfectly prepared so it melts in your mouth.  It would be five stars if there was more cha-siu and vegetables/mushrooms to go with the delicious ramen.

Also, it's really small inside and so it's great for a quick, casual, and surprisingly inexpensive meal, but would be nice if it was bigger and had some nice decor.  I will definitely come back to try their other ramen broths.
author: Holly H.

description: I have to been to Miki on three separate occasions and have only tried the ramen, which was delicious! Mind you, I don't have much ramen experience but I am very happy with what they have here. I have tried the to Torigara  and Tonkotsu broth in the miso and garlic miso flavor, both were amazing. The pork belly is a must! The only downside was that on two occasions we had to wait a very long time to get our food, and it was only a Tuesday or Wednesday night so I can't imagine the wait times on weekend nights. Overall, I will be returning here because I want to try their other menu items and because it's so close to my house.
author: Madelinn G.

description:
Good solid Japanese food. 

Due to proximity to work I am a lunch regular and dinner frequenter on late nights. 

Never disappointed with the service or entrees. While this is not my favorite place for sushi it's not bad when I have a craving.
author: Miharu Y.

description: After scouring the city for the best ramen, my boyfriend and I can't stop coming back to Miki over and over again. Get the spicy garlic miso ramen and add the pork belly. Amaaazing broth and perfect noodles. It's a small place with one server so sometimes it can take a while, but it's always worth it.
author: Carla E.

description: This little place is one of the most authentic Japanese restaurant with such a reasonable price for this city! It's very cozy, nice wood interior and great food. I'm definitely a big fan of this place!
author: Kyoko U.

description: Best vegetarian ramen I've ever had! Incredibly complex, delicious broth. Portions are on the smaller side for the price, but that's probably just because I from out of town and am not used to San Fran prices.
author: Lily L.

description:
First of all, I LOVE GARLIC. Unfortunately, I wasn't a fan of the tonkatsu garlic miso broth, I felt like the garlic was just way too assertive. I couldn't really taste anything else. I think I'll opt for just tonkatsu miso or tonkatsu shoyu next time. But, their noodles were so good. Nice bite to them. And I'm telling you, I've had a TON of ramen in Japan.

I was super excited about the soft boiled tea egg, but mine came out hard boiled. Can we say PUHLAAAYED?! I'm praying next time it'll be soft boiled!

The scallop nigiri was DELICIOUS. Sooo yummy. It was like butter, but better. Most amazing scallop I've ever had. 

Next time, I'll order my ramen with an extra egg and extra chashu.
author: Bianca W.

description:
Delicious food, but ehhh service. My glass of water was empty, and we had to ask for things.

This tiny, cute restaurant was packed with people, and we got up to leave our table as soon as we paid our check because there were others waiting  to sit down. We could have paid our check even faster, had the waitress noticed that we were ready to pay.

This place is supposedly known for ramen, so that's of course what we got. My friend got the garlic soup base, and I got the regular soup base. Hers was good for the first few sips, but you could definitely get tired of that soup base after a while. I was glad I had the regular soup base.

It's also conveniently located across the street from Purple Kow. :)
author: Christina L.

description:
How can this place have a 4-star rating? 

This is the worst Japanese restaurant I've been to in San Francisco. Full stop. 

Most of the food was so disgusting, it wasn't edible. 

Everyone talks about the fresh fish? The sushi was mostly frozen crap, and not high quality, and they only have a few standard fish that they make into hundreds of different combinations. 

Service was ridiculous. Completely incompetent, totally slow. 

Bad atmosphere, horrible service, inedible food, lousy selection. Does this place even deserve 1 star?
author: Eater S.

description: Simply delicious!  Soba noodles with chicken and veggies yum!  Service sometimes slow because they get really really busy.
author: Chelsea D.

description:
The Japanese food here is fantastic! I think Miki's strong points are sushi rolls (they are not only delicious but also cheap) and the Katsu-don (good comfort food on a cold day). 

However, the trade off is that service is slow. Even when my boyfriend and I were the only ones in the restaurant, it took a while to get our food and even the Miso soup and salad. We also went another time, crowded at lunchtime (so more understandable) but it took is 30 minutes to get our food.  It's a small place so there is only 1 chef and 1 waitress...but 30 minutes! 

I still love the food. I will probably do take out or something from now on because I can't stand the wait.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Made reservation for 4 ppl at 7pm on Tuesday night. When we arrived, the restaurant was only half-filled (max of 15-18 ppl). Ordered 3 ramen, 1 bento box of tempura & grilled mackerel, fried octopus, & octopus balls. Appetizers took 30 minutes to arrive. I inquired at the 20 minute mark and was then informed the kitchen would start working on our order. What if I didn't inquire? The bento then arrived at the 45 minute mark. The 3 bowls of ramen arrived at the 55 minute mark! I'm scared to imagine how slow it would be if it was a Friday or Saturday night. Ramen dinner taking 1.5 hours on a Tuesday night...huh? 

For ramen, we ordered 1 bowl of tonkatsu extra spicy and 2 bowls of garlic miso. The noodles had good body & chew! The 2 broths were rich & flavorful. The half runny egg was good but room temperature. There was only 1 piece of chasu and some haphazardly plated piece of seaweed and pieces of bamboo shoots. Plating needs work. Comparatively speaking, Ramen Dojo in San Mateo performs ramen art in a bowl. 4 stars overall for ramen taste (not presentation). 2 stars for the appetizers and the slower than molasses & clueless service. I would have been more understanding if the single waiter had perceptively apologized for the slowness of the kitchen and poor timing of the dishes. He just pretended to not notice my growing aggravation! He also asked if I would like more water when I waiting. Duh...I'll just stare at empty glass while waiting for my food to arrive! ;-)

If I had 1.5 hours to kill & only craved ramen, I would return. Otherwise, there are other comparable ramen places that serve food in half the time.
author: H E.

description:
2nd time back and decided to give their ramen another go. Tonkatsu spicy miso was great and still super spicy (FINALLY got me some bamboo shoots too) but I just think their broth is a little too rich for my tastes. 

Miso black cod STILL sold out?! *sad face* My friend ended up getting the grilled black cod ($14) but the portion was tinier than my small fist! It came with a few string beans and a small scoop of mashed potatoes.

My friends got the 2-item bento box ($12) and the chicken katsu was DELICIOUS! The batter was light and crispy over a large, tender chicken steak. I am definitely going to get that next time.

Curry croquettes ($4.75) tasted exactly like a less pungent Indian samosa. Good but not unique.

SPICY TUNA HANDROLL ($3) - So good, I had to order an additional one later in the meal. Something about the flavors of the rice, seaweed salad and spicy tuna just all came together perfectly. I can't stop craving for this!
author: Liana L.

description:
What a hidden gem for SF!

All this time I passed the restaurant off as another Chinese-owned Japanese place but it was quite the opposite! Outside is nearly unnoticeable from the street and unassuming.

We had two bowls of ramen and takoyaki.

Ramen was above average and I will definitely go back. Reminded me of Kotetsu in Santa Clara which is a few shades lower than Orenchi in my book. Rich and flavorful broth with what seemed to be an above average amount of noodles. I would go back here before I revisit Orenchi Beyond and Ramen Dojo. Orenchi Beyond - Can't deal with a 2+ hour wait. Ramen Dojo - Just didn't do it for me and I'm not a fan at all.

Ahh, the takoyaki - Possibly one of the best versions I've had! Crispy outside with big pieces of octopus inside - One included a full tentacle! YUM :) Perfect texture inside and very fresh.

Downsides: VERY small restaurant. Decor? None. Service? Slow because they had one waiter (who was very nice) for 8 tables (approx 18 people) and two chefs.

TIP: MAKE SURE YOU PAY FOR PARKING!
author: Con L.

description:
Dear NYC, 

You know what? I can survive without your ramen now that I know that great ramen and amazing broth that-tastes-as-if-it's-been-simmering-for-hours-if-not-days does exist in the City. Yes, that's right, I called San Francisco, "the City." 

---------------------

Now that that part is over, back to the main part of what this review is theoretically supposed to be about.

OMG, Miki has good ramen and even better broth. NYC, suck it! 

However, if you want to understand the reason why people don't eat garlic  before a hot first date or before an interview for their #1 dream job, try their garlic broth. While I can devour Gordon Biersch's garlic fries like no other, Miki's garlic broth is a little too much on the strong overwhelming side (think you're gonna have dragon breath) and I would strongly encourage just eating the ramen with the tonkatsu shoyu broth. 

Sadly, while their broth satisfied my NYC ramen cravings, Miki's service is a little slow. Water is hardly refilled, takes a while for the bill to get paid...
author: Rebecca H.

description:
I had a huge craving for chirashi so I headed over to Yu Zen but to my dismay they turned me down. They were completely full and could not even take a to-go order. So I walked over to Miki because I of their $13 chirashi. 

When I entered the restaurant everyone there was ordering ramen, which made me slightly regret my chirashi order. Looking at the chirashi, I now understand why it was $13 -- less fish. Instead of the normal two pieces of each type of fish, I only got one and there were only 5 different fishes. Very small but still very satisfying. Also ordered two unagi nigiri for $3.75, which was totally worth it. I will be back to try the ramen and probably order their affordable chirashi.
author: Andrew W.

description:
Oh, I hate to do this, because there is almost never a wait here. Miki's already had a high enough rating in my book, but after they added a Ramen menu, they earned a fifth star. I don't even want to let the hordes know, but it's my duty to write an accurate update--Miki's now makes the best ramen in San Francisco. Period. End of update. 

If you disagree, I really, really want to know about it and give the competition a visit. Luckily Miki's is still located way over on my end of town, and hopefully the hordes won't be waiting outside the door next time I visit.

Add an extra tea soaked egg (soiled egg) for .50. A perfect dinner is the Spicy or Miso Pork Broth Ramen with Garlic and an order of Albacore tataki nigiri. Their tataki is just right too.
author: Liza B.

description:
Small, cozy ramen/izakaya style restaurant.

Food was good = 4 stars. The natto omelet was one of my favs. I know it's probably easy to make but how they made the omelet was just perfection. The ramen had A LOT of flavor. I ordered the tonkotsu garlic miso broth & the garlic was a wee bit overwhelming for me. And trust me, I LOVE garlic. I probably still smelled & tasted garlic 2 days later. The noodles were good, though. I like them aldente (harder) & that's how they were made. It didn't get soggy either. 

1 star less because the service was really slow. It took awhile to order, then another 20 minutes or so to receive our food. Then they messed up on my friend's ramen so they took it back & by the time she got her new one, everyone else was pretty much done eating already. 

Restaurant is really small. Fortunately, even though we had a group of 6, we were able to be sat within 10 minutes. Not bad!
author: Alysha K.

description: Tried the miso garlic ramen, definite 4 stars for the tonkotsu miso broth. It's hard to find a place that does miso broth well, and this place comes in at above average. While I love garlic, I did regret choosing miso garlic -- it was TOO much raw garlic in top of cooked and roasted. It overpowered the good flavor of the broth and became just a spicy garlic soup. So unless you LOVE lots of raw garlic, I recommend sticking with the regular, which I will gladly come back for.
author: L L.

description: Just a great hole in the wall spot. Limited space but thats a good thing. Perfect for a little week night din din!
author: Andrey P.

description: I was on my way home, and starving, and wanted to grab some vietnamese food from a local spot on Balboa. LUCKILY that place was closed and I wound up across the street at this Hidden gem! I Yelped it and saw some good reviews about the Ramen bowls so in an effort to speed things up I went with the basic chicken broth ramen TO GO. The server was quick and friendly, and my Ramen  was done in 5-10 minutes. Normally I'm really not that into Ramen because they never have flavor, BUT THIS RAMEN IS THE BOMB.COM.... seriously!! It may not look like much in its' small togo containers but as soon as I opened the broth I could smell the flavor, and the ramen itself was perfectly cooked. Not super mushy but soft and slightly chewy. It tasted really fresh. They also have bamboo shoots that have ridiculous flavor and not to mention a soft boiled egg that I will probably order extra of next time! Once I took a bite I was instantly glad I had ordered it togo..... because I chowed down like a fat kid eating the corner piece of a chocolate birthday cake! If you like Ramen you REALLY need to try this Chicken Broth Ramen! I promise you there will be no sad faces at the end of your bowl! I will definitely be going back here, it was perfect for a cold and rainy night in SF!
author: Brandi B.

description:
Was excited to eat ramen/sushi at this small, quaint restaurant this weekend but then...

"You have to spend $10/person" said the waitress 

What?  -- we were thinking.  $10 minimum for credit card charge.  Sure! NP!

"No, you have to spend $10 per person. You have to have $50 worth of food" 

My group of 5 had only ordered 3 bowls of ramen and 2 sushi rolls.  We weren't hungry enough to eat $50 worth of food so we took our $40 somewhere else...

The customer service here was unfriendly and made the place uninviting.  =/  Will have to satisfy ramen cravings elsewhere.
author: Kristie F.

description:
Delicious spicy ramen! Broth is amazing & spicy! 

I think this is probably one of the best places in the city for ramen. Yes, it is a drive to the outer Richmond but it is worth it. I think it is the perfect location for ramen. For the cooler part of the city, a nice hot bowl of spicy ramen is comforting. 

A few things to add to your order are corn and pork belly. Yes, I said it, PORK BELLY. Now go and have a bowl!

Parking can be a problem during peak time.
author: Molly T.

description: Wow, have I not given this place a review? Come here probably twice a month at least. The best ramen you will find in the city.
author: Colin B.

description: Ordered the Garlic miso Tonkostu. The garlic is super strong! The noodles are different than most other ramen places. If anyone has ever been to Himarwari, the noodles are round so it is very similar to theirs. I didn't think it was anything special. The cha-su was very hard and everything else was average. My boyfriend got two specialty rolls. It comes with three pieces for 6.50 each. They were very average as well. It is quite expensive and expect to wait 45 minutes for your food.
author: Joey C.

description: The food was fine (when it finally came) and the waiter was really nice.  But the waiting!!   We had a 25 minute wait for the edamame, over an hour for the ramen!  Yes they say it's a small kitchen and may have longer wait times during peak hours, but this is just ridiculous.   Especially if you are going to have such incredibly long wait times for the mains, you should at least be able to get the most basic appetizers out relatively quickly.
author: S. M.

description: Haven't been here in two years,  loved it back in the day.. Best ramen in the city in my opinion .  I was thinking maybe something had changed with the bad reviews as of late. I was craving ramen and was like screw it... It was the same as two years ago,  best ramen I've had and I've been to ramen dojo.... Don't let the bad reviews detour you,  this is legit tonkassu and get the pork belly it has a subtle sweetness to it...
author: Nicholas P.

description:
I was seriously craving some GOOD ramen, so A and I thought we would FINALLY make the trek to San Mateo to try out Ramen Dojo.  Luckily, we decided to look them up online first to see what time they opened and discovered that they're closed on Tuesdays. :(

I still wanted ramen, so instead, I did a proximity search on Yelp for a ramen restaurant open on Tuesdays and stumbled upon Miki.

I have never even heard nor seen this place.  And it's not that far from my digs.  Yes, I said digs.  I thought I'd try it out.  I don't really like it.  I probably won't be using it again.

Yelp says they don't open until noon, so we didn't get there until 12:30pm.  FYI, it looks like they're open before noon since their afternoon happy hour is from 11:45am - 2:00pm.  Parking on Balboa street is metered, but they're doing a TON of construction in the neighborhood right now so it's a bit crazy.  We found FREE street parking on 37th Avenue, so that was pretty convenient.

There's about 8 tables in the restaurant.  6 two-tops and 2 four-tops, I think.  When we got there, 5 tables were already occupied.

I ordered the Garlic Miso Tonkatsu Broth Ramen and A had the Spicy Miso Chicken Broth Ramen.  The noodles were perfectly al dente.  The soup was not hot, but more on the hotter than warm side.  I loved the soft-boiled egg.  I think I discovered what my favorite kind of egg is.  Did you guess soft-boiled?

Both bowls were about $9.75 each.  We also took advantage of Happy Hour and got one large hot sake for $3.00.

Service is definitely on the slower side.  I think the kitchen prepares everything in the order it is received.

Approximately $25.00 for two.

I'll be back.
author: Kris L.

description:
It's true. This is a tiny restaurant with a couple of cooks and one waitress. If the restaurant is filled to it's limited capacity, it will take a while for the waitress to take your order and your food will take quite some time to come out which can seem like for-ev-ver if you're already starving before getting here. Also, the waitress isn't all that friendly but she gets the job done. 

Nonetheless, I am fan of both the tonkotsu garlic miso ramen and the tonkotsu spicy ramen. The ramen bowls come with chasu, egg, nori, bamboo shoots, and green onion. A bowl comes with plenty of chewy noodles and the best part of the ramen for me is the thick, rich flavorful broth. The garlic miso ramen packs a lot of garlic flavor with garlic bits in the broth, and garlic paste and whole cloves of roasted garlic atop the noodles. As for the spicy ramen, it's very flavorful in its own way. It carries a nice kick of heat that lingers in your throat.

I'm not sure how the rest of the rolls compare but I was unimpressed with the red roll (tuna, avocado and crab). It was simply a flavorless roll that I think may be due to the lacking quality of the ingredients. 

I would definitely return to Miki for the ramen and even to try the specials listed on their white board. In preparation for future visits, I plan to account for the extra time required to dine at Miki and plan to bring a whole lotta patience along too.

On a side note, I saw a paper on the wall which said Cash Only during lunchtime but they do take card at dinnertime. Also, they have a happy hour special for Sapporo beer and hot/cold sake from 5-7PM.
author: Maya S.

description: Pretty good ramen for Outer Richmond area where choices for Ramen are not that great!  I tried the Tonkatsu Garlic Miso and my fiance tried the Tonkatsu Spicy Miso.  Both were delicious!  Chicken Kaarage was not so good.  Very chewy.
author: Suzanna F.

description:
The ramen comes with *the* most perfectly soft boiled egg. 

So perfect. 

I weep. 

I steal the other eggs at my table.
author: Jacquee P.

description:
One cold and rainy night, my tummy craved for some hot tasty ramen. Looking for something close to the boyfriend's house, Yelp pointed to Miki. We were skeptical because we have never heard of this place and whenever we passed by, it was empty. And when we arrived, there was (just as we expected) only one other family having dinner. But we weren't about to give up just because of that, I ordered their "Yellow Roll" about $6, and the Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen. The bf ordered Spicy Garlic Ramen. Each about $9. The hamachi in the yellow roll was really fresh and the whole thing was simple and delicious.
Finally the ramen arrived. Looking at it gave me a heart attack. THIS IS NOT FOR EVERYONE. This is not the healthiest ramen ever, because it had a layer of shine and not just a regular thin layer, but a thick layer that can hold all the heat underneath it. Once we dug in and started eating, I stopped worrying about the oily fatness. It was delicious! Hearty, flavorful, authentic goodness. 

Real Japanese wait staff and cooks, with real Japanese accents with real Japanese food.

Must try, but definitely not for everyone!
author: Athena L.

description: Food is good but everything else is hit and miss.  Your order can arrive quickly or take up to an hour.  It doesn't matter what you order.  Identical order arrives randomly with some tables getting their food later even if they ordered first. Tables are usually cleaned well between sittings but there were a few times it wasn't clean.
author: Gus K.

description:
Came here for a random lunch on a weekday. It's a tiny spot across the street from Purple Kow. Got seated immediately. I was in the mood for ramen so my friend picked this spot from the Yelp reviews. 

I had the tonkatsu garlic broth ramen with pork belly. The broth was very flavorful and there was ample amounts of fresh garlic (yummm). The noodles had a good consistency and the portions for the pork belly were almost a meal on its own! Just kidding, but they were a lot bigger than I expected. 

All in all, a solid place to get your ramen fix. I'm not sure how busy it gets on other days but I would come back if I'm ever in the ramen mood again (and not willing to go to Ramen Dojo or further south for ramen)
author: Victor D.

description:
Mom n Pop type restaurant with tasty ramen at decent prices!  Sapporo on draft!
Besides the possible long wait for your food (it's a hit or miss) and terrible parking, I'd be here more often.
author: Leeseuh K.

description:
LOVE the ramen.  I know something is amazing when ever since my first trip I've planned in my head every day a way to get to Miki for some more.  I haven't been to many ramen places in SF other than Halu and Suzu (neither of which I recommend) but this place rocks.  

I had the tonkatsu garlic miso raman and the broth was amazing.  For $8.95 my bowl came with chashu pork, egg, bamboo shoots, and green onions.  There are plenty of extras you can order from bamboo ($0.50) to pork belly ($3.00).  The cons are that the pork was a little on the skimpy side and I'm not a huge fan of the noodles as I think they are a little bit more textured and al dente than I would normally like.  But really it is all about the broth! It was rich and buttery and not too salty.  There was plenty of garlic as well as some whole roasted cloves. Delish!!  

The prices are reasonable and the entire menu looks awesome.  I hear there can be a wait but I went right at opening and the place was pretty quiet for the duration of my time there.   Service was also quite good.

Soup lovers, run, don't walk, you won't regret it.
author: Mylinh M.

description: This is only for the ramen! If you get any of the other stuff they have then you're on your own. Ramen is definitely among the better I have eaten (and my friends and Itry a bunch of different ones). The best in my opinion is the Tonkotsu Shoyu with the Salt one a close second. Def worth a try. When we come up to visit San Francisco this place is on our must come again list. It's a small hole in the wall type so you might have to wait around 20 min. Do it...
author: Pedro G.

description:
I hate to do this, because it's my 'hood, and I don't want the wait to be longer than it already is. 

I've lived in this neighborhood for over 15 years, and have been coming to Miki since it opened, originally because of: 1) best chanwan-mushi 2)tempura oysters 3)never crowded and it was in my neighborhood.

But recently, they added ramen to their menu and that became a game-changer. Suddenly my favorite Japanese restaurant has a line out the door, and why...because they make the best chasu ramen (in my opinion)!

I love coming here, but please MIKI, or whoever the owner is, can you not add just one more server during nights and weekends? It puts a blight on my dining experience when I see your lone server (and they're always good and efficient), looking harried and harrassed while i'm shoveling your yummy chasu and ramen into my trap.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
My friends and I were on our way to Purple Kow and realized we were hungry for real food too! We Yelp'ed Japanese restaurants nearby and found Miki, literally right across the street from Purple Kow. 

Tonkatsu miso garlic ramen with extra garlic... is THE BEST!! :) It was raining that day and our whole meal was soo perfectly satisfying :)

It's my favorite ramen i've had in norcal so far (although I haven't tried Dojo yet)! the broth was flavored just right, almost creamy because of the garlic.  

We also got a few rolls to share, and the sushi was fresh and delicious :) I want to go back!
author: C K.

description: Their soup doesn't disappoint. Their ramen comes with a piece of chashu, seaweed, bamboo shoot, half an egg, and garlic. The location of this place is a bit ghetto though. I came during lunch on a weekday and it was deserted besides some middle/high school kids wandering the streets. Their sushi/nigiri menu looked promising although I didn't order anything from it.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Service: decent

Food: I am a ramen fan but my bf never was... But he def enjoyed the ramen here. We both got the spicy garlic miso ramen that is highly recommended, although there is too much salt!!
author: Cindy C.

description: Driving to get some cozy warm food, found Miki in yelp and decided to go in. Service is slow and ok nothing outstanding. Food ramen was delish I enjoyed it not a ramen expert, yet I love great food and clean food and I found a 4on both .
author: Meleesa M.

description: After its very pleasant remodel, I no longer see the health code issues which bedeviled the restaurant previously, and the very slow service has also improved dramatically. A great neighborhood spot.
author: Slip E.

description:
Oh my goodness gracious. The ramen here is delicious. My friends and I were lapping up every bit of delicious tonkotsu spicy miso broth we could (and word: it is, indeed, spicy). I prefer my noodles on the soggier side, but my friends loved Miki's springy, almost-al-dente ramen. There's one piece of chashu pork, one divinely cooked egg, and a scattering of mushrooms per bowl, so order extras if you don't like your ramen noodles feeling lonely.

It has to be said, however... the service is poor and the waits are ridiculous. We were second in line until the couple in front of us bounced -- they realized how slowly everyone was getting served. There was one server for a full house, which might have worked better if she had been more efficient or friendly. Instead, it seemed like she was avoiding us (incl. making eye contact with us) the whole time we were there. We waited 10 min for a table, 15 min to order, 10 min for water, 45 min for our food to come out, 10 min to get our check once we called for it... and these are likely underestimates. My sympathies. It must be hard being one person serving a whole house, and I won't blame the server-- but management needs to add more waitstaff. Otherwise, my friends and I will just be ordering takeout. But hey -- we're still ordering, so it must be good!

EDIT: have made many a return trip and Miki's service is still outrageously slow. One time, the waitress even forgot my order until my partner had already finished his meal! This would be so totally unforgiveable if not for the deliciousness of the ramen. Damn you, deliciousness!
author: Julie D.

description:
Super fresh sushi ingredients all around. Stellar ramen. Very reasonable prices. Overall great food. Japanese run (I heard the small staff speaking Japanese to each other and to the kitchen).

I am definitely coming back!

This place is tiny, so get here early. But it is well worth it!
author: Art W.

description:
Came here on 9/13/12. 
Waitress service poor. She was in a bad mood the entire time. When bussing our table, she flicked a grain of rice onto my shirt! 

The whole time she seemed like she didnt want to be there. She didnt bother asking us for any refills for our drinks.  

Maybe we caught her on a bad day, but im definitely not coming back for awhile.

Food was great, but the experience was pretty poor..
author: One L.

description:
Ordered a very small plate of tempura and two bowls of ramen.  Waited for 30 the tempura and 45 for the ramen.  It was not worth the wait.  No one checked up on us.  The restaurant was not full.  It was dinner time and there were a lot of to go orders.  But when you have people actually sit in your restaurant, its just good business to serve those people on time.  

The ramen was barely hot and not flavorful.  And the tempura was slightly soggy.  Would not go there again.  They get two stars for serving us.  But we did almost leave.  We only stayed because the server said they were pouring the broth.  The bill was almost $30.  I finished the bowl of ramen in 5 mins.  I usually eat fast.  But the bowl was small.  45 min wait to eat for 5 minutes.  Not worth it.
author: Victor H.

description:
I came here with some friends pretty late on a Thursday night. It was nearing their closing time but they were very patient with us and provided excellent service. We had a round or two of hot sake and beer, some sushi, and entrees. 

For sushi, we kept it simple with the spicy tuna and unagi rolls. They were okay but I probably would not go for them again.

I had the shrimp curry as my main meal and it was delicious. I love Japanese curry and this place nails the rich flavors. The shrimp was "double fried" and they were perfectly crispy and not greasy or oily. I tried the garlic ramen and it is good as well. Although I was not as fond of the strong garlic flavor, I can appreciate it for those who prefer that taste.

My suggestion would be to stick to the entrees as everyone at our table loved their meals. I also enjoyed the small but homey feel to the restaurant. Good food and great service together make the experience just right.
author: Brittany L.

description:
Best ramen I have ever had. At first I was taken back by the small restaurant, the drive, as well as the visible bullet shot in the glass door, but by the end of dinner I knew I would have regretted if we had eaten somewhere else.

We got:

1) Spicy Miso Ramen (chicken broth)- Yum.
2) Tonkatsu Garlic  Miso Ramen (pork broth)- Too creamy for my liking, but still good. 
3) Spicy Tuna Hand Roll-  Really good. The spicy tuna is cut into pieces as opposed to finely chopped and comes with seasoned wakame inside the roll, adding extra tinge of flavor that perfectly complements the spiciness.

Tips:
- Call ahead of time if you have a larger party. This is a tiny restaurant with about 10 tables.
author: Sylvia Y.

description: Very good ramen though the broth is a tad salty (which I didn't mind since I like salty). The broth is rich and creamy, like a home made bone broth.
