I ordered the pork with miso and garlic broth and it was super garlicky which I loved. The next day I finished my daughter's chicken shoyu ramen and enjoyed the leftovers. We will be back for more.
author: Marica C.

description: Good sushi and good ramen, they are very authentic.. The only thing is that, they are too small, they hold no more than 15 customers, that's probably 5 groups.
author: Evan Z.

description: I've been on a crazy ramen kick the last couple of years and have been trying to find a place that  fills that ramen void in my tummy and I've found it!  The best ramen in town.  Spicy tonkatsu - YUM. The broth is rich, without being greasy, and the noodles are the perfect texture.
author: Heather G.

description:
TL:DR; Solid ramen! Small place, average cost. Should be at least a 3.5

The ramen is good, a much better  broth than most places you'll stumble into. They also have several Japanese curries, but I didn't try them.

WHAT I ATE
Garlic tonkatsu ramen with extra garlic and pork belly. Each bowl of ramen was $9 + $3 for the pork belly. 

AMBIANCE
Small place, crams several tables, nothing fancy, focus on the food! 

COME AGAIN VALUE
If I'm in the area, yes, definitely. Good ramen is something to cherish

However, across the street a Pho place was packed, while Miki was kinda dead (6pm on a Saturday). So if I am back in the area, it's likely I would try the pho place. There was also a line out the door for the dessert spot across the street from Miki.

WHAT I WOULD DO DIFFERENTLY NEXT TIME
order double egg in my ramen. One egg = not enough!
author: Shawn S.

description:
Very good ramen (shoyu garlic). Delicious egg with oozing yolk. Broth was complex, flavorful and well-balanced (i had to empty the bowl). Broth was on par with or better than Katana-ya.  Noodles were elastic and perfectly cooked (reminded me of Tokyo). Only negative was the chashu which weren't tender.

Karaage wings were fried perfectly (crisp-out, freshness-in) lovely with a touch of lemon.

Hamachi Nigiri small but fresh-tasting.
author: M Y.

description: Best ramen place ever hands down. I've been here about four times now! It's delicious. I always leave with a warm garlicky breath. I always order the same, tonkatsu garlic miso ramen with nitamago. The eggs are the best! I love soft boiled eggs. However, something was different today when I walked in. The menus are new! The catch is that everything on the ramen menu was more expensive. A dollar more to everything. The extra egg was 1.50 instead of just 1 dollar and the ramen was 9.25 instead of 8:50 or so. I continued to order my ramen anyway. However, when I got my order, there was less soup than there usually was. Leaving me somewhat disappointed since I had to eat just noodles for the first few bites so I wouldn't run out of soup for the end. Overall tasted the same, just kinda sad about the soup and how prices were raised. But I will be glad to help a small business open! :)
author: Joyce M.

description: God! I've tried ramen before but never in my wildest dreams would I have guessed that I would stumble upon this gem! This is hands down the best tasting ramen I've had in a long time! I ordered the Spicy Garlic pork ramen with corn and pork belly added...needless to say my mind is fully blown and my stomach, full.
author: Barney S.

description:
I pass this place all the time when going to the dumpling place.

 So one day, I decided to take the plunge and came with a friend to grab some food. We got the agedashi tofu, curry katsu, and the grilled salmon. 

The food service was slow since its a small kitchen and fills up fast after 7. Overall, everything was good and would come back here again.
author: B H.

description: Excellent ramen and teriyaki. Took a long time. Bring a book :) but I felt like I was in Tokyo. My wife loved the noodles.
author: Adam B.

description: This is a nice authentic place with just some down to earth good Japanese food.  I usually don't trust that many places in SF..  But Miki fills the fix well...
author: Edgar C.

description:
Totally drove by this place! The only sign they have with their name is the blue curtain thing out front with the tiny "MIKI" print on it.

Been wanting to try this spot out for so long and finally got the chance.  

We ordered:
Miso Ramen $8.50 with corn $1.00
Chicken teriyaki and Tonkatsu bento $12
Dragon Roll $5 
Orange Roll $5 (salmon, avocado, cali roll)

Ramen was amazingly good! It even came with half an egg and the yolk was still runny! So good! Came also with cha-su, seaweed, green onions, etc. The ramen itself was pretty good. I wonder if it's freshly made or package though. Only complaint is for $8.50, I would expect at least maybe two pieces of cha-su..

Chicken teriyaki and tonkatsu was really moist and flavorful, not dry at all! The breading on the tonkatsu didn't fall apart like some other restaurants, plus!

Dragon roll and orange roll, both $5, came with 4 pieces, huge pieces, each. All the tables that were eating there, all had an order of the Orange Roll also. Good choice. The salmon was fresh and slices of salmon were perfect size. They definitely do not skimp on there fish. Both were delicious.

The restaurant itself isn't the biggest. Looks like it seats about 20 or even less. The service was amazing. Super friendly even though the food takes a little longer then others, it's worth it.
author: Juliane N.

description:
3.5 Stars

This review is strictly for their ramen; I have not tried anything else here.

It was yet another cold wintery day in SF and I was craving another bowl of ramen. I didn't want Katana-ya; it was too far and too pricy. I didn't want Santa Ramen or Ramen Dojo, again because they're too far. Thus I turned to yelp and searched ramen and lo and behold Miki poped up. And I'm glad it did.

Initially I was terrified; I perused the menu and I saw no mention of ramen! Note to everyone, their ramen offerings are posted on the wall! I chose the spicy miso. 

The broth was GOOD. It was thick, thoroughly flavorful, full bodied. It coated the mouth and brought me happiness. Unfortunately the same could not be said for the noodles, which is half the bowl. The noodles were disappointingly mediocre. They lacked the chewiness and and firmness ramen noodles should have and they simply did not match the quality of the broth. The egg was delectable and creamy, possibly one of the best ramen eggs I've ever had. but it was cold. 

If Miki can bring up the quality of the noodles, this would almost certainly be a 5 star joint. The broth is incredible and the location is great, not forcing me to go downtown or out of they city just for lunch. The egg really helps add to the quality of the bowl too; however the noodles detract from it. I will definitely be returning to miki just to satisfy my ramen cravings but the noodles make it a slightly bittersweet return.
author: Chris D.

description: I ordered the tonkosu Miso Ramen and it was delicious. My boyfriend ordered the spicy miso tonkuso ramen and he liked how its actually spicy when most other places don't have it as spicy. I don't normally drink the soup in ramen, but in this case I couldn't resist because it was so good. Hands down one of my favorite ramen places.
author: Susan K.

description: Went here for ramen because I was craving it so bad on a cold day in sf. Went here due to positive yelp reviews. Place is pretty small so it's not good for groups of more than 4. Place is decent at best. The broth is thick and looked like they never strained the it. There was floating pieces floating within the broth itself that was kind of overwhelming. I also ordered the dragon and it didn't taste very fresh. Wouldn't be worth the wait if there is a line.
author: Mike T.

description:
This place is good enough that it's worth driving across the city (from SOMA/Portrero) then freezing your butt off while you wait outside for 40 min before you can eat here.  

And I didn't even have the extra garlic ramen (which I will get next time for sure).  

In addition to the ramen being very good (and the broth excellent), the sides my friends got (sushi, maguro natto) also looked pretty amazing.  

Only thing that prevents this from being 5 stars for me is that the food was a little slow to come out.  Still I'd definitely come back.
author: Elaine S.

description: I've had a hard time finding pork katsudon in general and an even harder time finding *good* pork katsudon in SF.  Love theirs here!  Also love their sushi.  I have a shellfish allergy and always ask them to wipe the knife and cutting surface.  So far I have not had any issues with contact allergens.
author: Sharon E.

description: I will never come back to this restaurant, 30 mins wait for the food,the spicy ramen noodle is super salty ,I would not recommend this place to eat,there is many better choices
author: Cindy S.

description:
I really wanted to like this place as I love to search for hidden jems in the neighborhood.  Sure enough, the outside footprint was no longer than froyo spot.
Prices were not bad, but portions could be better.
Not the best, but not the worst.
author: Frank C.

description:
Miki Restaurant is one of those places that is located in literally NOWHERE....literally the outer richmond district is one of those places in SF where you really don't see anything there. Plus, one of the reason why the place is not so popular is probably due to the small size of the restaurant. For some people, it might look sketchy. 

HOWEVER, do not let this fool you. The Tonkatsu Miso Extra Garlic Ramen is superb! The broth of the soup and the egg is rich in flavor, order it you're not gonna regret it at all, its so good, the texture of the egg noddle is great too....We also ordered the special black cod with this miso sauce.....HMMMM yummm def makes my heart melt when i ate the black cod. OH you should also get the onion cream croquette, its so good(especially for all you creamy lovers). 

When we came here, it was pretty empty so the service is really good, my water is always filled and the waiter seems nice. Overall, i was satisfied with this place, lesson learned....dont be fooled by the outer appearance of a restaurant!
author: Cavin T.

description:
Tried and true.  Came back for a second round and left with a smile.  And garlicky breath.   Let's cut to the chase and get to what you're really here to find out:

- THERE IS A WAIT. Go with people you don't mind being with during the 40 minute wait, or else things could get awkward.  Unsuspecting newcomers might be agitated by the agonizing wait after ordering, so HEED MY WARNING, and only go if you've got the time.  If it's any consolation, the food is fresh, and it seems they run out of things here and there - my guess is probably because they don't use those made-to-last-forever preserved ingredients. 

Their ramen has shot up to the top of my list for ramen in the Bay Area.  I'm not crazy - I think it's safe to say I've been around the ramen block many times to compare and contrast and know what's good.

I got the Tonkatsu Garlic Shoyu ramen. AGAIN.  This never fails to satisfy since the garlic dominates the Shoyu broth.  If you want subtle, go for the Miso, it's a good balance.  I will be back for you on Thursday!

$$ Heads up if you don't carry cash -  Lunch is cash only, but dinner they take card.
author: michelle f.

description:
Tucked away on Balboa, this tiny establishment delivers some great tasting Japanese food. Came here on a whim with some friends. Small but cozy place.

Ordered the Fried Chicken - Karaage. Nice and juicy on the inside and plenty crispy on the outside. Perfect. 

Ordered the Spicy Tonkatsu Miso Ramen w/ extra egg. A little bit on the salty side, but the spiciness was just right. Wished they added more pork belly though, but overall enjoyed it very much. 

Price-wise it's pretty average so I'd come here again to try the other kinds of ramen that they serve.
author: Killah K.

description:
1 cook, 1 server, 24 seats... Not a good ratio for timely service.

If you don't get seated immediately-don't fret, the wait isn't too bad . Or perhaps my one time visit isn't really enough to judge. My from my corner seat by the window I saw a single guy sitting at a four-table top offer two strangers seats at his table. Cheers to communal seating to pack the restaurant, especially when it's ridiculously cold outside!

I ordered the Tonkatsu Spicy Miso Ramen and was pleasantly surprised with the bold flavorful broth. Usually when I order spicy ramen the broth  is either too spicy or not spicy enough, or it's too salty and tastes like Shin Ramyun (yenno... that Korean noodle in a bag). This broth was well beyond my expectations with a rich orange color and little fat blobs floating around the rim. As you eat the spiciness builds but doesn't overpower the pork base. The black pepper on top of my bamboo was completely unnecessary.  The noodles needed some work, the first bite was already a little too gummy for my taste - a sign that they'd been boiled for a minute too long. By the time I was half way through the bowl the noodles were fat and soggy. 

I'd have no problem coming back when I'm in the area again, maybe I'll try the Tonkatsu Shoyu or Tonkatsu Garlic next. I wonder... would they let me order my noodles firm? With a little patience and a little instruction I can easily like this place.
author: Meuy S.

description:
I like it! It's a small restaurant, probably family owned and operated (at least I'd like to believe so, next time I'll ask). In fact, it's so small that I'm having second thoughts about posting this review in fear of this place becoming too popular... but they earned it. 

No particular dish is a must-try, but overall, the dishes are tasty. They have a large variety of nigiri, dinners, soups (including hot soba noodles, which are kinda hard to find) and a smaller than average selection of sushi rolls... but like I said, everything I tried was good. My only comment is that their crab salad is a little mayo-flavor heavy, so if mayo is not your thing, stay away from california roll and similar (eg rainbow roll).
author: Eugene M.

description: The food was very tasty, but the portions seemed small. I think my American appetite fails me here. I got the full chicken teriyaki portion, and it was more like a half. I agree with some of the other patrons with the slow service. It was about half an hour or so just for water, and then at least ANOTHER half hour to ever get food. I am guessing they don't have enough workers and are busy? Friendly service, just not very speedy or attentive. From waiting for so long for drinks and food, I was now in a hurry by the end of my meal, I eventually got up and had to go to the register to get checked out. Mmm, I don't know if I would go back. Good food, but I think I can find better service elsewhere.
author: Elisa M.

description: Across from the land of boba drinks and Purple Kow popularity lay a quaint Japanese restaurant. The lunch plates are good. The people are friendly. And it's a cozy little place where you can actually have some good conversations with friends. It happened to be two accidental visits, but we all ended up as happy customers. The portions weren't large and the prices are decent. I would definitely drop by if I'm ever in the Richmond-Balboa area again. A tonkatsu lunch at Miki, then a green matcha tea with grass jelly at Purple Kow across the street.
author: Angie K.

description:
after having my first experience looking at cars and trying to sell your car to the dealers, boy is it tiring.

hungry and not sure where to go around 8pm, craved Japanese food, tani's kitchen was closed NO! so i was yelping and thought of this place, heard it was good, a bit far out there, but away we go!

luckily scored a parking on the same block, was suppose to be a 20 min wait, but got seated in 5-10! Score! Place is tiny and already I felt the service was a bit slow....food came out really slow too.....

We ordered!

Chicken Katsu Kaarage Curry- pretty good, curry tastes generic to me but the chicken was yummy, perfectly fried and enough meat to not feel jipped!

Chirashi bowl- unagi was super nice and crispy, salmon was fresh, pretty filling

sukiyaki- was craving noodles and soup, didn't get ramen! I know shame on me! it was a bit too sweet for me but pretty delicious with rice. nice big slices of beef and tofu and egg, and mushroom things. MMMM

Overall super full, left happy, total was $45? Kinda pricey but good. would come back to try the ramen!

oh and the waitress is really japanese! since I saw her write my name down in katakana. haha
author: Christine M.

description:
I ordered the salmon kazuki (sp?) it was on the special dinner board. When I got the dish the salmon felt hard and semi petrified. The taste of the salmon was bitter and some what rancid tasting.  It came with a side of potato salad.  The fish tasted strange and I asked my friend to taste it to confirm it just wasn't me. She confirmed the 'off' taste it had.  I mentioned this to the server, he took the dish back to the kitchen, a few minutes later returned with my dish and said 'the cook tasted the fish and that's the way it's supposed to be".  He then returns my plate with the same salmon (which the cook ate), back in front of me- completely unapologetic.  Then I sat and was glum because I had nothing to eat and my friend had a tasty bowl of ramen (which I wished I had ordered).

When I complained one more time the waiter told me that the chef would allow me to order something different. By this time I was too upset at the bad initial customer service I declined and just ate my bowl of rice.

At the end they didn't charge me for my petrified salmon, but why weren't they nicer about the whole thing at the start, and did they really expect me to eat salmon which their cook tucked in to?
author: Spoon G.

description:
I see all the ravings about the ramen here, but I actually have never tried it... I come here for the Yukkedon! It's like a chirashi bowl, but better. You can one or two types of fish (sashimi), and it comes in a bowl over sushi rice, wakame salad, some sweet little tofu strip pieces, and you can add an egg on top to mix it up with everything. It's kind of like a japanese version of korean's bibimbap, but with sashimi. 

My friend got a bowl of ramen here before, and didn't like it. I tried the broth and it tasted like straight fish. Like I was licking a fish fresh out of the water. Maybe I'll have to try the garlic ramen next time! BUT the tuna yukkedon is a must try.

The place is tiny, but they take reservations too. I usually go really early for dinner, or make a reservation before I go because there tends to be a line, and service is REALLY slow. Usually only one person serving. They also have a board of little appetizer specials, but they always seem to be out. Next time I'll have to go earlier to try them out.
author: Jaime H.

description:
Super slow service but amazing garlic ramen. 

Better to call ahead and get take out.
author: Melissa T.

description:
FINALLY! A decent place for ramen in San Francisco and it was right under my nose this whole time! My friends and I go to the Shanghai Dumpling place a few doors down all the time and never thought to look at the Japanese place. But one rainy day, craving ramen, I begin yelping and Miki's shows up. Better than driving to Santa Clara, we figured we might as well give this place a try and head over for lunch. 
Ramen prices are decent and my friend was delighted to see you can add pork belly for $3 I believe. 

I got the Tonkotsu Garlic Miso Ramen. Great garlic flavor but the miso wasn't as strong as I would have preferred it, but it was good none the less. The egg was prefect. Hard to find a place that can actually boil an egg correctly and Miki's gets it right. I wasn't a big fan of the pork, it was a little dry for my taste.

Totally would come back for ramen. I went at lunch right when they opened on a weekday so I had no problems with them running out of ramen.
author: Lang T.

description:
This place is such a gem!  

Miki restaurant is an authentic and family run Japanese restaurant that serves great food at a reasonable price.  They have a very extensive menu, including ramen, sushi, bento boxes, rice dons, and sashimi.  It feels very authentic and I think honestly, it's the little things that make this restaurant truly a great find.

Their bento boxes are great, very hearty and reasonable prices.  The sashimi is fresh and they put some sort of sesame seasoning in their sushi that gives it a great flavor.  

I've also had their zuru cold noodles.  Delish! And very reasonable prices.  Their tempura is also crispy and flavorful. 

Service is a bit slow, their restaurant is really tiny. 

It gets pretty crowded on weekends so get here early!
author: Katie L.

description:
i love the ramen here!

the broth is thick and full of flavor. i love adding corn and pork belly to my tonkatsu spicy miso ramen. the pork belly is really tasty and tender. i never tried a chicken based broth before but they have that option here too, along with a lot of different types for both chicken and pork based broths.

i like the croquettes here as well. its a good thing to munch on while waiting for your ramen. between the curry one and the onion and cream one, i like the onion one more.

service is a little slow here but in their defense it is a super small place with just 1-2 cooks at most.  ramen dojo is still probably the best ramen ive had in the area but miki comes pretty close. you can make reservations here so no need to wait almost an hour for just a bowl of ramen!
author: Katherine C.

description:
OMG YUM.

Came here with 3 friends for dinner pretty early (~5:30pm) to beat the rush, and luckily for us, we were one of the few people there! wooop

I'd like to quote my friend who says "the sushi melts in your mouth!!" lol pretty good prices for sushi rolls, and we ordered two kinds. 

I ordered the Tonkatsu (pork broth) Spicy Miso Ramen with garlic ($8.50ish an additional .50) I laaaaahvvved this. The soup is thick with good consistency, and the garlic made it taste even better. AND THE RAMEN--nomz all around. My stomach left happy and more than satisfied. 

ps, happy hour from 5-7pm! 
med/lrg beer $3
small $2
author: Victoria N.

description: Hidden gem in the outer Richmond!  Been here a few times for lunch and their ramen is kickin' it!!  Must try if you are in the neighborhood.  I have yet to have dinner here so this review is for their ramen during lunch hours.  This place is small and every time I came here...I had no wait.
author: Patrick C.

description:
Wow I can't believe it has been over a year that I have been going here, it seems like it has been longer. I figured that it was time for me to write a update :). Miki's is really close by to my workplace and when i want Japanese food its Miki's or Yu Zen. The only thing to me that is not so cool is during lunch time it is cash only! :(    why?  I don't understand. I usually don't carry a lot of cash on me.   

I came for lunch today with my co-worker and buddy because we were craving Japanese food.  I was greeted by the waiter and the soothing voice of Hikaru Utada song  Traveling. Ah  Japanese food and good Utada music  what else can i ask for :). Some new additions for people that have never been here is they have curry and they have had ramen for a while now!!   Be warned tho, they can run out since both are yummy!  I have and will come back for more food here!!
author: Jonathan W.

description:
A teeny tiny place that'll seduce your taste buds at first bite.

I've spent the past 3 years bitching about how whack ramen in the Bay Area is compared to NYC, and I've finally found a place in SF that made me shut up.

Like other reviewers have mentioned, Miki is simple and homey, and not a place where you'd want to eat if you're in a hurry. 

Once he finished in the kitchen, the chef (and I'm assuming owner) came out with a beer and just chilled like a boss. He visited all of our tables to chit chat and ask how our meal was.

Even though I wasn't terribly hungry to begin with, I ate every last bite of my ramen and nearly had to crawl out because I was so full.
author: Lesley C.

description:
I think the kitchen staff are related to the Slowky turtles because man, this place is ssssssslllllllllllllloooooooooowwwwwww. As in, more than 20 minutes just to get water and nearly an hour to get our food slow. We didn't realize our hot pots came with a salad and my bf ordered a side salad, so he got both salads (rather than the waitress saying, you also have a salad that comes with this). I ordered the Chawan Mushi as an appetizer and never received it. When we finally got our dinners I told her just to cancel the order, but she said they were already making it. By "making it" she meant that it was in the microwave, which we then heard beep. The custard was a bit watery for my taste. I don't remember having this in Japan so I'm not sure if it's supposed to be that way, though. 

The rest of the food: meh. It wasn't bad, but it certainly wasn't worth waiting an hour for! I will most definitely NOT be back here, especially with so many other options within just a few blocks.
author: Amy B.

description: Tonkatsu Ramen + pork belly. Way too salty. I'm sad.
author: Jackson P.

description:
this place is a hidden gem! i've gone to purple kow many times and never noticed this place until recently.  i'm so glad i came here for lunch!  small ramen shop with delicious broth!  love the thick noodles and the charshu was soft, yum!  :)

ordred:
tonkotsu shio ramen
spicy miso ramen with extra charshu

i was quite surprise and happy that the spicy miso ramen did not have spicy oils like other spicy ramen broths i have had.  i honestly dislike spicy ramen that have the spicy oils, makes me feel like the broth is not integrated with the spicy sauce.  shio ramen's broth is flavorful and my favorite.  

they offer 3 different broths, chicken, pork and vegetarian.  so that's nice for those who don't eat pork or meat.
author: mea f.

description:
Had a sudden HUGE craving for ramen, and didn't know of a real good place in SF since I normally go to the ones in San Mateo, but I found Miki on yelp, and yes, it does live up to the 4 stars that people have given it! 

My friend and I had the Spicy tonkotsu ramen. IT WAS DELICIOUS. 
Had the perfect amount of spice. The kind that doesnt murder your taste buds temporarily, and it wasnt not enough that you can barely feel the bang. The spiciness +the goodness of the broth = happy mouth. The noodles were good ramen noodles. Not too soft, nor hard. The broth was nice and hot when the bowl came out. I really dont like it when the broth isnt HOT, but Miki has hot broth. Yay! 
I dont know if the little white globs in the broth were fat, but I'm pretty sure they were. I was pretty disgusted by the sight of it once it came to the table, but MAN, it made the whole bowl SUPER GOOOD!! so, forget about dieting or picking out the fat in this case, just eat it and run an extra mile because it is worth it!!! 

We also had the spider roll and that was pretty good too. The soft shell crab was nice and crispy, not soggy at all, and the flavor was just enough. 

The service was pretty slow, but it was only one guy serving the entire small restaurant. I needed water at one point and it took a bit of time to catch his attention. But other than that, I'm not gonna knock off a star just because I know how he feels serving a bunch of people at once and the FOOD def deserves a 5 star. 

(however, I didnt try the bento boxes nor anything else. So my review is for the ramen!) 

Will definitely come back when I crave again and happen to be in the area! (:
author: Sharon L.

description:
Hmm.. I like this restaurant, but of course I came here and sake'd it up with the girlfriend so my review may be a result of bein a lil tipsy. 1 shot, 2 shot, 3 shot and some sapporo.. ahh it feels good havin sake downed the gullet. after succumbing to the effects of watching Naruto Uzumaki gulp down bowls and bowls of ramen, my girlfriend and I decided to come to Miki's to satisfy our ramen cravings. I ordered just a regular bento box, chicken katsu and tempura combo, and my girlfriend ordered the miso pork ramen. 

the chicken katsu was quite flavorful, and i really did enjoy the meat with my rice and 3-piece california roll (tasty roll). However, the tempura, although crispy on the outside, was a bit stale on the inside. I can taste these things, and its the detail that draws the masterpiece. nonetheless, Miki has a balance that many japanese restaurants do not have, and that is the balance between mixture and flavor. It's that feng shui that makes a bunch of insignificants turn into something beautiful. also, Miki portions come nicely, and the chefs inside knows how to make you happy (except for the tempura). 

The ramen, was also really good, full of flavor; however, like many other yelp reviews, I too found it a little.. full of residue, which only means one thing: fat. if you don't mind that minor detail, Miki's ramen is definitely worth a shot, or two, or three and a sapporo.
author: simon k.

description:
After experiencing atrocious service at Ramen Dojo in San Mateo, my friend and I decided to set our sights elsewhere and look for a better restaurant to satisfy our ramen cravings. 

I ordered a bowl of the garlic miso pork broth with corn and it was pretty good. The broth is much thicker than Ramen Dojo's and the pork flavor in the broth was more distinct. The noodles were somewhat chewy, but, closer to the soft side (which I don't mind at all). It also helps to ask for a side of the spicy sauce they add to their soups just to give your ramen a little kick!

The service was decent, being that there was only one server. I didn't catch his name, but he was very polite and helpful (something that you do not come across at Dojo).
author: Juliette R.

description:
My friend and I have been trying to find good ramen places around SF and was recommended to try this. We came here for lunch and I got spicy miso ramen which was pretty delicious. The sauce was very thick and flavorful and I like the spicy kick. The portion was fair and I really liked the egg inside.

However, if you are a healthy eater, this might not be for you because there is oil and fat in the soup base (probably why it is so delicious)
author: Pin X.

description: oh, miki...your so fine...your so fine...you blow my mind...hey miki...hey, hey...hey miki!...haha...it's not that great, but it's not bad either...smorgasbord of japanese bites...quite extensive and relatively lower priced...small japanese "boon-shik"....two guys working in the kitchen and a single girl working the tables...all relatively young and japanese in appearance...little salmon sashimi, salmon roe, orders of uni, a miso fish and more having...miso fish being a smaller portion, but finding to be the favorite...the sashimi acceptable for price...sharing many items...sake and soju by the glass...to sum, a japanese variety dinner without breaking the bank...
author: Hen A.

description:
I'm not sure what it is about small cozy neighborhood restaurants that I like, but this place has me coming back whenever I'm in the Richmond district. 

I've already made 5 visits during the past 3 months even though I live closer to the south bay and what has me coming back is their curry. I have yet to try Muracci's curry so I can't make a comparison to the purported best curry in SF. I have tried Japacurry before and although their curry has better flavoring than Miki, at least I don't need to find the Japacurry truck and I get bigger portions. One thing about Miki's curry is their sauce has bits and pieces of shredded pork which is an excellent touch. The tonkatsu (pork cutlet) curry is what I usually get and it's about $10. If you have a huge appetite, one order may not be enough.

Other highlights are their ramen (which I won't review, there is already so many here) and their sashimi is fresh although choices are limited. I won't bother ordering rolls since there are tons of Japanese roll restaurants littering the Bay Area now to eat at but I'm sure Miki's rolls taste just fine and dandy. I do like their spicy tuna handroll and both their hamachi belly and amaebi have been consistently good. No fried head with the amaebi though :( I overhead on two separate occasions that their omelet dish is really good but I have no idea what it is and will ask the waitress next time and try it.

Honestly this place probably doesn't deserve 4 stars when stacking it up against other more specialized Japanese cuisine restaurants. But, I do consider this place a "jack of all trades" type of restaurant when you are not in a rush and just want to enjoy a nice meal.
author: Andrew L.

description: Ok. Miki you've been a disappointment of late. Changed the menu,skimpy on your portions & the taste I not as authentic. Lots of MSG. blah won't go back. So bad...so sad
author: Luri S.

description: Very home feel restaurant! I wish I get to eat their ramen but it was not available for lunch. I will be back for sure!
author: Aylee G.

description: Noodles were chewier than expected (and I like chewy noodles.) Soup did not have great flavor. The egg was more cooked than I'd like. It wasn't the kind I've had at other ramen places (there is a great one in Las Vegas and if Las Vegas can do it, so can SF.) I hear you're suppose to go to this one spot in Japan Town for real good ramen. Sorry, can't endorse this place. Would have loved to.
author: Vicki T.

description:
3.5
Best ramen in san francisco? Yes but its not saying much. Its a tad better than genki and katanaya due to availability of pork belly and the strong garlic flavor but it does not compare to santa, dojo, or orenchi. Ramen is served at dinner only! Limited seating (~20 seats)

garlic tonkastu miso with pork belly ($8.75+3.00)
strong garlic bit all over the broth. The charsu was slightly above average as it was quite tender. The broth was garlicly but I felt it lacked enough pork flavor compared to santa/dojo/orenchi. The noodles were slighly harder than what I usually like. The pork belly was decent but not as good as santas. $3 gets you 3 small pieces. 

spicy garlic tonkatsu miso ($8.75)
Same as above except with the added spiciness. It tasted as if they added sriracha and hot bean paste/oil. Slightly better compared to the regular garlic tonkatsu. 

Overall I would reluctanly say its the best ramen in sf. Id rather go to santa /dojo/orenchi but if I dont feel like driving that far and want ramen for dinner I would recommend coming here.
author: Robert Y.

description:
Miki's is our go-to place for ramen. Very,very good tonkatsu miso with extra egg topping. The broth is something else. I've tried Ramen Dojo in San Mateo and although Their tonkatsu miso is impressive, Miki's is still my favorite. Miki's is a hole in the wall place staffed by Japanese folks for as long as I've been coming here.  If you come on a weeknight and are very hungry, get the combo with a 3-pc California roll to hold you up. Ramen takes at least 10 mins to come out. And it's so popular it sometimes sells out!

I've been to Miki's 8x for ramen.
author: Sherielyn G.

description: Taroyaki was delicious. One of the best I have ever tasted.  The curry is different from other Japanese restaurants.  There was  shredded beef in the curry.  Tonkatsu ramen was yummy.  So far the tastiest ramen in SF.  Small restaurant and the waiter was very pleasant.  Will return and try other dishes.
author: Elaine L.

description:
Miso garlic chicken broth ramen...WOW. The egg and pork belly were perfectly cooked, and noodles had just enough bite to them. This is my new favorite ramen spot in SF.

I would give this place 5 stars, but the service is tedious.
author: Rich L.

description: when i am craving a hand made ramen noodle and some addicting broth, I go to Miki. my favorite is the spicy miso garlic ramen with add on extras of pork belly and garlic. just a regular small joint....no frills, sometimes a wait even with a few tables filled (i think they have to cook batches of ramen and run out at times) There has been a few times when even seated you can wait up to 15 min to get your bowl. barely ever a wait on the weekdays. closed on mondays so don't forget. people are really nice. also recommend ordering for take out to avoid wait of any sort.
author: Tiger Lily ..

description:
One of my favorite places to eat on the planet. I'm so glad when we're back in our old neighborhood to see this place still in business. It's a tiny hole-in-the-wall and the chef/owner does a great job keeping things both fresh and interesting. For example you can taste that he makes his own broth and keeps things good by keeping them simple. I particularly love the way he does his saba shioyaki. 

It is also a pretty reasonable Japanese restaurant which is saying something. The box combos are a great deal and a consistent favorite of ours. The last time I ordered the udon just because I noticed he had added more soups and noodles to the menu. It was no surprise that this dish was as typically good as most others I've had there. 

If there is anything to complain about it is the fact that service can get a little slow here. To be honest I accepted that pace at most Japanese restaurants a long time ago. Here I would also add the factor that the operation is often run by only a couple of people (like the chef and the one server) so when they even get a slight rush things can get backed up. All I can say to that is relax and enjoy your meal and the company at your table. 

I just hope that this little gem can stay in business. So far so good.
author: David H.

description:
Homestyle Japanese cooking - no frills.

this place is close by to my son's school.  when in the mood for udon - we go here.

My oldest and I usually order the nabeyaki udon.

My middle son orders the tempura udon.

My youngest orders a plain udon.

It's a small place - takes a while to cook because there is 1 guy in the back cooking everything.

Don't look for crazy kinds of rolls here...you won't get it.  They don't serve uni :( but they make up with delicious kaki fry (fried oysters), gyoza, and other delicious things!
author: JJAMZ C.

description:
This is a small Japanese restaurant with a very home-style feel.  There's probably seating for less than 20 people.

The emphasis on the menu are the Japanese noodles (especially ramen), but they have an assortment of donburi and other items also.  I ordered the spicy miso ramen with the chicken-based broth.  At the time I wasn't sure if I had something in that soup base before.  It hit the spot nicely.  That makes this a discovery as being an excellent ramen place on this side of town.  Friendly server also at the time of my visit.

If you come at night, expect to wait for a table due to the size of this place.
author: H K.

description:
Good ramen is few and far in between in SF proper. Miki was great :)

Came here with my picky little brother for his 11th birthday, and the two guys working definitely made it great! Be warned, the restaurant is pretty tiny, so you may have to wait for a table but it's worth it. Sushi was fresh, ramen not too salty. Everything is also REALLY fairly priced for SF, $8-9 for ramen, but then again I'm used to paying NYC prices of $12+ a bowl.

Thank you Miki!! I'll be back before I have to move back to the other side of the country :(.
author: Sandra S.

description:
It's a small and homey restaurant. Great for family and couple friends to hang out. 

The food are really good. I would say they have the best Japanese food with $$ in town. Check out their special on the wall. They always come out some new menu which are always good to try. 

The service could be little slow some times because there is only one guy in kitchen.
author: Roger L.

description:
4.5 stars rounded up

My dinner guest and I arrived early to avoid the dinner rush (around 6:30pm). I say this because when we were done with our meal, the restaurant filled with dinner patrons!

Tip: this place looks hidden! It is located right across from PurpleKow and right next to Shanghai dumpling house. 

We ordered the spider roll, tonkatsu-based spicy miso ramen and chicken-based garlic miso ramen. The soft shell crab was still hot and crunchy crunchy when we ate it...which only means that it was freshly fried! The spider roll wasn't anything special though...I wish there was more content in it. But I know Miki is not known for sushi...

The ramen broth had hella flavor! There was no need for any extra condiments. It was a good ramen to soup ratio. My gripe is that there was only one slice of pork. I know you can add more toppings but $1.50 for a bit more pork???? I can buy more than that for some cha siu at a Chinese deli.
author: Jay Z.

description:
I was craving a hot bowl of ramen on a cold day. So excited that I found this place!

It's really really small and doesn't have a big sign, so it can be a bit difficult to find since it's squished in the middle of the shopping area.

Food was great - I had the garlic miso ramen. I LOVE garlic, but this ramen had almost too much garlic, for my taste. Aside from that, the broth was superb - hot and flavorful. Liked the bamboo shoots in the soup as well, haven't seen that at every ramen place. 

Also, the service was super slow.  I felt really bad for the waitress, as the restaurant was full and she was the only one working outside the kitchen. 

Overall: great, cute place for ramen if you are ok with a long wait. and make sure you have a breath mint if you get the garlic miso :)
author: Sara M.

description:
The best Udon i've had so far in San Francisco, broth, noodles, all top notch.

Prices were very reasonable for a Japanese restaurant, service was attentive though the food came out a tad slow.  All my buddies remarked how the quality of the food was good.
author: Ben S.

description:
Sushi and curry here are kinda crap.

I think tempora was decent if i remember right.   Soupish dishes are probobly ok.
author: Michael E.

description:
One of the best ramen ever! I really did enjoy the thickness of the soup.
Sushi roll was not the greatest and didn't taste anything special but the sashimi was fresh.

The place was small and got crowded really fast. Since it was only 1 lady who was serving everyone, cleaning the tables and on the phone taking to-go orders... the service was pretty slow. No water or tea refills actually we had to ask 3 times to get the water and we didn't even get our tea. The price was reasonable and the portion was ok, I wished it was bigger. 

Will I go again? Yes - I will go right when they are open and only for ramen!
author: Nokie N.

description:
Definitely one of my FAVORITE Japanese restaurants in the Outer Richmond District.  The owner is the chef there so the food is consistently delicious.  It's quite tiny so it's definitely better for smaller parties.  

My Favs:

-Spiny Tuna Crunch roll.  Never tasted anything similar in other restaurants.  
-Ramens
-Curries

Cons:

-Place is really small and since there is only one chef, the food takes quite awhile.  Not a good place to eat when you're in a hurry.
-The service depends on the waiter of the day.  Many turnovers so the service varies.
author: Esther K.

description: Terrible service. wobbly table tops. Very inconsistent, hit or miss, very slow service only about 8 tables most of the time takes over 35 minutes. Luke warm tea. I thought this place would be good because actual japanese americans are running the place. First time I went here it was good, the 2nd 3rd 4th and last time I will go was pretty upsetting
author: Max m.

description: Hole in the wall for sure and a pretty darn good one!  A traditional Japanese restaurant, not the common Chinese own Japanese restaurant.  Has pretty much everything on the menu from sushi to bento box to ramen and Sapporo draft beer!  I come usually for the ramen and its the best thus far in San Francisco.  The noodle and broth quality is superb!
author: Def J.

description:
Loved the tonkatsu garlic ramen!!  The extra pork belly was really good, but honestly it doesn't need it.  The soup is very good, but the consistency of the ramen is what makes it awesome.  

The curry croquette were also really good.  The soft shell crab was fried pretty well and good due to the sauce.  Fried oysters were not bad.
author: j k.

description:
Went here the other day looking for some good ramen and based on the Yelp reviews I figured this place was worth a shot.

I had the Garlic Shoyu Ramen w/stewed pork.  It was lacking in depth and was bland.  The egg noodles were not good at all (super curly, eggy, and just barely better than instant ramen noodles).  The chasu was bland and stewed pork was much the same.  I didn't really enjoy my Ramen much at all.

My wife had the Garlic Miso Ramen and it was the same story. 

In addition the the Ramen, we also ordered the Agedashi tofu and Fried Chicken wings.  The Agedashi was OK.  The fried chicken wings were OK too but Accent (MSG) was CLEARLY sprinkled on top.

I rank this place on the same level as Spirals in San Bruno and Ramen Club in Burlingame.  I don't go to either place much...not even for a quick fix.  Miki is 2 levels down from Himawari in San Mateo.

We didn't get a chance to try the other food there so I can't comment on anything else.  I will say, however,  that the waitress was friendly so that is a plus.  My friend tells me that the other food is OK, so I wouldn't mind coming back at some point.  I'd just stay away from the ramen.
author: ray r.

description:
I was surprised that there was no line when my friends and I met up here. Here is why.

Food:
I am no longer a fan. The ramen used to be so tasty. Now the noodle soup is just bland (even for the spicy ramen). What? The spicy ramen wasn't even spicy. I LOVED the ways their eggs were made in the past but now it just tastes gross. It's texture, flavor, and size was unacceptable. How can you charge more when quality reduced (by so much)?! It was $3 for three pork belly pieces. That comes to about $1/pork belly. Can you say expensive much? My friend was suckered to adding that to his ramen and he said it was not good. 

Service:
The server wasn't really attentive. Took her forever to ask us what we wanted to drink after we were seated for a long while. If I was thirsty, I would have been dead from thirst...like a fish on dry land. 

I would not recommend coming here.
author: Forest T.

description:
I tried this place maybe a year and half ago to have some of the sushi, donburi, izakaya dishes, custom created entrees, and the ramen.  Most of the stuff i would say was good, but the ramen back then was forgettable.  almost like the broth was canned or instant and the noodles were skinny.

Flash forward to the present, and WOW.  Major night and day on the ramen.  the other stuff are still good and with good variety, but the ramen... wow.  They have a hand written sign on the wall where the ramen are to say it's all handmade.  Not sure if it applies to the noodle, soup, or both...but honestly does it matter when it taste good.  The noodles are now fatter with a good texture.  And the broth... it's comparable to some of the best Tongotsu broth I had.  Becareful as it's on the thick side.   It's not your creamy and smooth broth, but more like ramen halu in SJ... where its reduced and thick and rich. Maybe mine was thick because I the tongotsu miso flavor, they also had the tongotsu shoyu, and tongotsu garlic... which i'll try next time on my trip here and maybe those are not as thick... but I definitely like it.  The chashu was soft and melts you in mouth too.

Before i would say come here for anything but the ramen... now i will say don't miss their ramen.  Way better than katanaya and santa ramen.

Word of warning...try to get the tables near the door and not to the back where the kitchen is...it gets hot back there.  Service may be slow, but be kind to the single server..  It's a small place and tight.  This place is truly a hole in the wall..But this place is worth a visit as there's so much variety and taste great... my kind of place.
author: Vien C.

description:
I must have walked past this place a million times thinking it was shut down. However, I yelped ramen and this place was one of the top choices that came up! I came here for lunch excited to try the ramen. The menu I was given didn't even have ramen listed, so I asked the waiter if they still offered ramen here. He came back with another menu and I was slightly annoyed that I almost missed an opportunity to try it had I not asked. 

I looked over the ramen and most were priced at $8.50 or more, which I thought was pricey for ramen. Not wanting to risk it, I decided to just go with the salmon rice plate for $6.95. Lots of their lunch items are very cheap. For the two item rice plates, I believe it is $7.50 and the single ones were about $6-$6.95 range. My boyfriend got the curry katsu rice plate. It included a salad a miso soup. I was surprised by the miso soup because it wasn't heavy with MSG as I've tasted in other places. Our food came out within fairly reasonable time. My salmon was delicious! It was a big portion, too. I sampled my boyfriend's curry and it was tasty and very complimenting to the katsu. 

However, I got confused when it came time to pay because the menu says cash only, but I saw a sticker of the Visa / Master card and yelp also listed that they accepted cash. Decided not to ask and just paid cash. 

Overall, I liked the food but I'm not quite sure I love it, even though it's really convenient location wise. I might just have to try something else on the menu next time.
author: Connie C.

description:
Yo Yelpers, this is a good ramen joint!

This place is a small but cozy restaurant that seats a lil' over 20 hungry people.  One waitress is running the front while two cooks are in the back, manning the kitchen.  Patience is a virtue and this will hold true here at Miki's.

For forty bucks, me and the GF ordered:
-Large hot sake - It's a Friday night so Cheers! Salud!
-Agadashi tofu - Standard appetizer that was not spectacular or bad
-Grilled scallops - These things were anorexic!  They were the size of a nickel.  
-2 tonkatsu spicy miso ramens - The broth was the money maker here.  It was a tad creamy and thick, and very rich in flavor.  The noodles were good and the pork was nice and tender.  It did not really taste spicy though so don't worry about it being too spicy!

I'm so glad that I have been able to find some great ramen joints in the city such as Miki's.  For the longest time, I thought they did not exist due to some mediocre experiences.  I'm ready to find some more!
author: Suzi K.

description:
Okay, so this is my first review and it's a good start so far. My bf and I went here for lunch today on his lunch break but apparently their lunch menu is cash only! I only had $5 in my wallet... oh well. Paid the $3 fee on the BofA atm and ate. During the dinner time they accept the plastics... sigh. 

This hole in the wall place is a pretty good place for good japanese food. definitely better than the one up the block next to American Grill. I had the Miso Ramen and my bf had the Chicken Katsu Don. Very yummy! I didn't even have to add the spices or chili oil since they were both mixed in the broth which was very, very tasty (seeing that I'm a spicy food fanatic :D). I had a bite of the Chicken Katsu and it burst of even flavors without even drowning the chicken in sauce. We enjoyed our meal under good J-Pop songs and the waitress was patient with us. It was pretty empty in the there so service was pretty good.
author: Marie G.

description:
Can I say this restaurant is real Japanese restaurant!!
Looks not clean,building is old so small.this's not for big party.but they have authentic Japanese food and chef who've experienced.
There are many simplified and strange Japanese foods lately,however their foods are
followed Japan.
If you're not interested in Japanese food or not have time,I don't recommend here.because chef's cooking everything alone and instructing his coworkers on the business.
We're accustoming to eat mixed food probably..Maybe you've been some restaurants that was nasty including services,so you could overlook their small mistake if you tasted their foods..

I will come here again!!
author: S V.

description:
I finally checked out this place for dinner on a Friday night. It's a good thing we got there early (~6pm), because this small place filled up FAST! I can see why it has such a loyal following though - the food tastes authentic, fresh and tasty! As nobu k. below describes it, I would consider the food as more of a modern, American-Japanese style, than traditional.

I love the fact that they have a fairly extensive specials menu (updated on a whiteboard) with some items in Japanese-only - it tells me that this isn't "yet another Chinese-owned Japanese restaurant" (tm). Plus, it gives me a chance to bust out my leet Japanese skills and feel good about my 1 year of Japanese! Haha.

Anyway, we ordered the Agedashi Tofu (clean and tasty... a welcome break from the thicker sauce that Takara uses), Creamed corn croquette, spicy salmon roll (very nice, fresh fish!), and curry katsu. The curry katsu was pretty good - I liked the breading/frying of the katsu (wasn't too oily), but you only get about 5-6 smallish pieces.

There's only 1 waiter and chef, so expect service to be slow (but polite!). All in all, a good Japanese restaurant that's worth checking out!
author: Steve L.

description:
Great mom and pop place in the outer richmond! 

Pros: Really good fresh fish! I was nicely surprised by that. I would especially recommend the hamachi toro tataki. I've gobbled up many of those along with their kani salad sushi. The price is very reasonable, the portions are moderate, and there's a decent variety of food to choose from. All the deep fried items are hot and crisp when you get them. 

Cons: This are a mom and pop place, so expect service to be a little slow (there's only 1 waitress) and the space to be a little tight. It took anywhere between 15-30 minutes for me to get food after ordering. But the stuff was well worth the wait. 

As for the ramen, i think it's solid. Not really life-altering. For me I would prefer something fattier, oilier, and satlier like Ippudo in manhattan. 

So all in all a great stop for a meal after work or something if you're in the area. Not really a place to drive more than 30 minutes to eat at.
author: Ray J.

description: Garlic base soup with double pork, double  egg, double noodles, Double Bomb!! I so like this place on cold evenings..
author: Rick P.

description:
I hate to give a mom and pop, hole in the wall, restaurant such a low rating...but I can't imagine recommending this place to my friends who are looking for a good Japanese restaurant.

My friend and I came in here because he was craving ramen.  He had the Spicy Tonkatzu Miso ramen and the Futomaki roll.  In case there were any vegetarians out there wondering, they do have non-Tonkatzu flavors - it's just too bad that they were all "OUT."  

I looked up at the bulletin board and saw a good variety of dinner options.  It's too bad that 1/3 of them were also "OUT."  Okay, so I decided to give the tuna katsu a try because after giving up most kinds of meat, I realized it's been years since I've had tonkatsu sauce.

Good thing we had a lot of time allotted for dinner because there was only one server and though there were less than 10 tables, it took a ridiculously long time for the food to come out.  

The tuna katsu portion was really large, but it was a little too tough for my liking.  The futomaki roll (which generally is vegetarian - but this one had some fish in it or bonito?) was wrapped very poorly.

I can't say that I will return.
author: Alvina W.

description: One of my fave Izakaya spots! The cool thing is you get to try a lot of different dishes. The squid is bomb for appetizers. Followed by a mentai omelette cooked to perfection. Cucumber salad is light and refreshing. For the main event, I always order the Beef Soy Sauce butter. And the answer is yes, it tastes as amazing as its name implies. It's like a Japanese version of the filipino dish know was bistek. The quality of steak is quite awesome in my opinion. Along with some green beans and steamed rice, this dish is a hitter for sure. And finally, wrap up the meal with some fried chakin for dessert. I love this place. =)
author: Alvin P.

description:
Recently I was ill and there was only one thing I needed: miso ramen at Miki.

Like manna from heaven, my friends. Like manna.

And for those who complain about how they are often sold out of things; well, I appreciate the fact that Miki only makes as much as they can sell without spoiling the quality of their dishes. If you don't think you can serve me a dish of something as you'd like to serve it, I'm glad you're honest enough to tell me that.

Also, in regard to the waiting issues: what are we, twelve? You can't wait for a delicious and thoughtfully-prepared dish of food? What happened to savoring things and engaging with people over a meal? Isn't that the point of going out? To sit and drink and eat and share time with one another?
author: Marcus L.

description:
tony basil would approve.  

***cue the "whatever happened to baby jane" cheerleaders"***

we came here before for the katsu chicken curry, but i wasn't a fan of the soup like consistency of the curry.  i prefer the heavy, gravy-like curry with chunks of beef and carrots (like at geta in piedmont).  

what i do keep coming back for is the tonkatsu garlic shoyu ramen.  mmmm mmmm good.  i see that people have dissed on the ramen here more than once, but i can't say that there is anything "untasty" about the ramen.  it's creamy, garlic-y, and slurpily delicious.  it's been the perfect match to the odd weather that the bay has been plagued with during the last weeks of may and beginning of june.  

the service is friendly and fast.  and there is never a wait.  i have been here a couple of times, though, and they have run out of the tonkatsu broth.  when i do come here, i usually call ahead to make a reservation, especially when i have 4 or more folks with me.

so yes, contrary to what other yelpers have said about the ramen here, i really do like it.  the minus one star comes from the fact that while the ramen is consistently good, it is not necessarily "blow my mind" good.
author: sharon b.

description: This place was hard to find because they don't have a big sign up in front. They have these curtains that hang in front of the door that have the name on it but just remember its right across from the movie theater. This is definitely a hole in the wall spot for sushi but it was really good. The prices were really cheap for certain rolls. I had a dinner plate and it was about $11.50 and my friend had a bento box which probably was around the same price. Service was a bit slow because they only have one server. Very small place and small tables--noticed they had a sign on the wall that said not to put any electronics on the table because they are not liable for water/food damage to the device. Overall food was good.
author: Jaimie M.

description: Miki is a great hole in the wall restaurant!  While service can sometimes be slow, it's worth the wait for the ramen.  I usually get the garlic tonkatsu miso or the garlic tonkatsu shoyu, and you can never go wrong with those choices.  The noodles are perfectly cooked, and you get the delicious layer of fat in the broth.  The egg is also cooked PERFECTLY!  Slow boiled for that gooey center.  This is definitely my favorite ramen place in San Francisco!
author: T D.

description:
Great little neighborhood spot! 

Maybe it depends on the day of the week if the sushi is fresh, but every special I've tried here was great. Service is friendly, food is tasty and affordable. I try to always order something different, but I do usually order the onion cream croquettes. 

The only thing I didn't really like here was the ramen. I guess others don't agree on this, but for ramen I'd rather go to Suzu in Japantown. 

Cheap lunch specials, too!
author: Diana H.

description:
It upsets me to do this, but I have to! Their service really took a dive! The last THREE times I came here, we got take out, and every time they messed something up! First time, they ran out of 2 items we ordered. When we got there, the girl said she tried to call but couldn't get through, even though the number she wrote down on the order was correct. We didn't want to wait 30 minutes for them to make something else, so we just left. Next time, I ordered a spicy white tuna roll, but they made a regular tuna roll. I asked to have this corrected, so the chef just dumped a ton of hot sauce on top. Seriously?! Last time, I ordered a spicy white tuna roll with cucumber and just got a regular spicy tuna roll. C'mon guys!!!! Get it together! 

Food is still yummy, if you get the right thing that is.
author: Irina S.

description:
Sushi studio.

Small space (bathroom is through the kitchen).
Small prices (easily feed two for about $25).
Not so small menu (sushi, noodles, more).

Smoked salmon roll was the highlight. As was the first hand view of the cooking and cleaning as I went to the bathroom.

Three stars for food. Extra star for exceptional prices and charming service/space.
author: Jason B.

description:
Come here for ramen.

In my opinion, this place has the best ramen in the bay area.  The noodles are flavorful (not the dry/bland taste of most other ramen houses) and the broth has some complexity.  Now I've never been to Japan and had authentic Japanese ramen, but if it's better than the ramen here, I'm missin out.

There is a lot of stuff on the menu.  If I lived closer, I'd come here more often to check it all out.
author: Johnny C.

description: Came here for lunch with my sister. It's cash only so remember to get cash at the bofa nearby. I had the ramen and a roll and my sister also go the same. I also got a bento box to go for later. The food was delicious, filling, and pretty inexpensive. That why I bought food to go. The lunch special is especially a good deal. Love this cute neighborhood place.
author: Annie P.

description: Other then waiting almost an hr for our food which should of only taken 15 minutes since there was only 5 other tables. The waiter and my friend were having stank eye contest and told us they were defrosting our food.... Not fresh vastly disappointed.
author: Weyland L.

description:
I saw a small ad of this restaurant in local free paper a few months ago, then I thought I should give it a try. I had miso ramen and it was much better than I thought it would. I may not be the best ramen in Bay Area, but
above average if not better. We also shared onion cream corokke(croquette)and we loved it , too. After finding this place I think I don't have to drive all the way to South bay just to find good bowl of ramen!
author: Kana Y.

description: Highly recommend this little spot. Always searching for incredible ramen. Good one. Very quaint and warm. Will surely attempt to eat hear again and again. Can hardly wait for the kids to eat here with me. The sushi I ordered was fresh and very well priced.
author: Piggly W.

description:
Best Ramen in the SF Bay Area for me to date!

Tonkotsu Garlic Shoyu
Simply amazing. The best broth I've had to date. Rich but still light, and with good flavor depth from the shoyu and pork, which is surprising of the shoyu, which is usually simple and more neutral. I believe its from the pork they add. While they only add 1 slice, which sort of sucks since most ramen houses give you 2, the consistency is perfect. The pork is always tender, perfectly salted, and has a good amount of fat, which also adds to the flavor. It feels like they also portion out the right amounts of radish, seaweed, garlic cloves and bamboo shoots into this ramen, as each element is enough to flavor the ramen, but not overwhelm it.  This place has the best bamboo shoots, mildly enough flavored, with a soft crunch. The egg is also a winner. A perfectly medium boiled egg, with a nice partially yolky center... this egg ties with Daikokuya for being the best. This also helps to thicken and enrich the ramen broth, but I usually just eat it up because hey it tastes good. The noodles are also cooked perfectly, but I actually prefer the broth to a point where I just have soup left.

Tonkotsu Garlic Miso
The only difference here is the soup broth being miso flavored. Compared to other Miso broths, this one did not feel as heavy or had as much of that fermented soy taste that could potentially overwhelm people. 

If you love garlic, add extra garlic. Its totally worth it but at times can overpower the broth flavor if you can't handle garlic spice.
author: Marc T.

description:
I drop into Miki's whenever the wait isn't too long. It's a bit under-staffed so hangery bellies could get hangrier with the wait. My usual picks are sushi rolls, katsu dons, udon, and karaage. Everything's been fresh, tasty, and satisfying. When there's room left in my gut, I'll order their house special dessert with the banana dumpling and ice cream. Yum. 

I hit this place with friends often and it's never let us down.
author: Tony S.

description:
i came here for lunch and it was a pleasant surprise. it was authentically japanese, not owned by koreans or chinese but by japanese people. the menu for lunch isn't that big, but be sure to scan the walls and see what specials they have because they aren't listed on the menu. 

i was disappointed that i didn't get to order japo curry for lunch. and i also missed that they had shoyu and miso ramen! FAIL for me. ;( 

i opted for the lunch bento box with chicken karaage, veggie tempura, soup and salad. it was pretty good. of all the chicken karaage i have had, this one was not dry! it was juicy, tender and you can taste a bit of salt. the veggie tempura wasn't bad, it had cucumbers, carrots and beans and they were all crispy and fried to perfection.

my sister had the tempura udon, it had nice thick noodles, with lots of seaweed and a very flavorful broth! she said she loved it and it was delicious! definitely coming back here. 

we also had the red roll with tuna, avocado and crab and it was fresh! the tuna was a nice red color, it was so soft, fresh and delicious on top of the roll. i just took the tuna off the top and ate it on its own. the roll on its own was decent because it was like a california roll with tuna slices on top.

total w/ tip $25.44
author: Stella J.

description: We stumbled upon this place because we were starving and didn't want to hike on a empty stomach. There was no wait for us but after we got seated there was a long line. I ordered the soysauce ramen and he had the katsu and chicken karaage bento.  We were so confused because the menu said cash only but the door had a visa anad mastercard decal. We asked her and she said debit is fine so don't worry if you don't have cash. There was only one waitress so it wasn't like it was super good service or anything. I LOVED my ramen! One of the best ramen I've had in SF. It was definitely a smaller portion like how small this restaurant is. But I will definitely return for that ramen.
author: Amy G.

description:
Soooo okay... let me tell you this... I'm sooooo tired of eating strange Japanese food at restaurants in this city. Karaage in udon? Daikon in Sukiyaki? Agedashi tofu with Tonkatsu sause? Seriously???? It just gets on my neeeeeerve. 

But now I know where I'm going, when I want "real Japanese food" next t ime!!! Thanks to Miki=] I love this place!!!

Everything I had here was great! Especially, I liked their Chawanmushi and Crunchy spicy tuna roll=] Ummm yum

If you want authentic Japanese food, this is the place you shoud go to!!!!!!
author: Sakura K.

description:
This place has some out-of-this world ramen. I've been coming here sporadically over the last few months and the ramen really pulls me in every single time. I highly recommend ordering the Tonkotsu Garlic Miso Ramen - it's a gem. Full of flavor and definitely won't leave you disappointed. 

Most of my friends like to order sushi, and from their reviews the fish is always fresh and top-notch. 

The only downside (if you could even call it that) is the very slow service. Each visit, I've only seen one person in the kitchen and just one server. When this tiny neighborhood place gets filled, it's hard for them to juggle service in a timely manner. But patience is key and you'll be rewarded with yummy food.
author: Daniel P.

description:
I'VE been going here for some time, and like the homestyle cooking and affordable prices. Portions are generous, and staff is pleasant and helpful. Staff is small, so if they have a rush, food can take a while to arrive. And I was a little annoyed with them the other day when I ordered take out, and they wouldn't pack up the miso soup with my order. I insisted and the server made an exception.

Recently their lunch hours have been inconsistent, being closed when I thought a lunch would be nice. Their lunch is an amazing value, generous and well made.
author: Kevin T.

description:
Before i begin, I'm not an absolute authority on ramen and although i've visited japan numerous times, i've never had ramen while there. however, growing up in an tropical island and living in the bay area where japanese restaurants are abundant, i frequently ate ramen. it's my comfort food. Now, with that said, here's my thoughts on Miki's.

i've visited countless ramen restaurants the bay area had to offer. living in SF, I really wanted "the hype" about Miki to be true. driving one hour to  Santouka, located in San Jose, (arguably serving the best tasting ramen in the bay area) was not economical. 

Tonkatsu ramen:
the noodles and broth were average at best. the chasu nearly tasteless. the egg tasted like egg. according to the menu it should be seasoned. 

Garlic Miso tonkatsu ramen:
the noodles, chasu and egg taste is similar to the tonkatsu ramen. as for the broth, i couldn't make an assessment. Sadly, all i tasted was the mince garlic that is similar to that of bottled minced garlic you purchase at some asian super market. garlic should't overwhelm the broth, it should complement the dish. 

Pro: Price, located in san francisco, adjacent to purple kow, abundance of parking. 
Con: excessive garlic taste. 

Again, although i've visited many ramen restaurants in the bay area, only miki, Izakaya Sozai and Santouka are worth noting. In my opinion, Izakay Sozai serves the best ramen in SF. However, Santouka serves the best ramen in the Bay Area.
author: Jude Q.

description:
3.5 Stars

Miki was the answer to my ramen cravings on a cold rainy San Francisco night.  Miki is a small Japanese restaurant with 1 waitress and what looked like 1-2 cooks in the back.  I had the shoyu ramen with extra chashu.  The soup was tasty and the ramen was cooked to perfection - al dente.  The chashu was a little on the bland side. 

The staff was attentive and accommodating.

Overall, I think it was a pleasant meal, but it wouldn't be a top choice for satisfying my future ramen cravings.
author: E C.

description:
We had an errand to run on this side of town - which we are never in - and were hungry so decided to stop for dinner. Girlfriend lives Japanese food so I thought this would be a fun option. 

I had a bento box. It was good. The oil on the tonkatsu tasted a bit stale. The sashimi was delish. 

Girlfriend had soup. Broth was amazing - so many complex flavors! Bowl of soup was huge! 

Service was ok. Our food took quite a while to reach us. 

Overall it is good. If you're in the neighborhood give it a try!
author: Kristine V.

description: Just had this place the first time tonight... And now paying for it still. Food poisoning!!! Ugh...
author: Stephen Y.

description:
Pretty good food.  Came here due to all the yelp reviews, and true to common opinion we tried the ramen.  It was pretty good, tonkatsu spicy miso ramen was tasty.

Much to my yelp review reading's surprise, the sushi was actually very fresh as well.  I think I liked the sushi better than the ramen, however since it is pretty authentic the sushi menu is fairly short.
author: Jeff W.

description: The tonkatsu garlic miso broth ramen is SO delicious and buttery. Service is a bit slow though--definitely not somewhere you want to be if you're in a hurry. Perhaps they are working some ramen magic inside to make it taste so delicious. =D Their selection is also quite interesting. I haven't had a chance to ask them when they exactly serve ramen, but next time. I came one Saturday for lunch and they didn't have ramen cuz they didn't even give me a ramen menu, but I came during a weekday lunch and they had ramen. So be sure to ask so that they can give you all the different menus (I think there are 3 lunch menus)-- One for sushi, one for ramen and one for bentos. I would say this restaurant isn't a place for sushi. They were just so-so. FYI: Lunch is cash only.
author: Allyson L.

description:
It's a great neighborhood restaurant. It is small and quiet but offers good dishes. I ordered the ramen which was very flavorful and delicious. They only make a certain amount of ramen each day. My friend and I happened to order the last one.

I also ordered a sushi roll and the fish was fresh. The service is friendly, but can be slow since it is only one waitress. As for the decor I do not like it. The menu is large so it is overwhelming. There are also menu items listed on the walls that are not on the actual menu. So make sure you scan the whole restaurant!
author: Chatree T.

description:
A small little mom(no pop) restaurant in the Richmond District serving authentic Japanese food. The place is small.........probably only holds 26 ppl max. Kinda remind me of the old Taraval Okazuya. 

Salmon sashimi (portion is small..........not that fresh) 
White Tuna sashimi (tasted a little old........not as fresh) 
cal roll (I'm weird but you know me about Cali roll.....it's good) 
Ikura (seaweed tasted a little stale.....they don't toast it here) 
spicy white tuna (it was ok) 
Spider roll (a bit too sweet.......but it's decent) 

Total price 62.00 for lunch for 3 ppl 

I think there are far better Japanese restaurants than this place but I haven't tried the dinner yet. Price is a little on the higher end but with such a small establishment, I guess the price should be higher. Would I come back.................probably not for lunch. For this kind of money, you can probably get better at any other Japanese restaurant in the city. I personally love the mom and pop stores. Some of the negatives. 

Cash only for lunch 
3 pc. sushi orders instead of the regular 6 
price is a little steep 
the sushi chef in the back has a sushi sam's t shirt ( more funny than anything else)
author: jason g.

description: Great sushi, ramen, and food here. The service here is always friendly, and efficient. Sometimes the wait for food can be long, but you have to realize that it's basically just one guy cooking in the back. Don't forget to look up on the whiteboard, because there are usually specials up there that aren't on the menu. If you are watching a movie across the street at the Balboa, you should definitely come to Miki's for a meal afterwards.
author: Mars F.

description:
It's rare for me to find sushi I really like but I admit to having a particular taste i'm looking for.  I want sushi that is simple, fresh, and delicate, and that's exactly what Miki provides.  The selection is a quarter of what a typical sushi place would offer, but they ditch tons of redundant overcomplicated rolls in favor of traditional classics with top-notch fish and rice.  

Rolls here come to your table at room temperature with sticky, chewy rice that melts in the mouth, crispy seaweed, and fish that always tastes fresh and clean.  I hate getting rolls at a sushi place with fish that's still half frozen and cold, dense rice with a soggy seaweed wrapper.  The quality here has impressed me beyond any other Japanese restaurant i've tried in the city.  

The chirashi bowl is really great too!  So many places just serve up a bland offering of fish on rice, but here the sampling is varied and attention is paid to the bed of rice itself instead of treating it as an afterthought.

In addition to the great sushi they have a fantastic selection of authentic Ramen, which is also a bit on the simple side compared to trendier bowls you'll find at other places in the city.  A nice complex broth and chewy noodles never disappoint though.

Considering how many times I've come here for sushi and ramen, I've tried to sample some of the other offerings on the menu as well and have never been disappointed.  A nice selection of curries and grilled items round things out really well.  Without a doubt one of my favorite places in the neighborhood, and the whole city too.  They tend to get slammed but I find the wait to always be within reason.
author: Paul L.

description: Tiny neighborhood place in the outer richmond. The service is friendly and helpful without being in your face. I always get the ramen and have never been disappointed. Great for those foggy nights!!
author: Mitch H.

description:
Been wanting to see what this place was about, walked by it a couple times after dinner at Americana Grill. So one night we went in..

I had this black cod with this sauce...I just can't remember what that sauce was..it was very good though, very happy with that dish.
My lady had the chicken teriyaki, that was surprisingly good also. A bit too sweet but hey its teriyaki.

We also ordered the onion cream croquette and agedashi tofu. I am a big fan of croquette and I tend to order it despite the fact that I know its not something difficult to make. Anyways, both very good and we were very satisfied with the food and service.
author: phillip w.

description: Variety and quality - chicken karaage, hotate (scallop) nigiri, eel-licious nigiri, soft yet chewy ramen in hot soup, and warm sake. Plus best gals Leslie and nancy. All I needed was more sushi and tempura and it would have been a perfect blue moon dindin. Next time! give it a try but best to go early or late since their fans frequently queue up.
author: Ron W.

description:
The ramen was absolutely delicious.  I ordered the spicy Tonkatsu and my friend order the regular.  We both loved it.

Dessert wasn't as pictured.  The mochi dessert we ordered supposed to have come with 3 scoop of green tea ice cream but we were served with a single scoop of vanilla.  It was still good though.
author: Kevin T.

description:
Wow, I'm glad one of my friends introduced me to this restaurant.  Sure, the restaurant is extremely small and most likely, you will need a reservation during dinner hours.  Their sushi is very delicious and we would order 4 plates of sushi (got to love that dragon roll and rainbow roll).  The ramen selection is great though my favorite is the tonkotsu shoyu garlic ramen.

The only negative thing is the price so try not to get the sushi too often or you might be looking at a bill of at least $15 per person.
author: Harvey N.

description:
this time i called before i drove over for lunch and YAY!!! they were open.
