had their tonkatsu garlic miso ramen and it was pretty goooood.  The soup was thick and even had bits of fat floating in it (definitely not for those health freaks out there). The ramen was nice and chewy with a good texture to it.  my only complain about the ramen was the bamboo shoots.  it tasted weird with a strange gamey aftertaste.  

I also had a bit of my friend's tonkatsu spicy miso and it had a nice kick to it!!! 

would come back but only if i was in the area!!!!
author: JY L.

description:
I thought this place was named "Azusa" since the large Sprite sign over the restaurant said so but apparently I'm wrong. 

This place is not bad. The service is slow as there's only ever one waiter there. 

My family and I sat down to order (*note, we have eaten here on several other occasions, all of which preceded my knowledge of yelp.). 

The restaurant became crowded quickly. I counted about 8 tables cramped together. There was a two-seater table behind mine where the patrons kept bumping into my chair since it was so close together. 

Price: Average Japanese. Anywhere from about 7-15 dollars per dinner entree. I ordered the chicken teriyaki and the salmon shioyaki. 

Service: Slow. I believe there may be only one or two chefs? A woman who came in wayyy after us got served her food way before us! Amazing. Also, our foods came out at different times. I had to wait about 5-10 mins for my brother's food to be served since I felt bad eating when no one else had their food. 

Taste: The salad was excellent. I loved the dressing. The chicken teriyaki still had the skin on. The salmon was overcooked, but still retained some good flavour. Unfortunately that fishy taste was very overbearing. The teriyaki sauce tasted like it had cilantro in it, which I hope was not the case. 

After I ate miso soup, salad, all the teriykai chicken & shioyaki salmon AND half a bowl of rice I was STILL hungry!!! 

Their portions are small. And not impressive. And served on plastic dinnerware. 

I'd be more impressed if the atmosphere was more inviting but it wasn't and I'm not feeling all so forgiving at this moment. 

Oh, and I asked "I though pickles were supposed to come with this meal" and the waitress answered that the pickles were in the salad. 

I had expected pickles with my meal. Oh well, maybe people like pickles in their salad except for me? 

Well, I'd suggest going here when they aren't busy. The food is pretty good but the service extremely slow. 

If they are charging the prices that they are, I'd suggest going somewhere else for a little better service. Yes, I realize there's only one waitress, but the fact that the place was jam-packed made it hard for me to believe that they couldn't hire extra help.
author: Kimiko Q.

description: Love the ramen, yukke (with raw quail egg) , and that the service has gotten better. Since its a small run place w what looks like 1 or 2 chefs in the back theres a little wait for food. Everything else has been good so far. Im almost a regular now
author: Lyra c.

description:
Good everyday place if you had to fend for yourself when the wife is out of town.  Both the hot dishes and sushi is excellent.  

There's plenty of stuff to try on the menu and you really can't go wrong with anything.  The service is a bit slow but decent.  

My favorite is the kani-ebi handroll...try it!
author: MTBer I.

description:
It's famous about "Ramen" over there, however there are so many "secret"

good Japanese food also.

Awesome...
author: Takuro o.

description:
I'm not a ramen snob by any means, but I had the garlic ramen and it's now my new favorite ramen spot in SF.  I think it's better than Suzu and Tampopo.  My friend suggested this restaurant, and we both said we'd go back if that helps.  The deep fried chicken karage was good too.

An extra bonus is that this place is across the street from Purple Kow.
author: Michelle R.

description:
a decent ramen option way out there in outer richmond.  

we shared curry croquettes and ordered the tonkatsu shio ramen and tonkatsu shio garlic ramen.  watch out - the garlic ramen is very strong and has whole gloves of roasted garlic in there.  

ramen broth is pretty fatty, yet could be more flavorful.  noodles have a very nice chewy texture.  they give you a good slice of fatty pork, half an egg and a few bamboo shoots.  

i liked it ok , but i don't think i would drive all the way out here again to have ramen.  it's missing something, not sure what.
author: Josie M.

description:
I had a sashimi combination, a spicy tuna hand roll, and a large Asahi.

Excellent across the board.  Fast and friendly service too.  I love small neighborhood places like this, and will be back again.

I didn't notice it before, but they have a board with specials on the wall.  I'll try some of those next time! :)
author: Justin C.

description: Located right across from the theater where we watched a movie, we decided to drop by and try it. Now, we have to come here at least once a month in order to satisfy our craving for Yuki-Don( Sliced Tuna sashimi over sticky rice with bits of seaweed, garlic and sesame) Food Highlight: Yuki - Don but ask for half tuna and half salmon
author: Rich L.

description:
This place isnt alright We got there at 6 right before the dinner rush that came 15 min later--I think the wait would have been astronomical as there appears to be only one chef and one waitress. Its def. a hole in the wall, we found it on yelp but have passed it numerous times without notificing it. 

We tried rolls and I got some kind of noodle soup, I forget. Not for large parties nor a good date spot either. Just a good hidden fix for sushi cravings.
author: Amy S.

description: The best ramen I've had in SF. I haven't tried every ramen place in the City, but I've tried quite a few. I had the Tonkotsu shio (salt flavor). It was excellent. The noodle had the right texture, just the right amount of al dente and chewyness. The broth had subtle but complex flavors. Don't just gulp it down. Don't let the layer of fat floating on the top deter you (reminds me of Daikokuya in LA). Let it swirl in your mouth a bit, so you can take in the layers of flavors. You don't get a lot of other things in your noodle, just some bamboo chute, a thin piece of chashu, a piece of dried seaweed and som green onion, so if you had a big appetite you'll need to order addtitional food. I didn't have any trouble with service since I didn't get there until almost 9 pm.
author: Kelvin L.

description: I had a problem that only a bowl of ramen could solve. I ordered the pork garlic miso broth. It was very delicious and satisfying. You can add extra noodles (1/2 serving) for only $2. I will do this next time, as I can always eat more noodles. I will be back.
author: Cecily W.

description: Long wait, Hamachi Kama burned, fried chicken very oily, others are ok.  Not worth my uber ride...
author: Ming Lee G.

description: The reviews raved about the ramen, so that was what the six of us ordered.  Place was small, hardly enough seating for 25-30.  Service was a little slow as was reviewed by many but not impatiently so!  The orders were accurate and came steaming hot.  The ramen were slightly springy to the bite (al dente), and the tonkatsu broth was flavorful, rich and not too salty.  There was 1/2 a soft-boiled, miserly slices of pork, quite a few strips of a preserved turnip.  Mine was the spicy miso tonkatsu broth which was not too spicy for the average chili aficionados, it could be spicier!  I have eaten several times at Orenchi in Santa Clara, and I must say, Orenchi has a tastier broth, one whole egg, and a notch tastier overall!  I would eat at Miki again if I am in the area.
author: Taipan L.

description: Nice service, albeit slow at times. i came in around 7:30 and got seated quickly. The service is friendly and nice--- try the spicy miso chicken ramen! :) they also make onigiri fresh and I had been craving it since I had a taste of it at the Japanese conbini... but order it before you even eat. It's fresh and takes a while. A good place to pick up dinner before catching a movie across the street at The Balboa.... If you don't have good parking kharma, try the neighborhood streets around 38th.
author: Patricia M.

description:
Miki, like Tani's, is a place to go for Donburi and Tonkatsu and Soba and all that other down-home Japanese goodness--not so much sushi.  While the food here lacks the drop-dead scrumptious-ity of Tani's, you gotta love the adorable interior with the green walls, not to mention the fact that you have a decent chance of actually getting a table (though it is still extremely tiny).  Plus, the neighborhood charm of Outer Balboa certainly has the edge on Westlake.

(Hint: If you're trying to find Miki for the first time, look for the Azusa Teriyaki / Sprite sign).
author: Wes M.

description: I drool when I think of the ramen at this restaurant! While the wait may be a little long for your food, it is worth every minute of it! We especially love the ramen here. The broth is rich and thick and the noodles are chewy and have a great texture. We have also tried their sushi rolls and they are just as delectable. I will need to go back...very soon!!
author: Carrie S.

description:
A great hole in the wall authentic Japanese neighborhood "kitchen",  with truly well prepared tasty food, including specials of the day, which is always a good sign to me.

But, the place sorely lacks enough employees to make it time efficient and practical for the customer, and therefore a major deterrant to visit, which is a shame.

We typically like to order a variety of single-dishes (ippin-ryouri) either specalities of the place, our favorites, and/or what we just happen to feel like, etc., but because the server was so overwhelmed and we deduced he may not be able to  return for a long while, you have to change your strategy and just get all your food at once, wherein food sits longer and get cold, and you stop enjoying as much, and kinda just, eat.

Whoever is cooking back there is good though, they ought to get a bigger place, or spend some dough on more help.
author: Keith M.

description:
Lunch was great and my belly is happy, thanks to Miki Restaurant in the Outer Richmond District! I cannot believe I have never been here before even though it's so close by to where I now live.  Maybe because it's hidden and it's hard to notice when driving on Balboa, but I came across it today while taking a walk in the neighborhood. 

This place is TINY, a total of 10 tables (6 for 1-2 parties and 4 for 1-4 parties). Simply decorated with a few framed things on the wall with round and square paper lanterns. It was not very crowded for lunch so my to-go order was ready in under 12 minutes. The sashimi slices were a bit on the small side, but tasted fresh and the teriyaki beef was cooked to perfection with no visible fat, which I enjoyed with white rice. My meal also came with a side salad and an orange slice ALL for just $7.05 including tax. 

It is really nice to know that fresh sushi is just down the street from me and I predict that I will be coming here more often :-)!
author: Celeste M.

description: This is now my favorite place for ramen in the city. The noodles are al dente, the pork broth is flavorful, and the eggs are cooked to perfection. I also add the stewed pork on top for extra meat. The pork is so soft that you don't have to chew much. I would recommend getting the spicy garlic ramen.
author: Jack S.

description:
Here's the deal -- I've been scarfing lunch here for weeks now, cheating, as it were, on the Day Boat up the street, which has been and continues to be a solid provider of dinner. What can I say, I'm a craven man. The Day Boat is like that staid but no somewhat boring relationship you have, that always cranks out the craftwork when you need it. But sometimes, one needs a little spice on the side -- harmless hunger-flirting, if you will. Well, I've crossed the line with Miki.

I've tried every possible position with the Lunch Boxes -- everything is excellent. The beef is particulary exquisite -- I don't know why either, is it the cut maybe? - and even though I'm more meat-free these days, they can always suck me back in for a quickie. The tempura is a light as a cloud. The rolls, while smaller than average, pack a lot in. it's not about the size of the tools, but the style of worker, after all.

They also have a respectable sake list to get in the mood, and the promise of many more exotic sushi opportunities (on whiteboards with just enough "out" arrows stuck on them to create a velvet-rope-like air of gotta-have-it around them), which I haven't indulged in yet. Frankly, an ideal date would be dinner at the Miki and then a movie at the Balboa across the street. Unless you're on the down-low...
author: T C.

description: Great food! Best sukiyaki I've ever had. Not much to say about ambience  or service. The wait is worth it though
author: Dianna M.

description: Great place for a bowl of ramen on a cold evening.  A big plus is that you can choose from pork broth or chicken broth.  The portion was just perfect.  A perfect bowl of ramen.  Note that this is a small restaurant and can get packed very very quickly and on that cold evening when you want a bowl of ramen...you'll could be standing outside in the cold waiting for a table....
author: Stella C.

description:
Perfect little neighborhood jem for simple Japanese cuisine.  The place is EXTREMELY small, maybe 10-12 tables that seat 2-3 ppl at most, so do not come with a big group.  It seems like a 2 man team, the chef works in the back, and the young lady serves the front.  I have a soft spot for simple mom & pop shops.

The menu offers typical appetizers, nigoris, donburi, noodle soups, and dinner entrees.  The entrees look pretty good, I'll try that next time.  The specialty rolls are written on the wall, VERY affordable.  Each roll has about 4-5 pieces for $4-5.  They even have $2 California roll, that's cheaper than the fake ones at Safeway or Lucky's.  

We had a half order of salmon sashimi, the catepillar roll, a dragon roll, a california roll with unagi, and a bottle of Nigori sake.  The verdict?  YUM.  The chilled sake was perfect for the hot day, rolls aren't the best, but good enough, the sashimi seems fresh.  The only gripe I have is that the sashimi I had wasn't cut from a great section of the salmon, they left some silver skin on, and the pieces were too thin for my liking.  Yes, I'm wayyy too serious about my sashimi, so ignore if you don't care for raw fish.  

Regardless, I have a feeling this place is at its best with its dinner plates, not the rolls.  Rolls are generally not traditinal Japanese affair anyway, so perhaps I should apologize for my Americanized palate.
author: Christina D.

description: Not good at all.  The place is tiny...fine I can deal with that.  The place smells like a combination of baby puke and smelly feet.  I'm not sure I can deal with that.  The food was awful - from other reviews on Yelp, it appeared that their ramen was good.  Not at all - the noodles appeared to be the dried ramen package type complete with flavoring package, plus the food was way salty.  Added to that, spouse was complaining of MSG after effects (thirsty and headache).  Totally not worth the almost $10 per bowl we spent for the ramen.  Disappointing to say the least.  Place needs a major overhaul.
author: J H.

description:
Honestly, we planned to go to Shanghai House next door, but it was closed so that's the only reason we ended up here. Before committing, I looked it up on yelp and with a 4-star average, we decided to walk in.

It wasn't busy at all and I swear we waited almost an hour for our lunch to arrive at our table. It took a while for the server to take our orders, another while to get tea, another while to get our miso soup, and then another while to get our food. You'd think they were out fishing for our tuna and hamachi during all that waiting!

Other thoughts: There were signs on the walls stating that there is a $7 minimum order per person. What a weird policy. The menu also said "Cash Only" but they had all these Visa and Mastercard stickers on the door and at the cash register? I. Don't. Know.

Everything disappointed me except for the food.
author: Zell C.

description:
The go to restaurant. It's only been a month I believe since we started coming here and I think that we are now on our eighth trip. The typical pre-dinner conversation goes like this.
- Where do you want to go for dinner?
- I don't know. Let's go to Miki
This has already happened quite a lot already and its not because its only ok. Its because the food is so flipping good. Everytime we have gone we have left satisfied. Fully satisfied from our taste buds to our wallets. The food coma is the only drawback but well worth it. Miki we LOVE you. Great place casual atmosphere.

Order
- beef soy sauce butter
- saba nizakana
- kushikatsu
- everythings good nevermind the list..

Toothpick - 3/5 cheap toothpicks that end up breaking on you. I usually take 3 just for backups here.
author: KY L.

description:
I've been going to Miki ever since I was a kid. My father was born and raised in Japan and is picky about which Japanese resturaunts he would actually frequent often. 

Miki is small and only has one server, but the service is fast and it's very cozy. The food is reasonable and yummy and it's a nice spot if you want to get away from the techno-edgy Asian fusion cuisine that's so popular with yuppies now. 

If you cannot read Japanese or are not familiar with Japanese cuisine, I really suggest that you ask what's on the white board menu. Take a step away from the chicken teriyaki and California rolls.

The only reason why I'm not giving it a 5 star is because since they only have one server, you're going to have to wait for a while when families come in (And that is OFTEN). Other than that, I absolutely LOVE Miki and take my friends there often.
author: Yuri K.

description: Came here for another bowl of ramen and to my surprise they added a Porky Belly option to their additional topping ramen menu. It's 3 pieces for $3. They're mid-size pieces with quite a bit of fat on these pieces. It's really well cooked, soft, and really tasty. Definitely worth it to get the pork belly if you're not afraid of eating fat. It's more worth it than the additional cha siu topping imo.
author: Steven B.

description:
Ain't no big thing, literally!  (Sorry Al, I know this doesn't make sense to you now, but you'll thank me later.) The space is super, super small, so no parties greater than 2 or is it 4?? Menu is all Kanji so forget about ordering anything here!!!  Oh did I mention it's way out in the foggiest of fog belts?? In fact it gets so foggy you probably won't even be able to find the front door!! You won't even be able to find where you parked your car! YOU MIGHT GET TRAPPED OUT THERE!! There's usually only one person, maybe two, working the entire room, so service is a bit on the "casual" side. Yup, don't even waste your time. Just head on over to your Ebisu's, Kabuto's and Ryoko's; safer yet, get on over to Zushi Puzzle. Save yourself the trouble.

Did we lose 'em Al?  Throw 'em off the scent?  Okay, this place is one of the best kept secrets in the city. If you're a true Foodie, this is Foodie Sushi heaven. The Sushi is incredibly fresh, though they never have any Saba Nigiri. Maki are great. Their Agedashi Dofu is the bomb if you like that sort of thing. Been there many a time, tried many different dishes and it's always fab. Went one night when there was a troupe of JAL crew members pounding down the Asahi and feasting. Well worth the trip. Apres Miki you can catch a movie at the Balboa!

5 duckets of RA-spect!
author: Johnny C.

description: Their garlic miso ramen was not bad.  Pretty flavorful and  they added garlic in different ways (diced garlic, garlic cloves, and garlic puree).  The noodles were a little bit soft, but I think they were okay.  The meal didn't really wow me, but I would probably stop by again if I was in the neighborhood and maybe try something else.
author: Lawrence E.

description: The best things about Miki are (1) the homey, authentic Japanese ambiance (2) the server who managed our expectations about the wait very well, and (3) the ramen. With the ambiance it brought back nostalgic memories of when I lived in Tokyo. I thought the ramen was a step up from most other places in the city. I'd definitely make a stop if I was in the neighborhood, but might not drive across town just to eat here for dinner.
author: philip k.

description: Spicy garlic miso ramen good but very slow service. Good for local neighborhood ramen. Compared to other big ramen names out there not worth the trip.
author: Larry L.

description: This place is fantastic! We loved the food, service, atmosphere. Great for kids too.  The garlic miso ramen is so delicious! Drove 150 miles to get here and well worth it!
author: Dustin H.

description:
Cozy place, good service, good prices, a real Japanese spot too. 
But, last time we ate there, our food took MORE THAN ONE HOUR to come out (we just order grilled saba and a donburi). I understand this is a Mom and Pop's kind of place but the other times we ate there, the food came out at a more reasonable pace. The portions were also small (but tasty). Sadly, will not be going back.
author: Empress C.

description:
The food here is quite tasty.  The black cod misosuke, salmon, and miso saba were ordered that night.  The flavor of the sake marinaded cod was a real zinger, charred and flaky.  It was very well prepared. The saba  however was cooked to death, and pin bones were found tucked away.  It's lucky that the saba can take on quite a bit of doneness with its high oil content.  

The sushi is ok at best.  The handrolls were skimpy on rice, and the poor nori left almost empty.  The sushi itself (the rice) was mush and the same quality served for dinner.  The tamago was tasty and the pieces were ok.  It's not the best fish i've ever had.

The poor kitchen is tiny, and I give them much props for pumping out the food they do in such tight quarters.  However, fire times and service were slow.  If you have the time to wait around for ok fish, and to fill the hunger, this place ain't so bad.  I feel bad for the one and lonely server who looks like she's gonna pull her hair out.  

The restaurant is tight, and the customers that pile up during a rush inside the restaurant gets annoying and in the servers way.

One visit is enough for me.  Tasty food, ok quality fish.  It wasn't bad, but it wasn't anything worth coming back for.
author: Phat Hippo L.

description: Love this little neighborhood restaurant. Cozy and unpretentious like home cooked Japanese. Try cold tofu ramen and the salmon teriyaki combo dinner.
author: Sam S.

description:
A really cute and tiny little hole-in-the-wall, usually run by two young Japanese folks: One in the kitchen, one outside. This means that when things are busy, they are extremely understaffed, so don't expect super quick service.

The food is good, and has a home cooked feeling.  They have all of the staples of Japanese food on their menu, and a chalkboard for the more exotic specials. I'm not a big drinker, but I see a lot of people drinking sake here, if that means anything to you.

Parking's kind of tough in this area. I'm so glad my parents live only a few blocks away. ;)
author: Bekki J.

description:
Small and cute restaurant in the neighborhood; a little hard to find if you're not looking carefully enough. I went here tonight for the first time with my two friends who kept telling me that Miki is one of the best places for Japanese homecooking in the Bay Area. They're both Japanese (one Japanese-American), so I trust their judgment.

The tea was served in a nice, authentic pot and the interior was simply decorated, yet it emulated the feeling of being in Japan. I really felt like I had stepped into Japan when I went into the restaurant. 

Dinner specials are written up on a board, and there's also a lot of choices in the table menu itself. Apparently, lunchtime is cash only, but dinner can be paid with credit card (if need be). Prices are all very reasonable for the amount of food.

I ordered the chanko nabe and still feel really full from it. Seafood, two potstickers, fish, chicken, all in a soup hotpot, served with rice, miso, and salad. All for $9.50; great deal! Portions were not stingy either (unlike some other Japanese restaurants, i.e., Maki). I had a good time at Miki, so I will definitely be back again. This may become one of my favorite neighborhood places yet. =)

P.S. Service is a bit slow due to only having one waiter in the whole place (hell, it's tiny). Still, it might be good if there were two servers to speed up the turnaround on tables.
author: Helene K.

description:
I was directed to this cozy sushi restaurant by Johnny C. and he is always right!  The sushi was super fresh and so good I almost fell off my seat!  My favorite sashimi is sake (salmon) and this place doesn't disappoint!  I'm so happy I live so close to Miki!!!

Arigatou Johnny-kun!
author: Keika L.

description:
ok, i have not tried the sushi yet since i have been sooooo busy eating their ramen....i used to love katana-ya on geary as my favorite ramen in the city....not any more.  miki's, you win!!!
the service has gotten to me so that is why i minus a star....sorry.
the only time service is decent (time wise) is if you go on a weekday for their lunch.  we were there a few days ago (evening) and a server we have never seen before was there and talk about not very japanese like....
basically throwing things at you....ok yes i am exaggerating...very rough....a "i dont care if you come here or not, i just help out and get paid very little, so i dont give a damn attitude..."

But I LOVE THEIR RAMEN!!!!!  shoyu tonkotsu ramen with extra cha-shu please.....
If I ever see that server, I will just walk away, no matter how much i am craving their ramen...just walk away...must not give in...
other than that.  i will gladly wait however long it takes.  :)

BTW i know there are a lot of people who rate places on how cheap it is.  LUNCH is a must if you are on a budget!  cheap eats!!  Their lunch menu is awesome!!
author: Elisa O.

description:
Nice "shitamachi" atmosphere here.  How would I define "shitamachi"?  Erm, not ghetto per say, more like... "working class"?  I guess what I'm trying to say is that Miki has a down-to-earth, friendly, authentic teishokuya feel that is really rare here in the image-crazed S.F.  Bay Area.  It's like the Japanese equivalent of a greasy spoon, I guess you could say.  I think the only other place that has this same shitamachi feel is Tani's Kitchen in Daly City.

... But this place is a lot better: food is tastier, place is bigger and cleaner, not as crowded (usually).  Some pretty tasty karaage here, and the kaki fry is nice too.  But I would steer clear of the sushi since this place is straightforward enough to call itself a "teishokuya", NOT an "osushiya".  

Solid 4 stars for a combination of good food,  low prices, competent and subtly friendly service, and a bearably comfortable atmosphere.  Much better than many other Japanese restaurants in San Francisco.
author: Ryan D.

description:
oh miki, you're so fine.

SORRY, i couldn't help it...

no really, though - delicious and fresh.
author: Mooni P.

description: Everything's good!! And very reasonably priced. A hidden gem in the richmond for sure..
author: George W.

description: I received a recommendation from a co-worker about this place so i decided to try it out today, as I only live only a few blocks away. I normally don't go out of my way to write bad reviews about businesses unless I feel they sincerely deserve what I have to say about them. My bad experience isn't with their food as I have never tried it, but with their horrible attitudes and service. I have never in my life been not greeted and looked past as I have in this place. I walked in with the hostess looking past me as I wasn't there after which I got her attention asking her for a menu. Standing around now next to the kitchen window 7 minutes later , I decided to go and grab the menu my self. After doing so the lady rudely ripped it out of my hands only to say that's the lunch menu. I stood back not knowing what this lady was doing ripping anything out of my hands especially after ignoring me now for more then 10 minutes. Getting frustrated I started on my way to the door as she came back and gave me the correct menu. I looked over the menu briskly and told her I was ready to order with her responding "ok, one second". After waiting another five minutes I decided my business wasn't needed here as I now wasted eighteen minutes waiting to just place an order. Maybe their food is great, and maybe I would have came here all the time and told all of my friends about this place, but being treated like I was I would never ever come here again!!!!
author: Vlad M.

description: Miki is the best!!!!! Generally there is only one person waiting on all the tables, so you need to be patient, but the food is some of the best true Japanese.  The specials of the day are always on the white boards on the walls, so take a look.  Oh and watch out, they close at 8:30.  A really nice small, quiet place to go, always worth the trek to outer Richmond.
author: Anders Y.

description:
A gem! Truly a gem! My favorite restaurant in SF. Small, so get their early, and don't plan to get in and out fast, as they usually only have one wait person. 

Spoils you for most other Japanese food. I am a bit torn recommending it as I don't want it to get more crowded, but my last favorite (Crescent City Cafe) went out of business, so I want Miki to have as much business as possible. 

My favorites (everything), but the best, the beef with eggplant, Saba (mackerel with salt), sukiyaki, California roll with unagi. 

Oh, and did I mention CHEAP!!! We can stuff our family of three for $40 including beer. 

Bring a coat if you have to wait...
author: Erin C.

description: Yummiest bento boxes! White tuna sashimi is melt in your mouth good! And salad dressing is sooo delicious, along with complimemtary california roll!
author: Sarah Z.

description:
A GEM

One comes here to eat. Plain and simple. 

The asahi butter clam soup is beyond..

Weeknights are best, as the joint is small.
author: Stanley L.

description:
This is one of my favorite mom-and-pop restaurant where I know I can find comfort food when I feel like spoiling my taste buds and making my tummy very happy.  My favorite entrees here are Tuna Yukke Don with a raw egg, Saba Shioyaki (Grill Mackerel), Chicken Shioyaki, and spicy-tuna-avacado-crunchy roll.   

I have to admit, the spicy-tuna-avocado-crunchy roll doesn't taste the way it use to anymore.  For awhile I thought they changed owner but I asked and they said no. I guess they just changed the sauce?

You have to come here early to beat the crowd since the service is slow, it will take a long time to be seated =) Be prepare to wait, or come early like at 6pm. 
I'll come here again in a heart-beat.
author: Lily L.

description: Tonkotso Ramen was OK, not great. It did not have a lot of meat, maybe 2 slices. Overall, a forgettable bowl of ramen.
author: Yelp R.

description:
This is one of my neighborhood spots for Japanese food and based on the reviews, I thought this place was really going to be kick ass but it wasn't all that.  

We came around closing time one night and I guess a restaurant to be good, has to either have real good food or have real good value.  I think this place is in the middle on both of these items so I think if I am ever craving Japanese in the hood, I'll go to Balboa Teriyaki up the street instead...
author: Mark W.

description:
Must try: Tuna/Salmon Yukke Don and Tuna/Avocado crunch roll.
They must have added extra sugar to their yukke don rice because it tastes a bit sweeter than most Japanese sashimi over rice orders. because I have a sweet tooth, the sweet and savory combination instantly hit the spot. This place is definitely worth the drive.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
It would be four stars, but I waited 50 minutes for my bowl of ramen and two small sushi rolls.  I heeded the advice of my fellow yelpers, and allowed myself an hour and a half to eat, but still, that's a long time.  The place was packed, and there is only one server doing everything.  I asked for a to go box before I got my food, just in case I wanted one, and paid cash even though I would have rather used plastic. It may have taken a while to run the card.

I'll admit to everybody that I'm still learning about ramen here in the city, so I'm no expert (another admittance, but hey, I'm an expert on other stuff) but I do know what al dente is, and the noodles were that.  There were indeed little splotches of fat in the broth. Maybe that's partially why it was so good.   It was the soy based ramen.  

I got a cali roll and a salmon cucumber roll.  Damn, the cali roll was the best I've ever had by far!  It just melted once i started chewing, and it tasted really balanced.  There was just the right amount of everything in the roll.  I'm going to go back there and just order a bunch of that. 

The salmon cucumber was good, but I didn't like it nearly as much. 

I think that just based on how amazing the Cali roll was, that this place really knows what they're doing.  If you are going to a movie across the street, then allow some time, especially if you are going out on a friday or saturday.
author: Luke S.

description: In my opinion, this place has the best sushi in the city for the price.  The fish is never frozen and is always fresh and flavorful.  They also make killer natto omelet and good ramen.  A staple in my week.
author: Victoria R.

description:
I've been going here for quite some time now. After my family decided to not go to Balboa Teriyaki anymore (see my post regarding the incident) we changed allegiances and went to Miki's. We have not looked back yet. 

The food is super traditional Japanese Mom and Pop status, and i'll be the first to tell you, it's amazing. Also the prices are so low that when you get the bill you'll actually feel as if you are robbing them. Food this good should not be this cheap, but then again, that's what makes Miki's great. 

The only downside is that the food takes a while to arrive, and this is the reason. There is one waiter, one cook, and one prep guy. That's it. But we're not in the best of times right not economically so I dont blame them for being short staffed. I also don't blame them on the 7.00 minimum order either, because the fees for credit cards are awfully high. 

Outside of those few and little downsides, Miki's is the best for the food and for the price. No doubt about it.
author: Eric T.

description: Returned after having moved from the area, with a craving for beef tataki. Sadly, I was disappointed by the over-seasoning, smaller portion, and different taste. I was really looking forward to an authentic Japanese meal.  I used to go to Miki at least once a week when I lived in the area. I'm hoping I was just there on an "off" day.
author: Coco M.

description:
I've lived here for 5 years now, and this is one of two authentic Japanese restaurants in San Francisco that I've found.  It's a cute little homey restaurant nestled between a row of other small shops and restaurants on the block.  If you're homesick for Japan, go to Miki.  You'll feel better.  

Only bad thing is the service....it  takes a while.  There's only one server, so it's understandable.  But, the service is always authentically japanese....smiley, friendly and mindful.
author: Mellie P.

description:
I'm not sure if I really love you or if I just want to love you. 

The first time I went the food was yummy.  Teeny tiny rolls at teeny tiny prices, and a dinner menu that I couldn't wait to try, but really, I was in the mood for sushi, so sushi was what I was going to have, damnit. 

Last night?  Over twenty minutes just to bring tea to our table and then longer to take our order, and after an our of waiting for our food (it wasn't that busy, dears, I know skeleton staff, I know they're so so nice), the food was... meh.   And spendy for meh sushi, at that. 

But I really really want to love Miki.  Its so homey and cute and...  

sigh.
author: Nora B.

description:
This place is the real deal.  You will find that unlike the chic overpriced noveau sushi places with the cool names this place is patronized by japanese people - young, old , families, and the reason is obvious.  It is genuine and prepared with great care by the same person that buys the food.  We have eaten there about 25 times a year since it opened.   We also go to the other Japanese restaurants on Balboa, they are good.  We venture to the the upscale places around town and appreciate their presentation and variations, and they often have some amazing dishes you will not find here. But in the end if I had to eat in one place and one place only, my desert island restaurant would be Miki.
The board is what you want to look into, this is what the fresh and special dishes are listed, but the routine items are made with the same attention.  Clean, straight up, perfect Japanese food.
author: Peter R.

description: the place is pretty small but small places are usually pretty good and it was! the food was great! not all the items are in the menu so look around at the boards to find unique foods. Even though it was kind of pricey, i felt like it was worth it.
author: Edna L.

description: I like their ramen, but love their spicy tuna roll.  Large pieces of tuna, rice cooked and seasoned to perfection with an amazing touch of hot chili oil with wakame.  But please do not mind the look, which is far from perfect.  Just close your eyes and taste the perfect balance of fresness and texture in your mouth!  I can tell you looks can be deceiving.
author: Mrs P.

description: This place is one of the better izakaya type joints in the city. Everything we had was cooked delicately and right. My 11 month son cried when we stopped giving him beef udon. The yakitori and oyako don were very good. Awesome.
author: Chad W.

description: Sushi and ramen were excellent!  Grilled black cod was just okay.  Service is pretty slow, but I felt bad for the one waitress responsible for the whole front of the house, taking orders, serving food, and busing tables.  $3 Sapporo drafts 5-7 pm.
author: Cy C.

description:
100% Japanese owned restaurant is what we love about this restaurant.
Sure, it is a small place but the food and the service is great! The price is fair. We will eat here once a week!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
This cozy and cute little Japanese place is a neighborhood gem. I eat here several times a month because it is within walking distance to my house. The food is fresh and tasty.
The daily specials are  really good and the sushi is always very, very fresh.
My favorite dish here is the Udon. They really do it well. The broth is perfectly seasoned and the noodles are puffy and a little chewy.
It is a small place with only 6 or 7 tables and one server but I have never felt I've waited too long for my food or received substandard service.   I wouldn't recommend it for large parties, but for 2 or 4 people it is a lovely little place for dinner.
author: Missy F.

description: Had to update my review from last time for two reasons.  (1) Since then, I've had a couple of the other bowls of ramen from other places in the city that were more deserving of 5 stars.  (2) Today, my brother and I went for lunch and had a not so great experience there.  The place was close to full, but there was only one server there. She didn't speak great English, and maybe wasn't the right person to be running the front of the house by herself.  The service was slow, and they forgot the pork belly in both of our bowls of ramen.  We had been waiting so long when the bowls came that we asked them to bring the pork belly separate.  It took at least 10 minutes for the pork belly to come, and when it did, it was a bit too sweet, and not entirely warmed through. The texture was good, but it would've been much better if it had been in the soup when we got it. The ramen itself was delicious -- I had spicy garlic miso tonkatsu and my brother had garlic shoyu tonkatsu -- but for some reason I got one piece of pork and he got five pieces.  I understand it's a small, probably family-run place, but they need to be more careful in the future to make sure that people keep coming back for their great bowls of noodles.
author: Pilan C.

description:
Miki is a good solid neighborhood sushi nook. That's the best way to 
explain it. Its in my neighorhood, walking distance, it has a decent selection of fish, rolls/ sashimi and hot dishes but not always the freshest. I do like that their rolls are half rolls, so you can get more items to try. I do end up going there simply because it is right there and I dont know if I would be going to it if it wasnt in my hood.
author: Lori O.

description:
uuugh. go get a bowl of pho while ur waiting

the food is just OKAY. nothing spectacular. soy sauce butter stuff is disappointing. the sushi is above average though.
but the service is HORRRIBLEE. probably cuz its so smalll & is often packed @ night. but 1 waitress.... 30min wait & 20mins to clear a table? 
2hours for a dinner......... noooooooo fricken wayy not worth the wait

illl go back to try a few more dishes only if its totally empty
author: R Y.

description: It was a really long wait for the food, but when it finally arrived, it was the best Tonkotsu Ramen in San Francisco.  The soup was nice and fatty with lots of flavor.  The noodles had a nice texture, I prefer it a little chewier, but still very good.  I ordered it with the egg and it is hands down THE best egg I've had at a ramen place in SF.  The last time I had an egg this good, I was in Tokyo.  The egg was marinated with the yolk a little runny (the way I like it).   If you're looking for some good ramen in SF, you gotta give this place a try!
author: Mandy L.

description:
This is my favorite regular spot in the city! Only Good unpretentious affordable authentic homey cooking here.  It's the only place that I actually can go to everyday and probably still not be tired of it. But everything is sooooo gooood here. It's my secret little spot hidden away in the fog of Richmond. Everytime I come here it feels like I'm back in Japan eating at those cozy neighborhood restaurants and izakayas. The best part is that Miki's serves all of it in one place, whereas in Japan you had to pick 1. At Miki's everythings rolled up into a fuzzy little ball. Izakaya, Sushi, and good ol' homecooking in one place!

If you come here you have to get something off the specials board. It sucks that some of its in Japanese but you have to try the Hotate (scallops) in butter served in the shell with butter and sake I think. Also the tigerprawn gyoza, gyu-tan (beef tongue), ika karaage, and chawanmushi are all good bets for appetizers. I'm not normally a sushi-roll type of guy, but my favorite sushi roll is the spicy-tuna/avacado crunch with tempura batter on top. it's worth my trip there alone! And for dinners the Beef Soy Sauce butter is deee-lish, another one of my regular orders. I don't know what he does or where he gets that beef but it just so damn tasty. Other things I normally get are the Chirashi, Saba shioyaki (can't live with out that), and the Tuna yukke don (it's like marinated korean raw yukke style beef only with tuna). Theres a whole lot of other things that are on the board that are great and if you're tired of the same old chicken teriyaki vanilla restaurants around the city, try hitting Miki's up, but watch out if it's packed. I guess you can always go during lunch for the sweet "7 dollar pick 2 things lunch special."
author: clint t.

description: oh man, tons of noodles.  so many noodles!  this is up there with the likes of halu and saiwaii but not quite as epic as chotto or izakaya sozai (for the city that is...).  solid ramen that's special enough for me to make the trip out there if sozai is too packed.  the pork belly could have been a bit more tender and tasty, which is really my only complaint about the ramen.
author: Jeff N.

description: I used to live around the corner from this place, and it is one of the very few things I miss about the Outer Richmond.  The place is small and a little cramped, but has some of the best sushi in the city.  For the money, I don't think it can be beat.  Everything is very reasonably priced, a rarity in SF.  I particularly love their spicy tuna rolls.
author: Jules R.

description:
This is definitely my favorite Japanese Restaurant in the city.   The sushi is authentic and so affordable.   And you usually cant' say that about a Japanese restaurant because it is either too expensive or not authentic.  I always rate Japanese restaurants by their sushi, because if their sushi in not authentic or doesn't taste right, then it usually means most likely you might have trouble finding the authenticity with the rest of the menu.  

The biggest thing to consider here is the affordability.  I mean I can order six rolls and an appetizer and the bill is around $30.  Their Spicy Tuna Crunch roll great and the kani/ebi roll is delicious.   They also have one of the best Beef Sukiyaki's in town.  I usually rate other Japanese restaurants to this restaurant and the prices are usually double the price.   I find myself thinking I would rather eat at Miki's twice before I eat somewhere else.  Try my rating system and see if you agree.  

Just try to get to the restaurant early because it is not too big and if it gets crowded you will have to wait a long time with a hungry stomach.  I believe they are closed on Mondays as well.
author: Bryan W.

description:
Fanfuckingtastic.

Dinner here felt like an hour-long fellation by the Japanese seafood gods, topped off by peach sorbet served inside a peach.  Sweet Jeeba.

They run a skeleton crew, so expect to wait.  I counted four people, including the hostess/server.  But, still, refer to the previous paragraph.

Also, I think I have diabetes from the saccharinely cute* hostess.  She drew a cartoon raccoon that said "Arigatou!" on the back of our bill, for Christ.

*Japan's third-leading export after consumer electronics and fucked-up game shows.

Go now.  It's worth the wait (and the freezing in The Avenues).
author: James N.

description: One chef (WHO IS JAPANESE).  The kitchen is the size of my closet.  The specials are written on a dry erase board daily.  You know the food at a hole in the wall like this is gonna be the shit.
author: Tommy O.

description:
first time here after a recommendation from a friend.  true its a long wait, not sure why the owner doesnt hire a kitchen helper.  anyways.  ordered the tonkatsu miso ramen.  noodles were great, best ive had in a while.  the broth was flavorful but i must admit the extra added fat was a little over done.  overall good bowl of ramen.  got the extra pork belly which was dumb since i dont really like pork belly.  next time ill go with the sliced pork.  

will go back.
author: DEREK S.

description:
Excellent small owner chef run restaurant.  Decor may be able to use upgrade.  Food is excellent and staff are accomodating.
You may have to wait if it is busy.  Small restaurant is open when owner is able to cook.
author: judy s.

description: This place is like a Japanese restaurant imported to America. I love coming here for my saba shioyaki and katsu-don cravings. The place is small and home-y, and so is the food. If you want real Japanese food, come here. And try the specials!
author: Pearl P.

description: I crave kaisen chawan mushi!!! I love this place. It's a really tiny restaurant in the Outer Richmond but I'm so glad that my friend introduced me to it. It is not good for a group but it is very nice for lunch or dinner with a few friends. I have mostly ordered the Japanese tapas there or small plates and have never been disappointed. The chawan mushi or steamed savory egg custard is a must have!!! It is a small bowl of hot soupy goodness!!!
author: Lisa M.

description: Nice spot for basics in Japanese eatery- my usual is the maguro sashimi combo that includes gohan, tempura, salad, and miso.  This all goes down very well with a big Asahi and a fun place for practicing your Japanese listening skills ( yeah iam a nosy mufo).
author: omar b.

description:
my ramen was cold. i watched it sitting on the counter going from steaming to lukewarm before the server decided to carry it over.

they weren't busy. there were only 2 tables. they were not shortstaffed. (1 server and 2 cooks in the back should've been enough to handle such a slow night)

i went to the restroom and they were all standing around talking with their phones out before they saw me coming and pretended to work.

no matter how good the food is, i will not be going back.
author: Lizzie O.

description: Miki is a great neighborhood japanese restaurant that brings traditional japanese food to San Francisco.  I ordered the Unagi Don, Chicken Katsu, Sweet Potato Tempura, and Salmon Toro are wonderful.  I would recommend this Japanese restaurant for lunch or dinner... very reasonable prices... Groups are hard to fit as it is small and you probably would have to wait...  Simple and clean decor and the waiter... 1 waiter is very nice.
author: Frank M.

description: I would not come here for sashimi or rolls here..why? because it's not that great. The hot food here is awesome, Ramen here is literally the best here. Although it may be the best, the portion is pretty small compare to other Ramen places. They have some other hot plates that I enjoy like their bento boxes etc, but their biggest problems would their services... It took me 40 minute to get my ramen... and this isn't my first time coming here. Oh ya did I mention that the restaurant is tiny? It's tiny enough to be able to eavesdrops other customers conversation which is pretty annoying...
author: William C.

description:
After finally seeing the noren go up at the front doorway, I knew it was time to stop off for my monthly fix of Japanese goodness.  The place was stuffed with people, but had really a lot of foot traffic. Small (seats up to 24 people) & whoever says they can't do groups...they fit 8 people with 2 tables.... From the outside, the place looks iffy, but going inside, it was really nice and low key. Clean and traditional Japanese decor only adds to the pluses.  They have quite an array on their menu and their wall menu too.  I chose to do the combination menu and ordered the salmon teriyaki and tempura...with a side ikura sushi.  
You can always tell if you're eating at an authentic place or a wannabe when you taste their miso soup and declare "This is EXACTLY what Miso taste like in Japan!" The side salad wasn't drowning in miso dressing and the pickles were really spot on. 
OMG..the salmon teriyaki and the tempura shrimp were worth the walk.  The teriyaki sauce wasn't overtly salty as some places tend to do and just the right sweetness ratio. The Ikura was not too salty and tasted fresh. 
Because there's only 1 server for the entire floor, he was kept hopping...but he was unfailingly polite and asked about my experience with my meal...kudos...
Next time I want to try the peach sorbet for dessert which they serve in an actual peach.
Parking is great if you come after 7:30...and gets progressively worse as the night goes on.

**Lunch Update** They have a really filling lunch box offering of 2 items for $6.50...$5.50 for the 1 item. I love their dragon rolls...it's unagi is sooo yummy.

**Dinner Update** OMG...the most moist and savory unagi-don I've had in a good long time. Excellent Japanese Sweet Potato tempura. The rice could have been cooked with a bit more water...it's a bit harder than I'm used to.
author: Pauline L.

description:
I wanted to give Miki five starts, I really really did after reading all of the wonderful reviews about it.  But sad to say, it has suffered a loss of two stars.  Granted, the fish was very fresh, and I do have to say I adore their spicy tuna because they use actual tuna slices and not mashed tuna, big plus and almost brought a star back.  

First star lost: definately good sushi, but not so amazing that I thought I died and had gone to heaven.  I would not have given it five stars based on the food alone.

Second star lost: it takes FOREVER!  Everybody said be ready to wait, right?  Well I am going to tell you to really really be ready to wait.  We got there at 8:10 and were planning on seeing a 9:20 movie at Balboa--literally 15 steps away.  We did not get our menus until 8:20, order was not taken until after 8:30 and we didn't get our food until 9:10!  

To sum it up, if you like good sushi and want a long, lingering date with someone special, eat a snack before you leave the house and go to Miki.
author: Whitney T.

description: They have great Yukke Don!!!
author: Unko G.

description:
Ahh Miki, so yummy.  By far my favorite outer-richmond neighborhood Sushi joint (there are at least 3 others within 2 blocks).  As much as I hate to sound like a sushi newbie, and I'm not.   I love the spicy tuna crunch roll, unlike your average spicy tuna roll; It's nice and tasty, and covered with some tempura crumbles and a sesame oil type of sauce.  The rest of there sushi is all pretty decent,  not top-of the line, but definitely worth the price.

Another Note,  When you go to Miki, you will see that one of the daily menu whiteboards has some things written in Japanese. Apparently, they are just too laid back to translate these items. Don't be scared to ask your server what these things are, as they tend to be interesting.

Anyway, to sum it up,  Miki is not a fancy business meeting sushi joint, it's a neighborhood sushi joint, a take your friend out for a cheap lunch place.  I wouldn't suggest someone who lives on the other side of town to come out here, but if you are in the richmond, it's definitely the spot.
author: Nicole M.

description: A small unassuming Japanese restaurant no bigger than a master bedroom. There is only enough room for six or so tables. There is one chef, a prep, and one waitress/waiter. The food here: Spectacular. There something to be said about cozy intimate places where it feels like you're looking into someone's kitchen instead of being at one of those snazzy Japanese places like Ozumo, where the focus is on something other than the food on your plate. Because of the limited space, and staff, the service is at times slow, but it's definitely not from a lack of effort. In a quest to look for those tiny jewel of a restaurants that are totally local and relies heavily on word of mouth, sometimes it's worth a little sacrifice.
author: Eric C.

description:
This is my usual order for 2 people.
1. Wakame Salad 
    Tender Seaweed with light sauce not too salty or greasy
2. Gyoza 6pcs
    Yummm. Most places just cook-up some frozen gyoza. This is more than decent gyoza.
3. agedashi tofu
    OMG.. juicy tofu.. deep fried with very thin batter with delicious sauce 
4. side dish sweet potato tempura
    sometimes I order full combo tempura but this sweet potato tempura is on he white dry-ink board menu is on left side of wall (writting board)
5. zaru soba
    cold noodle with sauce best in town.. not many places have this on the menu and even when they do they dont know how to make it as good as MIKI.. I love it love it love it
6. Teriyaki Salmon or Beef
    Small size with few vegetable. If you looking for big dish you might disappointed.
    but salmon/ beef is very tender and juicy
7. California Roll - very nice
8. Dragon Roll or Caterphiller Roll
9. Uni - you have to check because they don't always have it, or it sells out fast, but when they do have it its super fresh and delicious.
Total $50.00-ish

Also Miso Ramen/ Spicy Ramen/ Bento/ Don Katsu/ Chicken Teriyaki... But these 9 items i listed above are my favorit and I LOVE IT!!!

You have to be patient because they cn take some time to make the food. The cook is a serious guy too, so don't bitch about waiting because your gonna get good stuff. If you come between 5 and 6:15 I have seen this to be the best time in terms of getting the food fast.

You can't take the menu home, and they don't have printed menus, so use your cell phone to take pictures of the menu.

The atmosphere is a small place, so there is none of this "Welcome to Chevy's!!" type of fake excitement. This place is pure Japanese all the way, and you can probably already tell that I think it's one of the best in the city.
author: Tony M.

description: Cozy place for authentic home-style Japanese cooking.  Everything on the specials board has always been sure to please.  But they do sell out of alot of those items early-which is a good sign that their food is fresh.   Katsu curry is one of those.  The beef tataki and hamachi sashimi combo dinner hits the spot for me since I always want a lil bit of both red meat and sashimi. Service can be slow but I don't mind cause it's a small operation.  Most of the customers speak Japanese -always a good sign...
author: Amina B.

description:
i came here for dinner on a weeknight and seeing how there was only 30 minutes until closing time, a lot of the items on the menu were sold out but by far, the best dish we had was the miso saba. this place is a bit on the smaller side, maybe 10 tables total with an even smaller kitchen to boot and one chef which may explain why it took us a while to get our food but it was worth the wait.

the server was really attentive and helpful and the place itself is very cute with the daily specials written on a board on the wall. the sushi rolls were just average but whats nice is that they come in half sizes so you can try more of a variety.

a cute little neighborhood sushi spot except i don't live anywhere near there but i would trek out again.
author: georgette y.

description: This place I've been eating for some years. Nothing fancy but good food. The server is nice. Since the WHOLE  place only have 3 person (1 cook, 1 help and 1 serve), so the wait time is TERRIBLE. If you're hungry, you might wanna go somewhere else.
author: Jason L.

description: Love this place!  Everyone that I have taken there loves it as well.  Don't go if you are in a rush because service can be slow at times.  Nonetheless a friendly staff!  Try the spicy tuna avocado crunch roll.
author: Lonnie A.

description: The food at this place was great.  It is a good value.  For a total of $13 (including tip) I got a dinner combination plate including a salad (DELICIOUS dressing), miso soup, rice, chicken teriyaki, and beef tatami (sp?).  The food tasted high quality and authentic.  Our waitress was friendly (we even had a typical American/Japanese language misunderstanding when she told me that the beef would be medium "layer" and it took me a few seconds to figure out that she meant medium "rare").  The small restaurant was packed with people speaking Japanese.  This place is the real deal.
author: Adam M.

description: Went here for the first.....and second time this past weekend.  That should tell you something.  We already love Miki.  It had been recommended for the Japanese food specifically.  Since our trip to Japan we hadn't been able to find anything close to authentic and tasty as in Japan...until Miki.  I got the tori toji soba which was delicious.  The boy got unagi don.  He loved his too.  I didn't expect much from the sushi since the place has no sushi bar and specializes more in cooked dishes so we only ordered a couple items for appetizers.  It was so good that when we went back we just ordered sushi.  Stick to the specials board and you won't be disappointed by anything.  Service wasn't as slow for us as others have mentioned.  Even if it was, the service is so kind and genuine, it wouldn't matter anyway.
author: M M.

description: Great food for a very reasonable price. Only drawback is if they are busy, you may be waiting 30 minutes for your food. Worth the wait though
author: John D.

description: Finally a Japanese curry place that's better than hurry curry or curry house in LA!  Went here on a Friday night and loved the find! Although we sat for a good 30 minutes staring at other tables' food, salivating and almost finishing our $6 bottle of sake, when the food finally came, it was pretty damn good! Thanks to Justin for the recommendation!  I can tell that this place is a local favorite.  Order from the board and you wont be disappointed.  Stuff on the board ranges from beef tataki, fried oysters, curry katsu, gyoza, ika karaage, and other yummy goodness.  I'd come here for the appetizer. The BF loves the katsu curry.  Just be prepared to wait. There's only one chef and one waiter.  I have to go back and try everything else on the board.  Sushi items and rolls are decent, but not mind blowing. Stick w/ the homey comfort food :)
author: Amelia S.

description: I was visiting a friend in the outer Richmond last night and we stepped out for sushi... This neighborhood joint was just right: slightly bemused but not confused waitress, one bottle each type sake, super good deal sashimi plate, super good deal nigiri plate, super fresh fish all around, super happy sushi eaters rolling back down the block. This is what SF is all about - cheap, casual and *excellent* local food, right on.
author: Bowen D.

description:
so, we're looking for a go-to japanese joint.  i'm going to be generous with the stars today, with it being the holiday season and all.  really though, can you go wrong with reggae and japanese food?  curry croquettes was good....can anything be better than fried potatoes over rice?  did i tell you i was a carb whore?  probably....

tempura, which used to be my barometer for japanese food was so-so, but i just don't do tempura anymore.  will just save that for when i'm visiting japan or something.  there's only so much disappointment a pig can take....

is this our go-to japanese joint?  probably not, but the parking is good and the food is alright, so our search will have to continue, but i'll visit miki restaurant again, because i like croquettes, dammit!
author: Miss P.

description: One of the freshest sushi joints in the city! Miki Sushi is pretty authentic for the US and they have some dishes here that I've never seen anywhere else. It's a very cozy restaurant and the staff is super friendly. The only thing that keeps this from being a 5 star review is the wait. If you come to Miki during dinner rush then you should expect for your meal to last about an hour or more. I came once when the previous tables had just been served and there was noone else waiting so my friend and I were able to get our food super quick. Even when I do have to wait, all is forgiven when I get my food anyway...
author: Queenie C.

description: I ordered saba teriyaki and sashimi from here. It must have been left on the grill too long because as I ate it, I started tasting charcoal (probably not a good sign). Though their hamachi sashimi was fresh, their soft shell crab had a unusually chewy texture. The batter was very thick and heavy. Never order it if you go here. The sushi was ok. The waitress seemed like a very friendly person. There were some japanese people showing up, which is usually a good sign. But the only thing that I was impressed by was the chicken karaage. It had a very light, crispy texture and the chicken inside was tender. But, it was the only thing that I really liked. Other than that, I wasn't too impressed by this place.
author: Kay T.

description: Unintrusive staff, but not to the point of being nonexistent.  Menu depth is excellent, with dope eats like gyu tan, and other great favorites.  Sucks if you can't read kanji or kana, because you'll miss a lot of the good eats they have to offer, so bring someone who can if you can't or you'll be stuck with the ROTM fare.  Cozy size, and just far enough off the map to be "tourist" free.
author: Al K.

description:
i really want to write good things about this place, but every time i go, it takes FOREVER to just order. then the food comes out an hour later. yes it was a saturday night, but that's ridiculous. hire another waiter please!!

the only reason i would go back is because the nabeyaki udon is frakin delicious. BUT i was so hungry by the time it came out that i singed my tongue off.
author: Lisa M.

description: Hey miki you're so good, you're so great you get an 8! well... ok so I have lived two blocks to this place for a year and last night was my first time. Great prices, small intimate space and good fresh food. Yes, slow as heck but when busy they have one guy in the kitchen and one server...just have some more sake ($6/bottle of yumminess).  Basic and creative dinner options. The salmon hand roll is really a chunk of tuna vs the mashed up not so tuna-y tuna hand rolls most people give you. Right next to hockey haven so what can be so wrong. ahh the outter richmond, how I love thee.. and walking home from thee bars/restaurants to my casa without getting jacked. Only reason for not the full blast on stars...is portion sizes and wait.
author: Gen O.

description: This is a good neighborhood spot.  It's very, very small, maybe only like 20 seats at the most. It has great home style cooking.  The food here is like mom would make.  A must get for me is the albacore tataki nigiri, love the lightly seared albacore with the light ponzu sauce.  I also like the soy sauce butter beef.  It's a very simple dish that goes great over rice.  They have the hardest working waitress / bus girl in the biz.  She has so many jobs at this place, she's Jamaican.  One night my friend's and I were there to eat, and we felt so bad for her, that we actually helped her bus the table we sat at.  She could use some help, but honestly there's no room for two people constantly moving back and forth.  There are a couple of japanese places within a two block area, but the only advantage those places have are they have more seats, and that's it.  A great spot for lunch or dinner.
author: Shane Y.

description: I love this place.  When I don't feel like cooking and want some yummy authentic japanese food this is where I head.  It's small and there is usually a wait but the staff and food are always top notch. Prices are reasonable and they have a pretty extensive menu.  I'd recommend trying  something off the white boards or getting the combination with sashimi.    Yummy!
author: kacey h.

description:
Excellent sushi. It is a small whole in the wall in the outer Richmond. I think we caught it at a time where seating did not take a long time on a Friday evening ~7pm . My friend agreed with that the portions were excellent, or "just right". I noted how service time is an issue, but the place was only half empty when we ate there, so it really was not an issue. 

The surrounding areas are quaint and quiet.
author: Rahul T.

description: This place is pretty darn good.  The quality is amazing, but the serving size is a tad small.  I had a teriyaki salmon and tempura, and both were really good.  That 2 item dinner wasn't enough, so I got a california roll with unagi as well, which was good.  Would definitely go to again, but never with a large group since the place is pretty dinky.
author: Lawrence L.

description: Yes, this place is hidden. My friend made me go!!  and we will go again!!Good for starving students on the go!! Good price and good tasting food.
author: Clementine O.

description: Shh don't tell anyone but this place is way better than Kitaro's. The service here was kinda dilatory because there are like only 3 or 4 people working the restaurant. Other than that the sushi are pretty gratifying. Arrive during lunch for the specials menu prices. Cash only during lunch and cards accepted during dinner.
author: Michael L.

description:
Homestyle Japanese food, at last.

Onion cream croquette (from the japanese menu only), asparagus shiitake saute, karaage, kushi-katsu, yukke-don, all outstanding. Go for the a la carte stuff and skip the set meals. I'm really not sure why I'm writing this review at all, because I really don't want too many people to know about this place....but oh well.
author: Inago R.

description: After watching the game at Hockey Haven I headed over in need of some food fast! We were seated right away which is always a plus. But, once we ordered it was downhill from there. The waitress mentioned after we ordered that it might be a little wait because they only have one sushi chef. I thought that was totally fine considering the size of this tiny hole in the wall sushi spot. There was only one waitress and one sushi chef and every spot was full (maybe about 5 tables in the whole place). There definitely was a wait! A LONG one! I'm not one to complain because I have a fear of spit in my food, but I was getting close to saying something. (I didn't....I'm too much of a wimp! That's what Yelp is for, so I can share my good or bad experiences!) Once the food finally came I scarfed it down so quickly I forgot to actually taste it. I think it was good.....let's just say it wasn't amazing and it wasn't horrible because I think that would stand out to me. I also didn't get sick so that's another clue that it wasn't bad. All in all, I think I'll make the extra walk over to Yu Zen next time. (p.s. this was a Tuesday night! I can only imagine what a weekend night would be like!)(p.s.s. the price was pretty good considering we also ordered a large house sake)
author: Casi C.

description:
Y'know, people say this place is good, even really good.  I had takeout from here.  Man, what a disappointment!!  Maybe there's a specialty dish that's really good here but it certainly wasn't in my takeout order.  I had the sashimi platter, teri beef/chicken katsu combination.  The sashimi were half pieces of fish.  It was literally one (1) sq inch slices of fish. The hamachi wasn't really that fresh and kinda mushy.  Maybe they cut it with a dull knife?  dunno.  The cooked food combination was so-so.  Maybe I got it on a bad day but I really can't recommend this to anyone from my experience. 

Oh yeah, I almost forgot. There's only 1 cook so the wait is long.
author: gummy j.

description: This is the second time I've been here and it was great. The only thing that was disappointing, they ran out of UNI which is my favorite! I ordered the Unagi Don and my Friend orderd this Sake Don or whatever it was called. It was Sake Sashimi over rice and she added a raw Egg and it was amazingly delicious! I will definitely return. But make sure you try to go a little bit early because the place is small and always a wait!
author: Renee Y.

description:
the only reason miki gets 4 is because i went there once and the waiter was such a dick. i know. i couldn't believe it either. i was super nice and unimposing, but the dude gave me bad spiteful service. he didn't look like he belonged there so maybe he was just a friend filling in. don't care, he sucked. that said though, the younger guy and the older guy with the really short hair are always rad. the food though-always ridiculous. it's hard not to tell friends about this place so it won't get too crowded and blown out.

author: schitzen h.

description: This teeny tiny place has great udon, and is one of the reasons it rocks to live in the Richmond. I can't not get the Nabeyaki every time. Sushi is yummy, too. But I love a big bowl of udon or soba before a show at the Balboa. And you'll marvel at the waitress' ability to pour sake without spilling a drop. Tables get filled fast at dinner time, so get there early  or be prepared to wait.
author: lee d.

description: Oishi!  Delicious food, tasty sake, good prices, friendly service. Place is small and gets hot (crowded), but we just propped the front door open and voila! Fresh air. Definitely worth going to =)
author: Odizzle D.

description: my husband and i don't get out to eat much so after a movie at the balboa theater, we thought that we could not go wrong with udon...but it took an HOUR to get our order. the food was salty and the chicken was mostly fat. terrible experience. the kitchen is disorganized and the waitress never apologized for the long wait. san franciscans ...this is the WORST!
author: lourdes l.

description: I lived in Japan for years and imagine my surprise when I moved back to the States just blocks away from Miki. This place is solid, I have eaten here countless times and never been disappointed. It's not Japan (no where is, other than Nihon!) but it's always fresh.
author: L A.

description: Boy there sure is alot to love about Miki.  This place was recommended to me by a drunken retired SF Fire Captain who resides in the nether regions of the outer Richmond.  I had band practice mere blocks away from this place for almost ten years without giving it any thought, and then I took the advice of the drunken fireman and boy am I glad.  He said that Miki had very authentic Japanese food and that he knew Japanese food.  I went and ate the unagi donburi which was delicious.  The little salad that comes with the dinner plates has the best dressing EVER!  On a recent trip they had Santa Barbara Uni on the specials board.  We know that the sushi here is pretty darn good so we tried it and it was amazing.  Not what you might expect from this type of place (not specializing in sushi)  If you find yourself out that way to catch a flick at the Balboa or maybe a brew with the locals at the Hockey Haven, be sure to check it out.  The drunken fireman was right, this place is good.
author: Matt P.

description: There's some bad comments about Miki's. First off, it's ran by Aki the owner and cook. Pops, no mom. It's small so it can take time to be served, pending when you came in. So if it's crowded and you don't have time. Simple go somewhere else. Small places usually always have things that are good, such as: the Chawan Mushi, Gyoza, most appetizers. Sushi, this is not a sushi bar, but the fish is not old. Not the best o sushi, but ok. I never thought that I'd get sick. As with most Japanese places, portion are not huge Chinese or caucausians portions, so eat more rice. That's what most Japanese would do. Rather complain. I bet most of these people who complained like those non-Japanese places ran by wannbe Japanese. Large portions, cheap, with a non-Japanese taste.
author: Local S.

description: if you want comfort japanese food, this is the place to go. it's a very small place, but the food is really good. i love the butter scallops, soy sauce better beef, and the tempera.
author: Karen H.

description: cute place, good sushi, super-convenient for balboa theater. service is a little slow (5 stars food, one off for service)
author: b p.

description: Pretty good tiny Japanese restaurant. The waitress was nice. Pretty good sushi. Would go back again.
author: VVVV H.

description: I LOVE this place almost as much as Hotaru (see my other review), but throughout the evening I got increasingly angry, as I waited 45 minutes to get my food...they're a small restaurant and the service is really slow for some reason (2 waiters).   But the udon was excellent--I love udon and that really hit the spot.  The tempura was delicious as well--probably the best I've had in a long time..maybe even since Japan...Ok, I don't know what I'm talking about anymore, but it's pretty awesome!  Go check it out!
author: judy j.

description: good cheap little japanese restaurant. theres like 6 tables and its one room, really intimate. it's usually pretty warm inside, so bring a removable coat. they are always playing some weird music i wouldnt expect a place like this to play. like 90s r&b and stuff. cool little comfort spot to try out on a cold day.
